text:
Gabaldon schoolhouses refer to the schoolhouses built by the American colonial government starting 1907 which followed one of the 10 main prototypes designed by American architect William Parsons. These were schoolhouses for elementary and intermediate or high school students.

During the American period from 1900 to 1946, education was a priority of the American colonizers, and into it the colonial government poured all the resources and personnel that it could muster. American-style education had the avowed aim of producing good, upright, skilled, and educated citizenry to benefit from and to contribute to the establishment of the American type of democracy in Asia. Toward this end, the Americans established the Bureau of Education, the predecessor of the Department of Education (DepEd) of the present.

To work for the Bureau, American teachers called Thomasites (because the first batch arrived on the USS Thomas) were brought early in the 1900s to replace soldiers who had been teaching since 1898. English was introduced as the medium of instruction.

 

The need to provide school buildings to facilitate the education of the Filipinos became immediately evident. In 1898, there were 534 schools constructed by the Spaniards. The Americans added 1,000 more school buildings and the numbers steadily grew in the first decade. The Americans adopted three kinds of school buildings: the barrio school, the municipal school, and high school buildings.

American Architect and Yale University graduate William Parsons was commissioned to design several prototypes for the schoolhouses. He designed 20 prototypes that ranged from the school with one classroom to one with more than 10 classrooms. Prototypes were also designed for elementary schools and high schools.

In 1907, assemblyman Isauro Gabaldon allotted a budget of one million pesos or $60,000 for the construction of these prototypes all over the Philippines. Because of his sponsorship of the prototype schools, they came to be known as Gabaldon Schools.

The schoolhouse prototypes ranged from 1 to 20 classrooms and depending on the budget and requirements, these were normally laid out in a straight line, L-shaped, U-shaped, or quadrilateral with a courtyard in the middle. The materials were made of wood or concrete depending on the availability of materials in the vicinity. The roof was commonly made of corrugated galvanized iron sheets on a truss system made of wood members. There were two distinctive construction systems of a Gabaldon school, one was the vertical member of truss made of round steel bars and if the walls were made of concrete, it was made of a reinforced concrete built-in wall.

 

The Gabaldon schoolhouses were invariably one-story structures raised above the ground by a meter or so to keep the wooden floor safely above the humid ground. The ceilings were about four meters high to allow hot air to rise. The ceiling kept heat generated by the roof from seeping downwards. A steep roof with wide overhangs, similar to the bahay na bato (stone house) roof, kept rain away. The windows were tall but narrow and swung outwards like the awning windows of the bahay kubo (nipa hut). These were made of wood and capiz shells. To give the school a monumental air, the facade had a portico approached by stairs that traversed the length of the building. The more common structure had a room jutting out from each end of the facade, creating a recessed effect. The initiative for building schools rested firmly on the municipal government. A level, well-drained, square site was considered ideal. The school was to be built away from the street, its distance depending on the size of the building; the bigger the school, the farther away it was to be. Grounds were needed for playfields, gardens, walks, and lawns.

There were 15 typical plans. By 1911, Plans No 4, 5, 9, and 11 were abandoned since the other plans served their purposes well. Plans No 1 and 2 had one and two rooms, respectively, and were suited for barrios. Plan No 3 was for a central barrio in a town where the average school attendance was not large. Plan No 6, designed for a central barrio whose students did not exceed 200, had the advantage of having an assembly hall and could be built in parts as municipal finances allowed. Plan No 7, similar to Plan No 6, had a storeroom and office. Plan No 10 was suitable for intermediate schools and was built in large growing towns. Plan No 12 was Plan No 10 with additions and was large enough for the needs of a large provincial capital. When completed, it formed a quadrangle and had 20 classrooms. Plans No 8 and 12 were for trade schools. Provincial high schools were designed case to case. Schools varied in cost from 2,100 to 2,700 pesos for Plan No 1 types, and from 17,000 to 22,000 pesos for Plan No 10 schools.

High school buildings, which likewise followed a longitudinal plan, could have porticos in the Renaissance style, i.e., with arches resting on columns or arches without columns. In spite of the devastations caused by World War II, many schools from the first half of the 20th century survive.

In 2003, the Department of Education or DepEd allotted a budget for the conservation of several Gabaldon schools in order to commemorate its centennial celebration. The Gabaldon school is projected as the image of the department and an icon of the education system. Since most of the Gabaldon schools were left abandoned and deteriorating, restoring these schools would add more public school classrooms, which were needed by the educational system. The restored Gabaldon school would also be the central hub of the campus as it would house not only classrooms but also common facilities, which students could use even as they appreciate the style of the old school.

DepEd issued guidelines in identifying school buildings that were to be conserved. The distinctive significance—whether architectural, historical, social, or scientific—of the Gabaldon schoolhouse marked them as deserving conservation. As one of the key buildings in a town, some schoolhouses had the added significance of being the site of historical events or being associated with a famous person. DepEd listed the following characteristics as giving significance to the schoolhouse:

1) Architectural —The buildings’ adaptation of classical forms to a tropical setting makes the schoolhouse an important heritage building.

2) Historical —The schoolhouses have historical significance because of their age. According to Republic Act No 10066, the National Cultural Heritage Act of 2009, the schoolhouse counts as an Important Cultural Property due to its age which is more than 50 years old. The schoolhouse points to the origin of DepEd as the continuation of the American education system established in 1901. The Gabaldon buildings are the living testimony of DepEd’s history.

3) Social —The schools attest to the role of education in Philippine life. Majority of Filipinos in the American period were educated in these schoolhouses, including many outstanding Filipinos, some of whom have assumed public office.

4) Scientific —Its more than 10 prototypes spread all over the Philippines are a significant accomplishment and a unique one for heritage buildings.

 Written by Melvin G. Patawaran

text:
Heritage refers to the historical, social, cultural, and religious inheritance of a place or a people that may be tangible or intangible. Using the distinction made by UNESCO in the Kyoto Heritage Convention of 1972, the National Cultural Heritage Act of 2009 or Republic Act (RA) No 10066, passed 27 Jul, defines tangible heritage as “sites, places or locations, structures and objects that last through time and remain long after their original creators have passed away,” while intangible heritage “refers to practices, customs, belief manifested externally but need to be reenacted, repeated, renewed and passed on often through oral instruction and hands-on practice.” Tangible heritage is thus applied to town plazas, buildings, fortifications, churches, schools, ancestral houses, government buildings, sites, and landscapes, as well as art works and objects of value and significance, either because they are associated with an important historical person or event, express a culture distinctly, or have artistic and aesthetic merit. Intangible heritage is applied to such things as performances of drama, music, dance, ritual, practices, local cuisine, arts, and crafts passed on from teacher to student.

The Heritage Act defines heritage zones as “historical, anthropological, archaeological, artistic geographical areas and settings that are culturally significant to the country, as declared by the National Museum and/or the National Historical Institute.” A heritage zone covers built and open sites, protects tangible heritage, and fosters the continued existence and survival of intangible heritage. This same law identifies the National Museum and/or the National Historical Institute, now National Historical Commission of the Philippines (NHCP), with the cooperation of the Housing and Land Use Regulatory Board or HLURB and other agencies, as the implementing agencies.

 

In its Implementing Rules and Regulations (IRR), RA 10066 defines other terms related to heritage zone. Historical landmark refers to “sites or structures associated with events or achievements significant to Philippine history as declared by NHCP.” Historical shrines refer to “historical sites and structures hallowed and revered for their history or association” as declared by NHCP. In addition, two terms of popular nomenclature are heritage site, which refers to specific areas, whether built or open, or a building, and historic center, which refers to the poblacion of a municipality. In lowland areas influenced by hispanic urbanism, this corresponds to the areas around the town plaza where the church complex, civic centers, market, school, town hall, hospitals, and principal houses are built.

Usually found within these historical areas are the following as defined by RA 10066: Cultural property refers to “all products of human creativity by which a people and a nation reveal their identity, including architecture and sites of human activity.” Important cultural property refers to a cultural property having exceptional cultural, artistic, and historical significance” as determined by the NHCP, the National Museum (NM), and the National Archives. National cultural treasure refers to a unique cultural property found locally, possessing outstanding historical, cultural, artistic, and/or scientific value which is highly significant and important to the country, and officially declared as such by the pertinent cultural agency. The NM is the agency that usually declares an object or site as a national treasure or an important cultural property. The latter designation is a step below national cultural treasure.

 

An NHCP declaration entitles the historical site or heritage zone to a marker and government protection. Likewise, all property declared by the NM as cultural heritage areas enjoy government protection. Interventions on them must be consistent with the characteristics of the declared site. Adaptive re-use or “the utilization of buildings, other built structures, and sites of value for purposes other than that for which they were intended originally, in order to conserve the site, their engineering integrity and authenticity of design is recognized” by the IRR. The IRR also provides for professional assistance from the government, including funding, for declared sites and properties, whether publicly or privately owned. Funding for conservation and restoration, however, is subject to availability. But the provisions of this law have proven to be beneficial, for example, in the case of the earthquake-damaged churches of Bohol and Cebu, which received assistance through the NHCP and NM.

In the Philippines, the NHCP has singled out a few areas as historical. In 2000, Pila, Laguna’s town center with its church complex and 35 residences were declared a national historical landmark. In 2001, the town center of Malolos was also declared a national historical landmark. Declared as the first Heritage Zone on 24 May 2011 is the “Old Town of Dapitan,” marked as “Ang Lumang Bayan ng Dapitan” in celebration of the 150th birth anniversary of Dr. José Rizal, who lived in Dapitan from 1892 to 1896. In 2014, a portion of Iloilo’s central business district was declared as a historic center with the title “Distritong Pangkomersyong Lungsod ng Iloilo Bilang Pook Pamana.” The zone includes the area of the former Calle Real and clusters around the Iloilo Central Market. Also in 2014, a portion of Santa Ana in Manila was declared heritage zone by the NHCP. Vigan’s heritage zone, which includes the cathedral, bishop’s palace, the Burgos house, and the many bahay na bato (stone house) of the former parian, stands unique because in 1992, it was listed in UNESCO’s World Heritage List.

Neither the NHCP nor the UNESCO’s list is exhaustive, though they indicate those sites that have passed their respective criteria. These often need thorough and adequate documentation, a local body organized to protect and conserve the heritage site, and a plan of action for conservation and protection.

Although not officially declared as such, the following are also recognized as heritage zones: Intramuros, Binondo, Escolta, University Belt, and Taft Ave Corridor, and San Juan in Metro Manila (NCR); and Baguio city center, Tayabas poblacion, Romblon poblacion, Silay City center, Cebu poblacion and Carcar center, Loay poblacion, Romblon poblacion, and Zamboanga City center in the provinces.

As the historic capital of the Philippines, Manila encapsulates the country’s architectural and built heritage. The walled city of Intramuros, the heart of Manila’s heritage zone, stands out. Although damaged during World War II, Intramuros has been partially restored, and its walls still speak of the Spanish legacy. Across the Pasig and north of Intramuros are two business districts: Binondo, which represents the Spanish era, and Escolta, which represents the American. But representing the American years best is the Taft Avenue Corridor, enclosed by three parallel roads that run north to south: Roxas Blvd (formerly Dewey), Taft Ave, and San Marcelino. Bounded north by the Central Post Office on the banks of the Pasig and Rizal Memorial Stadium on Pablo Ocampo St (formerly Vito Cruz), this zone contains public and private buildings associated with the American colonial era. In this zone are the Legislative Building, the Finance and Agriculture Buildings (now all part of the National Museum complex), the Supreme Court and Court of Appeals, the Philippine General Hospital, and the University of the Philippines. Along Roxas Blvd are Manila Hotel, Rizal Shrine, Elks Club, Army-Navy Club, American Embassy which used to be the residence of the American Commissioner, and other hotels. Scattered in the area are churches, schools like St. Paul’s and De La Salle, residences, and business establishments.

The University Belt along C.M. Recto Ave (formerly Azcarraga) and España is so named because of the many schools clustered in the area. The City of Manila and NHCP declared Santa Ana, along Pedro Gil and around the church of Nuestra Señora de los Desamparados, a heritage zone. San Juan’s heritage zone is along N. Domingo and P. Guevarra Sts. On the elevated portion of P. Guevarra known as Little Baguio are grand houses, a few even from the American era.

Baguio is the direct result of Daniel H. Burham’s plan for a summer retreat on a hill station for the American civil government and bureucracy. The heritage areas here include the city center around Burnham Park, northward to Teachers’ Camp, Mansion House, Camp John Hay and Baguio Country Club, and the surrounding hills Aurora, Dominican, and Mirador.

The Malolos heritage district is composed of the Barasoain district, which includes the Barasoain Church and convento, several bahay na bato on Paseo del Congreso, and the restored casa real (royal house); and across the bridge, the older poblacion dominated by the Malolos Cathedral, convento, and plaza, including the ancestral houses around the church and plaza, especially in the pariancillo or kamestisuhan barrio right next to the church where most of the Women of Malolos lived and where most of the offices of the Malolos Republic were housed.

Tayabas is the old capital of Quezon Province. The heritage zone is in the town center, with the church of San Miguel and the casa real. At the boundaries of the town are the Spanish colonial cemetery, with its chapel and bridges from the same era that connect the capital to the rest of the province.

Although Silay has not been officially declared by the NHCP as a heritage zone, a number of structures have been marked by the agency. The city itself has marked other ancestral houses and historic structures, thereby virtually declaring Silay’s center as a heritage zone.

While the NHCP has declared the central business district of Iloilo a heritage zone, the zone may actually be expanded south to include Plaza Libertad, Gen. Hughes St until Fort San Pedro, which has been demolished. This zone is the site of historic church of San Jose, the Elizalde and Ker houses, Colegio de Sagrado Corazon, the Casino Español, the English Club, and theaters such as Prince. Northward, the zone may include “millionaires row,” which is along the road that connects Iloilo with Jaro and Zarraga. Molo up to Arevalo Sts along the highway could be considered as a heritage zone.

Cebu’s heritage zone is defined by the areas around Fort San Pedro, the Basilica Minore of the Santo Niño, the Cathedral, the Parian and Tinago districts, and the southern end of Colon St. Structures built here are from the Spanish and American colonial eras. The Cebu City Hall, the Maritima building, and the Gotiaco Building are from the American era. Another heritage zone is midtown and uptown Cebu where the Fuente Osmeña, the Bradford Memorial Church, and the Cebu Provincial Capitol—all from the American era—are located. The town of Carcar has two foci: the Santa Catalina church and its immediate environs, and the lower town linked by a road system that connects to the National Highway. Loay’s heritage zone is on the hill where the church is located and at the foot of the hill where there are ancestral houses.

The Romblon poblacion are possible heritage zones. Romblon’s heritage zone is defined by the pier, plaza, church complex, city hall, provincial capitol, and hills that flank the poblacion where the fortifications are located.

Zamboanga’s heritage zone is defined by Fort Pilar, which represents the Spanish era, and the Zamboanga City Hall, which represents the American era. Within this area are found the residence of Gen “Blackjack” Pershing who was appointed military governor of Moro Province and the park named after him. Pettit Barracks, the Ateneo de Zamboanga, and the Knights of Columbus are also found in this zone.

Heritage zones define a city or town. They contribute to the sense of history and continuity of a place, give it an identity, and foster neighborliness instead of individualism and separation.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Nicanor G. Tiongson

photos.photodesc:
Sama Dilaut (Badjao) houseboat in Sitangkai, Sulu

(A Philippine Album: American Era Photographs 1900-1930 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1998)

Casco, a large wooden houseboat

(Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994)

text:
Houseboats, as the term suggests, are boats that also serve as residences. These are found among the seafaring Sama Dilaut (Badjao). As of the 1930s, the Badjao had three types of boats: the fast sailing vinta, the fishing lipa/lepa, and the sapit. The latter two may be considered houseboats. The lipa, a longer and slower boat than the vinta, had no outriggers and was used as a residence. The houseboat, which never left the anchorage, was 12-15 m long and 1.80 m wide, and had a palaw (house) mounted on it, which made it top-heavy and cumbersome for maneuvering on the open sea. However, the palaw of both the lipa and the djenging can be dismantled so that the boats can be used for fishing or speedy travel.

The Sama Dilaut of Tungkalang have three types of boats: the lepa; the djenging; and the dapang. The houseboats are the lepa and djenging, whereas the dapang is used for fishing and long trips. The boats are dugouts or made of casco (timber or log) that are hollowed out. Of the three boats, the lepa is without outriggers. From end to end, or bow to stern, its hull is about 11 m. Its palaw consists of a long pole with a sapaw (nipa roof) slung over it. An adult cannot stand straight inside the palaw, which is only a meter high.

 

The djenging is considered by the Sama Dilaut to be their oldest type of houseboat, which they trace back to their ancestors. The hull of this boat is 15 m long and 2 m wide, on the average. Its palaw has four dingding (walls), windows, doors, and a galvanized iron roof. The walls may be of either wood or thatched coconut palm leaves. The cooking area is at the bow, which is the front part of the boat; one enters the palaw through the stern. It is simply furnished: a sail, a lamp for fishing, a water jar, a stove, several pots, plates, poles, a baul (chest), perhaps a suitcase, pillows and mats, and above the roof, fishing gear held by two poles with forked ends.

The Sama Dilaut’s home is also a place of worship; they have no special structures designated as such. Thus, the palaw’s interiors may also include the hainan, a bar 1.5 meters long that represents the ancestral spirits. It is carved in the ukkil/okir/okil style, which consists of lines, curves, and geometric shapes painted in the traditional Sama Dilaut colors of green, red, yellow, blue, and white.

The largest houseboat, no longer being built, was the balutu or kubu, which was the residence of a wealthy panglima (community leader). The house was 10 m long and 3 to 4 m wide; thus, it was the most spacious of the houseboats. Running along the top of the front and back walls of its house were panels with the lauwa-lauwa (cobwebs), which were very finely carved designs. This was similar to the calado in the Spanish-period bahay na bato (stone house) owned by the Christianized elite.

 

The traditional Sama Dilaut houseboat is a sculptural and visual work of art. Up to the 1960s, individual master boat builders were known by name and highly respected for their artistic genius. First, with the use of his patuk (tools), the tukang (boat builder) works upon the natural shape of the casco that will become the baran (keel). This determines the boat’s basic structure. The hull of the boat is a layer of planks that are laid on the hollowed-out log. Each plank must be deliberately bent to fit the shape of the keel. The plank is balanced on a pile of rocks like a seesaw so that each end can be bent down by weights. The katig (bamboo outriggers) are bent in the same way so that the ends will rise slightly from the surface of the water.

Wooden ornaments carved with ukkil designs are attached to the jung-ar (prow). The most eye-catching of these is the sa-am, an elaborately carved and brightly colored wing-like extension jutting from the bow. Designs for the sa-am are the dragon, the sarimanok, and the buaya, which imitates a crocodile’s gaping mouth. The ling-ai-at is a strip of decorative carving placed underneath the jung-ar. Additionally, a bar in the ukkil design stretches along the whole length of the boat itself.

Related to the houseboat is the casco, a flat-bottomed boat used for transporting goods at a short distance. Popular from the 19th to the early years of the 20th century, the casco in Manila and its environs also had provisions for living. Toward the rear of the casco, an area covered with sawali matting was used for sleeping and eating.

On the flooded plains along the banks of the Agusan River are the floating houses of Bunawan, Agusan del Sur. These residences, built by the Manobo, are placed on top of a raft of timbers. The raft rises or sinks with the overflow of the river. Unlike boats, these houses do not travel but are tied to piles, trees, or stone anchors.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Rosario Cruz-Lucero

Ukkil-style panolong of the Maranao torogan in Lanao

(CCP Collection)

Hanunuo Mangyan house in Mindoro, ca 1990

(CCP Collection)

text:
“Indigenous house” refers to domestic architecture among the ethnolinguistic groups of the Philippines, and includes the lowland houses called bahay kubo (nipa hut), as well as the dwellings found among the cultural communities in the Philippines and known by various names. They can be as elaborate as the Maranao torogan (datu’s large house) or as simple as the dait-dait, the windscreen of the Aeta. These houses are created in the typical Southeast Asian fashion with no architects, guided only by traditional wisdom and a humanistic vision of the house as a setting for relationships with other human beings and with nature. The indigenous house shares common features with the rest of Southeast Asian indigenous architecture, namely, piles or posts to elevate the floor of the house, and the gable or hip roof.

Whether built on a hill, mountain, plain, river, or sea, these structures are fashioned out of the bounties of the earth—wood, vegetation, sometimes mud. Bamboo is the favorite material, as in most of Southeast Asia. It is used for posts, flooring, siding, roofing, and many other purposes. Materials may include coconut wood and leaves; bakawan or mangrove; hardwoods such as narra, pine, and molave; stones; cogon grass, nipa, and banana bark for roof coverings and wall sidings; and rattan and other vines for fastening.

 

Most indigenous houses conform to a general pattern: they have steep thatched roofs to keep out the rain; they are elevated on posts or stilts, the answer to floods and the dampness and humidity of the earth; and they have slatted flooring, which allows the cool air from below to enter the house. In the lowlands, they use bamboo, nipa, and cogon to help keep out the heat; and in the uplands, tightly fitting solid planks to help keep out the cold. In the absence of walls or partitions within the house, the use of different levels, even mats or a fireplace in a corner, can differentiate one section from another. This generally results in a multipurpose one-room structure, which is light and airy, comfortable and functional, yet durable and structurally stable.

The decoration of the house is often a good fusion of aesthetics and social, political, and religious realities. Pig skulls or carabao horns may adorn a house mainly for social prestige. Among the Maranao, the colorful panolong (decorative beam-ends) of houses indicate one’s social position.

Culture dictates a set of beliefs and assumptions decidedly indigenous that govern the choice of site, time, and season for building; rituals to be observed before and during the construction of the house, including the reading of signs or omens that may affect the progress of the work; orientation of the house as well as the distribution of interior parts; and such other beliefs and practices that assure good health and a prosperous, happy family life, as well as protection from evil spirits for both occupants and builders.

 

Rituals and celebrations are a way of life for the indigenous peoples, and for these occasions the house doubles as a social and a cultural center. Ritual platforms are then built near the house or attached to it; otherwise, different parts of the house, such as the porch, or the whole house itself can be transformed into the setting for these rituals or ceremonies by simply moving or altering some parts to allow for more space and create a more appropriate setting.

With such frequency of rituals and life-cycle celebrations, a strong sense of community and indigenous identity inevitably emerges. People work together, build houses together, do things together in a spirit of harmony and togetherness. In such a culture that permits and encourages maximum interaction of people, communication is largely indirect, intimate, accomplished through suggestions, hints, gestures, and symbols, where each message may be decoded with ease and fluency by the members of that culture.

Territorial spaces are not marked by fences or walls, but merely suggested by certain symbols which are, however, accorded a certain degree of respect by the other residents in the area and by passersby. The following are avoided: littering within another’s space; allowing cows or carabaos to stray into a neighbor’s area; and passing too near a neighbor’s window where someone may be sleeping.

While privacy is generally observed within the understood limits of each area within and without the house, the plot of land or the designated zone at sea or along the shoreline where the houses are built remains communal property. Thus, the responsibility of maintaining the surroundings—e.g., the hill where the cluster of houses stands—rests on all the residents in the area. Common areas give the children a wider and bigger area for play, and adults more opportunities for socializing, with the increased number of possible conversation sites.

It may be surmised that the earliest architectural improvisations bear the same pattern as present-day indigenous houses, and that the basic features of lowland dwellings, the bahay kubo of the Christian indigenous populace, had already been established even before Spanish contact.

Indigenous dwellings developed with changing life styles and modes of sustenance: the lean-to evolving from the highly nomadic life of hunters and food gatherers such as the Aeta; the bamboo or wooden, one-room houses emanating from the more settled life of dry- and wet-rice cultivators such as the Cordillera groups; and the elevated house standing in water for seafaring groups in the south such as the Sama and Tausug of Sulu, and fishing communities along the coast across the Philippine archipelago. During times of intercommunity strife, when the warriors’ culture prevailed, tree houses were built by several indigenous groups, such as the Samarnon of eastern Visayas; the Bugkalot (Ilongot) and the Gaddang of northern Luzon, and the Mandaya, Manobo, and the Bukidnon peoples of Mindanao. In Batanes, sturdy, stone dwellings with thick grass roofs have withstood frequent typhoons. Other house types that evolved in response to various conditions are the longhouse for community dwelling among the Mangyan of Mindoro; the twin houses of the Itawit of Cagayan Valley; and the multi-level house of the Tagbanua of Palawan and the Manobo.

Indigenous concepts of building would persist well into the succeeding periods. In the bahay na bato (stone house) of the Spanish colonial period, the tsalet (chalet) of the American colonial period, and even the barong-barong of the contemporary period, the prototypal indigenous house is recognized despite changes in material, scale, plan, and elevation.

The indigenous house has also provided motifs and elements for modern houses and buildings. Francisco Mañosa’s design for Pearl Farm on Samal Island is inspired by the Sama’s houses on stilts. The ridge beam of the Tausug houses have inspired carved ridge beams in diverse projects such as municipal halls, hotels, and restaurants. The indigenous house remains a rich source of ideas for architecture.

The indigenous house is a structure that copes with the specific conditions of Philippine geography, climate, and environment. It is also the embodiment of indigenous values relating to family, clan, community, and class. As a structure that expresses the unity of the people, nature and society, the indigenous house embodies some of the best characteristics of architecture that can be called Filipino.  Written by Ma. Corazon A. Hila, updated by René B. Javellana

Manobo granary in Mindanao, 1905

(CCP Collection)

Kamalig made of bricks, formerly housing the Tabacalera, now the Museo Ilocos Norte in Laoag City, 2013

(Emir Sicangco)

Granary in Bontoc Province

(The Bontoc Igorot by Albert Jenks, Manila Bureau of Printing, 1905)

text:
The kamalig, also known as kamarin (from Spanish camarin, “cabin”), alan, alang, bangan, baysa, falig, tambubong, and tangkil, is a granary—i.e., a storehouse for grain.

The storage of rice and corn, which is harvested once to three times a year, is an important preoccupation of farming communities. Therefore, the granary is their most important economic structure. This is indicated by the history of place names in certain regions of the Philippines. Tambobong is the old name of Malabon, Manila. Camalig, which is the original name of Albay, is said to derive from a shed-shaped hill next to the town. The town gave its name to the province of which it was a part until 1847, when the new province of Albay was established.

 

The meticulous construction of the granary produces distinctive and striking structures such as those in the Cordilleras. The alang of the Ifugao and alan of the Isneg are smaller replicas of the bale/fale (house), which are of wood and cogon. These are built on posts with lidi/liphon/libong (rat guards) that can take the form of disks, knobs, or cylinders. The Ifugao alang has wooden walls called gaob in Kiangan/Hungduan. The Isneg alan has walls of sawali (woven bamboo strips) that flare outwards, thus giving it the shape of a large basket. On the other hand, the falig (granary) of the Bontok is built at the center of their fayu (house). It is raised above the living quarters on the ground floor.

Inside these granaries are the bulol, a representation of the Cordillera rice god, and the pun-amhan, or the ritual box. Under the alang, the mumbaki (priest) performs the baki-hongan di page, which is the ritual for the agricultural cycle. Offerings of animals are made as the mumbaki chants and prays to the Ifugao gods and ancestors for a bountiful harvest.

 

In lowland communities, the silong or space beneath the bahay kubo (nipa hut) can be a place for storing grain. However, the more common practice is to store grain in the kamalig/kamarin, which is a separate building. The term “kamalig” remained in use during the Spanish colonial period despite adaptations made by the people to changing circumstances.

Two common methods of storing rice appeared during the Spanish period. The more common was to keep sacks of rice in the zaguan or lower floor of the bahay na bato (stone house). These were piled up side by side with carriages as well as equipment and supplies needed by the household. Big landlords, who took a share of their tenants’ harvest, kept rice in large stone buildings, also called “kamalig” or “camarin.” The term almacen was also used, but this term could also refer to stores for buying and selling. The kamalig consisted of a thick wall of stone and mortar in which small openings were made; hence the interior was almost always dark. A single entrance with a sturdy door was usually cut into the center of the long side of the kamalig. The building could have a roof of nipa, tile, or galvanized iron. Tile was the common roofing material because it kept the interior cool. The interior was a large space in keeping with its function of storage. Many kamalig still stand.

In the sugar plantations of Negros Occidental, Spanish-period 19th-century kamarin are intact, though few remain in use as storage buildings. Originally these were for storing equipment, tools, and machine spare parts, such as those of the hydraulic or the carabao-drawn sugar mills. These were also spacious enough to function as evacuation sites for the plantation workers and their families during typhoons and floods. When sugar centrals took over the milling process with 20th-century technology, the kamarin were abandoned.

A kamalig in Laoag, Ilocos Norte, once the storehouse of tobacco for the government company Tabacalera, is now the Ilocos Norte Museum. An ethnographic museum, it is called Gameng—a word meaning treasure. The structure resembles a church because of its pitched roof and longitudinal plan. A ruined kamalig standing near the Marikina Church has fluted pilasters in the upper story. It has been restored and is used as the Shoe Museum of Marikina, which highlights the town’s best known product.

 

As modern methods of drying and storing rice developed, so did the structures for storage. The national government, through the Department of Agriculture’s National Food Authority (NFA), built warehouses for storing bought grain. These large, long buildings have steel frames and galvanized iron sheets. The entrance is at the center of the long side. Provisions have been made so that delivery trucks can come in and out of the building with ease. Rice traders build smaller versions of the NFA-type warehouse. Structures using galvanized iron sheets for walls and roofing over a metal or wooden frame are common.  Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Joy B. Mananghaya

photos.photodesc:
Leyte Capitol in Tacloban City, ca 1990

(Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

text:
In the Philippines, the kapitolyo or capitol, from the Latin word capitolium, has always referred to the building of the provincial government, located in the capital town or city. The kapitolyo houses the three branches of the provincial government: the executive, which includes the office of the Governor; the legislative, including the offices and meeting room of the Provincial Board; and the judicial or the court. The term has never been applied to the national legislature in Manila, which has been called the National Assembly or later on, Congress.

The term capitol originally referred to the Temple of Jupiter on the Capitoline Hill in Rome and was later applied to city halls of the Roman empire. In the United States, the Capitol is the building in Washington, DC that houses Congress. The kapitolyo was introduced during the American period. During the Spanish regime, although a town was designated the capital of the province, there was no specific type of building for the provincial government.

 

Following norms set down by William Parsons, consulting architect of the Philippine government from 1905 to 1914, the kapitolyo was located in a park, away from the center of the old town, in a place that was dignified and restful. Thus, kapitolyo are found in spacious grounds or at the end of a broad boulevard, or when possible, on a bayshore.

The entire building or its main portion was rectangular in plan, two to three stories in height, and set on a podium consisting of several steps. A two-story portico at the center of the facade sheltered the entrance which had one or several doors. In some instances, one-story buildings flanked the main body of the building. The spacious rooms had high ceilings and large windows and were arranged along broad corridors.

Most kapitolyo were in the neoclassic or Greek-revival style, characterized by the use of columns, entablatures, and pediments. Their architecture was influenced by the Ecole des Beaux Arts of Paris, which championed neoclassicism and had influenced architectural schools in the US where the early 20th-century Filipino architects were trained.

Among the notable kapitolyo in the neoclassic style are those of Batangas and Cebu; the one in Laguna built in 1912; the Sorsogon Capitol built in 1916; the Pangasinan Capitol built in 1918; the Negros Occidental Capitol in Bacolod, designed by Juan Arellano and completed in 1933; and the Leyte Capitol designed by Antonio Toledo. Some kapitolyo, such as those of Bulacan in Malolos and Tayabas (now Quezon) in Lucena, departed from the neoclassic style and tended toward the modern.

Since the 1970s, new capitols have been built either to replace older ones or to construct new ones for recently organized provinces. When Pasig became a chartered city, Rizal moved its capitol to Taytay, where a neoclassical capitol with Grecian temple facade and a dome were built. Saranggani, in Mindanao, has a capitol also in the neoclassical style. That of Sulu province in Jolo is inspired by the shape and motifs of Islamic architecture, like the dome and the geometrically decorated entrance reminiscent of the iwan. When the Autonomous Region of Muslim Mindanao was created, a central building was constructed, with a roof quoting vernacular and regional architecture characterized by projecting roof beams.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III

photos.photodesc:
Fuerza de Santa Isabel, Spanish colonial fortification in Taytay, Palawan

(Fortress of Empire: Spanish Colonial Fortifications of the Philippines, 1565-1898 by René Javellana and Jose Maria Lorenzo Tan, The Bookmark, Inc, 1997)

Ijang, the Ivatan fortification in Savidug, Sabtang Island, Batanes

(Fortress of Empire: Spanish Colonial Fortifications of the Philippines, 1565-1898 by René Javellana and Jose Maria Lorenzo Tan, The Bookmark, Inc, 1997)

text:
The kuta, also known as muog and tanggulan (from the Tagalog tanggol, meaning “defend,” and an, a suffix to denote place), and later as fuerza, fortaleza, trinchera, and baluarte, is a fortification—that is, a structure built to protect the lives and property of a community against enemies. Fortifications are often built in strategic locations where protection is provided by such natural barriers as waters, swamps, cliffs, hills, mountains, and narrow passes. High grounds, which function as natural fortifications are called ili or ilihan in Visayan. Ilihan Hill in Dapitan is an example of such a fortification. In Ilocano, ili can mean village or one’s native place. It is not unusual for these high grounds to be inhabited over time.

Indigenous fortifications use stakes driven into the ground, earthwork, and stones piled on top of each other to improve the natural defense of a site. Cordillera communities locate their villages in areas which can be easily defended. Entrances to villages may be protected by low stone walls. The Ivatan fortify elevated places accessible only through narrow paths. Rocks are stockpiled in the idjang, the places of refuge, in case of enemy attack.

 

Islamic communities call fortifications kuta, “whether constructed of stone or earth” (Majul 1961). In its broadest sense, kuta refers to any fortified position, so that even well-protected residential compounds may be regarded as examples of kuta. In 1609, Antonio Morga reported that indigenous fortifications consisted of putting up “walls of palm trees and stout arigue (wooden posts) filled with earth.” Lantaka (native cannons) were mounted at strategic points on these walls. Houses were usually located inside the fort to insure the safety of the inhabitants.

Although forts were built in non-Muslim communities, notably in Pampanga and the riverine settlements along the Pasig, the best kuta were found in Muslim communities. So effective were they that they repelled advancing Spanish and American troops. The best known Muslim kuta during the Spanish period were Raja Sulayman’s in Manila, perhaps one of the earliest Muslim kuta, which had a palisade of palm-tree logs surmounting a narrow mound and from which medium-sized artillery were mounted; Sultan Kudarat’s in Ilihan heights close to his capital in Lamitan in Cotabato, its name derived from kuta and bato (stone), and having trenches around designed by the Dutch; the Maguindanao and Buayan string of kuta, which featured long-range cannons of Portuguese and Dutch manufacture, and were built on hills, swamps, and plains along the Pulangi River; the Maranao kuta in Lanao, which vexed the Spaniards greatly; the Sama kuta in Sipak, Balangingi, Sungap, and Bukotingul, the most formidable being the Sipak kuta which had 5.4-6 meter-high walls of thick tree trunks filled with coral, rock, soil, and earth.

 

The Sulu kuta of Raja Bongsu, located on a hill close to Jolo on one of the slopes of Bud Tumantangis, had a system of interlocking trenches and walls of stout tree trunks, and had an ordinance of native lantaka and Spanish cannons. The fort, considered impregnable, resisted several assaults by Spaniards. It fell only when an outbreak of cholera, dysentery, and smallpox forced the occupants to surrender.

Other forms of indigenous fortification are the tree house and the strong house made of hardwood called muog in Tagalog. Around 1672, Ignacio Alzina provided an illustration of the Visayan tree house, which one approached using a retractable ladder or a rope or vine. He explained in his Historia de las Islas e Indios de Visayas (History of the Islands of the Natives of Visayas) that the ladder was used to bring women and children safely to the tree house, while the rope or vine was used by men.

During the American period, the kuta, such as the Sahipa kuta on the western slope of Bud Sinuman in Sulu, continued to be built. However, such archaic fortifications proved inutile under attacks by heavy American artillery, which knocked them down.

Spain introduced the European system of fortification, which may be categorized into field and permanent fortification. Field fortification was used during battle and was usually a reinforced trench or an embankment of stone and gravel, supported by a palisade. Permanent fortification used stone and mortar. The best fuerza or fortaleza was made of thick walls of masonry. Forts of lower grade were the estacada (palisade) made of stout tree trunks stuck to the ground to form a wall, and the terraplen (earthwork).

The first permanent fortification built by the Spaniards was a circular roofed tower on the southern side of Intramuros, facing the hermitage of Nuestra Señora de Guia after which the tower was named. It was designed by the Jesuit Antonio Sedeño and built ca 1587 during the governorship of Santiago de Vera. Criticized in 1595 as medieval, the tower was incorporated into Bastion San Diego, a corner of the defensive system that Gov-Gen Perez de Dasmariñas built around Manila.

Intramuros was considered the premier fortification built by the Crown. It underwent a number of renovations to improve its defensive capability, especially after the British successfully occupied Manila from 1762 to 1764. Other major defenses include Fuerza de San Felipe in Cavite, Fuerza de San Pedro in Cebu which was built ca 1600, Fuerza de Nuestra Señora del Rosario in Iloilo built in 1617, and Fuerza de Nuestra Señora del Pilar in Zamboanga, built in 1635 under the name San José, demolished in 1663, then rebuilt in 1719.

rThese forts were constructed following the most advanced system of fortification. The forts were laid out as polygons—Intramuros, a pentagon of unequal sides; San Pedro in Cebu, a triangle; and Nuestra Señora del Pilar, a quadrilateral. Thick cortina (connecting walls), about 3-10 m, connected protruding baluarte (bulwarks) built at every corner of the polygon. Soldiers stationed on these bulwarks had a good view of the connecting walls and could easily ward off attackers seeking to ram the gate or breach or scale the walls. The walls could be vaulted structures providing space within for shelter and storage. Around the 18th century, parapeto (parapets), an innovation in military architecture, were added to the walls and bulwarks. The walls could have a casamata (platform) on which were mounted the artillery that guarded the foso (moat), and a garita (guardhouse of wood or masonry) to protect sentinels from heavy rain. The moat, a deep and wide ditch surrounding the fort, was usually filled with water. The moat was fortified with masonry: the inner wall, nearer the fortification, was called escarpa; the outer wall was called contraescarpa; and its depths, fondo. A falsabraga (low wall), called barbacana in ancient times, was built in between the moat and the walls to serve as protection for the higher and principal wall. Sometimes a contrafoso (second moat) was dug to improve defenses. Another feature of fortifications of this era was the revellin or rebellin, polygonal in plan, like the bulwark, and built in front of the puerta (entrance) of the fortification to delay direct attack. Open on the side facing the principal wall, the revellin was linked to the gate by a covered road. If the fort had a moat, part of this road had a drawbridge. Provisions for water, living quarters, ammunition, and military offices were found in the fort. A chapel occupied a secure area within. Soldiers usually prayed before a battle, and a military chaplain was on hand to hear their confession and bless them.

To protect the Christianized communities from marauding pirates, slave raiders from the south, and foreign invaders, and also to protect the path of the galleon, the economic lifeblood of the colony, a complex system of fortifications began to be erected as early as the 1630s in towns along the galleon route and the route of pirates. The town church itself, if made of stone or brick, was the most important defensive structure. Beside the church, the tall bell tower served as a lookout, and the tolling of its bells signaled the approach of enemies. To augment the church’s defensive capabilities, walls were built to its side or surrounding it. The corners of these walls sometimes had bulwarks on which artillery was mounted. Outstanding examples of walled churches are found in Baclayon, Bohol; Boac, Marinduque; and Cuyo, Palawan. Small freestanding forts were called fortin, an outstanding example of which is the Castillo de San Vicente Ferrer at Punta Cruz, Maribojoc, Bohol.

The baluarte and castillo were two other defensive structures built at strategic places according to plan. Located on a hilltop, the baluarte was a fortified structure with slit trenches, blockhouses of stone, and a palisade of wooden logs or palm trunks with an embankment. In it was the residence of the castellan, the officer in charge of the fort, and sometimes a parade ground. Building the baluarte took more than three months. The castillo was less costly to build. If not built of stone, it was a structure with four sturdy posts, an elevated platform, and a roof resembling an oversized dovecote. The baluarte and castillo were not impregnable. In fact without ammunition, these were reduced to vulnerable structures of stone or wood. Other defensive systems were devised including the planting of pandan thickets and the scattering of star thistles along the enemy’s path.

Signal systems were devised to warn the populace of an impending attack. Sentinels posted on the baluarte or castillo struck a hollowed tree trunk or wooden gong like the balalong, batong, and tatolong, or blew a horn, which could be a big shell called bodyong in the Visayas, or a handcrafted carabao horn called tambuli in Tagalog. The ringing of church bells was the most common signal. Flags, baskets hoisted on poles, bonfires, candles, torches, the firing of three cannon shots, and even fireworks were also used to signal impending attack.

Delgado, writing in 1754, listed other forts in the country:

In the Luzon-Palawan area were Fort of Playa Honda in Pangasinan; Fort of Mamamalas in Lubao, Pampanga; Fort San Francisco in Nueva Segovia, Lal-lo, Cagayan; Fort San Jose Cavicunga, Fort San Jose Capinatan, Fort Santiago, and the forts of Tuao and Cabagan in Cagayan Valley; Fort of Taytay in Palawan; and Forts of Cuyo, La Lutaya, Linapacan, and Culion in the Calamianes Island group.

In the Visayas were Fort of Capiz, Panay Island, which was a palisade; Fort of Romblon Island; Forts of Carigara and Palo, Leyte; Forts of Baclayon and Dauis, Bohol; and the forts of Palapag, Lauang, Catbalogan, and Guiuan in Samar.

In Mindanao, there were Forts Santiago and San Francisco in Dapitan, Zamboanga del Norte; Fort of Iligan in Lanao del Norte; Fort San Jose in Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental; Forts of Linao in Agusan; and the forts of Tandag and Cateel, Davao Oriental.

Fr San Antonio added the following to Delgado’s list: Fort Santiago Itugud and Fort Cabaga in Cagayan Valley. Besides these, Fort Nuestra Senora de Triunfo was built in Ozamis during the 18th century.

Both Delgado’s and San Antonio’s lists are incomplete, though. In the later part of the 19th century, forts were built in Jolo, Sulu; Lamitan, Basilan; and Bongao, Tawi-Tawi. Taken together they formed a defense network. A survey of colonial fortifications completed for the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2008 documented more than 350 structures consisting of permanent forts, watchtowers, small forts or fortín, gun emplacement points, fortified towns, and churches.

Most of the fortifications that dotted the Philippines were built at the initiative of the townsfolk under their parish priest. The Franciscans in Albay, the Recollects in Mindanao, Palawan, and Mindoro, the Jesuits in Bohol and Mindanao, and even the secular priests in Antique built many fortifications with government approval. As ammunition and artillery were modernized, the thick connecting walls that characterized fuerzas built during the 17th and 18th centuries were replaced by thinner walls with more provisions for rifles. A government-built 19th-century fort is at Pikit, Cotabato toward the direction of the headwaters of the Pulangi River. It was built on a hill to forestall any Maguindanao attack on the Christian settlements downstream. With the coming of the Americans and more sophisticated weapons like the Winchester repeating rifles, the Spanish fort became obsolete. Although soldiers did take refuge behind these old walls, dug trenches, and set up palisades and sandbag walls during the Philippine-American War and World War II, the fort of masonry was no longer built. Forts like McKinley, later renamed Bonifacio, were tracts of land surrounded by wire fences. This was also the case for Camp Keithley in Lanao and Fort Stotsenberg (later renamed Clark Field) in Pampanga.

Some of these fortifications have found a new use that has proven to be popular. A number have been turned to parks and venues for events. Examples are the Fort San Pedro in Cebu, Fort Isabel in Taytay, Palawan, and Fort del Pilar in Zamboanga.  Written by Ma. Corazon A. Hila and René B. (Studio 5 Designs, Inc., Land Bank of the Philippines Collection)

text:
The kuweba (from Spanish cueva “cave,”), also known as yungib, kweba, liyang, langub, butas, lagusan, lungga, may also be an overhang or a rock shelter. It is a term associated with ancient habitation, enchantment, mystery, the supernatural, worship, ritual, burial, and treasure. Since the appearance of modern man on the planet about 200,000 years ago, caves have been a very essential means of man’s survival. Prehistoric humans used caves as their dwelling place, source of water, a place for making pottery, tools and weapons; and for protection from heavy rain and cold. Eventually, humans used caves to bury their dead, to perform ceremonial or ritual activities, and to express their artistic talents. Thus, such caves have a high cultural and scientific significance.

In the Philippines, the oldest known human fossil was retrieved in Callao Cave, Peñablanca, Cagayan Province. Dated about 67,000 years old, this human fossil is the oldest that has yet been found in the Philippines. Callao Cave is one of the biggest caves in the massive Peñablanca limestone formation, which is covered with lush vegetation. It is located on the formation’s higher elevation. The cave opening is 50 m wide and 36 m high. Composed of seven large chambers with stalactites growing from the ceiling and stalagmites on the cave floor, the cave is well lit. Skylight from the large openings and the crevices on the ceiling illuminates the large chambers, making this cave ideal for habitation.

 

The most popular ancient habitation sites are found in the Tabon Cave Complex located in Lipuun Point, Quezon, Palawan Province. Archaeological explorations and excavations in the area since the 1960s have yielded numerous artifacts and ecofacts that provide insights on 50,000 years of Philippine prehistory. The most important find is the set of human remains dating to 47,000 years ago, recovered from a cave popularly known as Tabon. It is named after the flightless megapod bird that buries its eggs in a mound and is thus known as the “Philippine mound builder.”

Tabon Cave is located at the foot of a cliff about 34 m above sea level, with one chamber and a big mouth, measuring 8 m high and 16 m wide. The large dome-shaped chamber, which is more than 40 m long, has stalactites growing on the ceiling. It is constantly sun-lit, making it a perfect place for human occupation. In this cave, studies made on the human remains and associated tools provide significant information on the subsistence patterns of humans during the Paleolithic Age, or the Old Stone Age (50,000–8,000 years ago). They were hunter-gatherers who lived in caves and used chert tools with sharp edges. In this cave, they hunted bats and birds, which were their primary sources of protein.

In Bongao, Tawi-Tawi Province, a prehistoric habitation site that can be traced back to the Neolithic Period (8,810 to 5,190 years ago), was discovered in Balobok Rock Shelter, considered as one of the oldest and most significant archaeological sites in Mindanao. Located along a cove in Sanga-Sanga Island, the Balobok Rock Shelter is a coral limestone formation resembling an amphitheater, 19 m long and 10 m wide.

From the interior of the rock shelter, the ground surface, or flooring, slopes slightly 12-15 m, then drops abruptly to the shore. The floor is 10 m above sea level while the sides extend to the water to form a cove, which has a sandy white beach. The archaeological excavation undertaken by the National Museum has yielded significant archaeological materials, such as shell adzes, that have had an impact on the reconstruction of the prehistory of the Philippines, Southeast Asia, and Pacific islands. Based on this archaeological information, Balobok Rock Shelter may have played a significant role in the movements of people into Southwest Pacific and to the Pacific World.

During the Neolithic Period, about 3,000 years ago, a shallow rock shelter, measuring 63 m wide and 5 m high, was also used for artistic expression. Considered the oldest known work of art in the Philippines, the Angono-Binangonan Petroglyphs include 127 drawings of human-like, frog-like and lizard-like figures carved on the rock wall, which is made of volcanic tuff. In the Anda peninsula in Bohol, a rock shelter is likewise decorated with hand prints.

The petroglyphs are representational symbols bearing some cultural content. In Maitum, Sarangani, archaeological excavations in Ayub Cave resulted in the discovery of unique anthropomorphic secondary burial jars that could be traced back to the Developed Metal Age, or about 2,005 years ago. This limestone cave is located in a coconut plantation traversed by a narrow road. The cave has an opening, about 2 m wide and 2 m high, which slopes downward. Considered as part of the sacred grounds in the past, Ayub Cave provides significant insights on Maguindanao prehistory.

Another significant site that was used for burial during the Age of Trade with Great Traditions of Asia is the Ipot Cave located in the Guyangan limestone cave system in Banton Island, Romblon Province. This cave is located in a very high cliff overlooking the sea, an ideal site for burial. In this cave were found two pieces of Banton cloth, which were associated with wooden coffin burial, and Yuan and Ming ceramic tradeware (ca 13-14th centuries AD). This is the oldest textile ever found in the Philippines.

In the late 19th century, the many caves of Marinduque, were documented, such as that of the island of Los Tres Reyes. The caves southwest of Boac have calcined walls and guano deposits. When discovered, these contained human bones and other relics. A larger cavern in the proximate area is partly hidden by vegetation and is entered through a small opening, which leads into several narrow galleries lined with bats. On the east coast of the island, about 70 m above sea level, are a cave and a grotto with volcanic debris and skulls, as well as funeral urns and ornaments. Nearby, a boulder blocks the entrance to another cavern. Among the caves found in Napo, Santa Cruz in the northern coast is one that opens into a vale and another, named Bathala, which has two burial chambers. East-southeast of Santa Cruz are silicon caves which are difficult to enter. These were likewise burial grounds that had been disturbed by landslides. Deep and empty caverns surround the mountain. The funeral cave at Pamin-Taan is intact and well preserved. The Macayon Cave has huge chambers below which are great depths and above which are hanging stalactites. The caves May-Igi and Padua are located in the vicinity of Boac, and are copper mines once rumored to contain gold. Still within the same vicinity, a 70-meter-high coral rock has five to six caves. Inside the lowest of these caves was discovered a small broken gargoyle and a skull covered with stalagmite. At the peak of this coral rock, an elevated vault crosses the entire top, from which corridors can be seen. Coffin debris and tibor (stoneware jars) were discovered inside one of these corridors. The little port of San Andres has near empty caves. One of these stands at the top of a 300-meter calcareous mountain and may have contained a considerable amount of carbonic acid. The entrance to this cave is through a well. In the Gasan area, a small mountain borders the coast line. Discoveries inside include burial traces and clay vases that contained a human skull, a little tibor, pearls, and urns.

Inside the caves of Antipolo, Gasan were found little wooden statues. The caves of Manoche and Salombog had skulls, pieces of tibor, and a big broken plate. A kilometer from Pamin-Taan, near Boulen, was a cave containing pot debris and two sculptured coffins. Eggs of tabon were unearthed inside the caves of Moupon Island.

The functions that people put to the caves in their vicinity are also determined by historical necessity. In times of colonial repression, the caves were sites of native defiance and resistance. During the Spanish colonial period, babaylan priests and priestesses—such as Papa Isio of Negros, Tamblot of Bohol, and Tapar of Panay—gained a following of thousands, who continued to hold their secret rituals in mountain caves. Revolutionaries held their initiation rituals in caves, which were also their hiding places and forts, which foreign invaders continually tried to penetrate. Caves abetted such revolts as the 85-year-long Dagohoy rebellion (1744–1829) in Bohol.

During the Filipino-American war, caves served as armories for the Filipino guerillas. Maestranza Cave in Dingle, Panay, became an ammunitions factory. Gintabuan Cave (from Ilonggo tabo, “encounter”) in Silay-Patag, Negros Occidental, is the site of a major battle between the American invaders and the Ilonggo resistance fighters. In this cave they held off for several days until, having run out of ammunition and refusing to surrender, they charged down on the American troops. They were led by Lt Elias Magbanua, who belonged to a family of revolutionaries and resistance fighters, the best known of whom is his older sister, Teresa Magbanua.

In Spanish-period chronicles, a cave in Gigantes Island, Iloilo, was called Longon-Longon (“like a burial place”), a name that is verified by the mark of a set of human ribs imprinted on the cave floor. However, in the people’s memory, including that of the elders, it is called Bakwitan Cave. Oral tradition attests that a boulder in the cave was used during World War II to block the entry of Japanese soldiers into its deeper chambers. Bakwitan Cave is also an evacuation site against typhoons and storm surges, the deadliest of which was Typhoon Yolanda (international name Haiyan) in 2013.

During the rainy season, when low-lying areas in Palawan become flooded, the Tau’t Bato in Barangay Ransang move from their huts to live in caves and rock shelters. They settle at the cave mouths for light and air and where smoke from their firewood can make an easy exit. The natural formation of the cave walls provides ledges and supports for bamboo platforms to rest on. Each platform has a domestic function, such as the da-tag (sleeping platform), the family’s living room, a makeshift dish rack, and so on. The cave ceilings and walls are sources of food, such as snails and bats.

In 1971, an alleged “Stone Age” indigenous group called the Tasaday was announced to have been discovered living in caves on a mountain peak in South Cotabato. However, the Tboli people, who are indigenous to the area, have always known of these caves they call Kilib Mata Awa (Caves of Mercy), which are on the mountain peak they call Tasaday. This system of caves is their holy ground, where they give offerings to their ancestor gods or take shelter when they travel long distances.   Written by Monica P. Consing, with notes from Angel P. Bautista and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

(Fung Yu, www.pamana.ph)

The King Faisal Center mosque inside the Mindanao State University campus in Marawi, Lanao del Sur, 2007

(Igy Castrillo)

Grand Mosque of Bacolod, Lanao del Sur, 2014

(Hesham Tamano Abolais)

text:
According to the Quran, the masjid are “houses which Allah had permitted to be erected that his name be remembered in them,” and therefore primarily centers of divine worship. Masjid is Arabic for “a place for prostration,” where the usual activities inside a mosque symbolizing complete surrender to Allah are done.

With the arrival of Islam in Sulu sometime during the 14th century and in Mindanao in the 15th century, the country was introduced to a type of organized religion which demanded a more permanent and separate place for worship. Thus, the tradition of mosque building began.

Originally, the mosque was just a courtyard encircled by a wall modelled after Muhammad’s house in Medina, Saudi Arabia. Eventually, a minaret was added for the azan or adhan (call to prayer); then the mihrab (prayer niche), considered nowadays the most important part of the mosque as it indicates the direction of Mecca, the holiest city of Islam, toward which all Muslims pray; the mimbar (elevated pulpit) for delivering the khutbah (sermons); the dome, which represents the “dome of heaven” of the original open uncovered courtyard; and arches supported by pillars, as well as cloisters, both important elements of Islamic architectural design.

 

While the general features of Philippine mosques approximate the traditional mosque, some of its elements are peculiar to the country. The sahn (wide enclosed courtyard), for example, is generally absent; instead, benches are provided outside the mosque where people may sit and talk while waiting for the next prayer. Also, the mimbar is not as high as those of Africa and Western Asia. An elevated platform, a chair, or any similar structure could take the place of the mimbar in some mosques.

Furthermore, the call to prayer was usually done, until recently, not on tall minarets but inside the mosques as in Indonesia. Suspended drums called variously the tabo, jabu-jabu, or dabu-dabu are beaten to call the people to the mosque. Great care, however, is taken so that the sound of the drums in one mosque is not heard in nearby mosques; the same care is observed with respect to congregational prayers. While minarets may be present in Philippine mosques, they are usually not functional. The bilal (the one who calls the prayers) may simply stand in the mihrab found in the quibla (wall) that faces Mecca and call the azan there, traditionally with the beating of drums, with the help of a microphone and loudspeakers mounted on the domes or minarets.

 

Another interesting feature of Philippine mosques is the almost ubiquitous presence of the crescent and star ornament on top of many graceful domes all over the land. The use of okir carving and the burak (a mythical winged creature, half-human, half-horse), and other motifs in highly colorful designs are also local adaptations.

Two types of mosques may be recognized in the Philippines: the masjid and the ranggar (Maranao) or langgal (Tausug and Yakan). The masjid is the “larger and more permanent structure, built on stone foundations, often near a stream or a body of water” (Gowing 1979). It is only in the masjid where the Friday noon assembly prayers, accompanied by a sermon, and Id observances may be held. The ranggar or langgal is some sort of chapel, a “small semipermanent structure built for the convenience of the faithful who are not in easy walking distance to the masjid” for the afternoon prayers during the Ramadan season. Among the Yakan of Basilan Island, the langgal may sometimes serve as a mosque in the absence of a masjid so that even the Friday noon assembly prayers may be held there. It is described as a rectangular building elevated on piles, like the typical Yakan dwelling, although the side walls of the Yakan house of prayer do not reach up to the roof. Entrance is through the porch, which is normally covered by a roof somewhat lower than that of the main room, which is also a step higher than the porch. At the center of the opposite end wall is a sunting (niche) that faces the west. During services this part of the langgal is covered with cloth, but usually it is devoid of any decoration, like the rest of the place.

 

In a sense, the langgal of the Yakan is the equivalent of the Indonesian Javanese langgar and the Malaysian surau. Like the Javanese langgar, the Yakan langgal has a porch with a separate roof, and a large room with a pangimbaran (niche), and the whole house-like structure stands on piles in the same way as the langgar.

The masjid was originally a three-tiered bamboo or wooden structure similar to a Chinese or Japanese pagoda or a Balinese temple, a pattern also common in Indonesia and the Malay Peninsula. A second style developed later, the more familiar onion-shaped dome on squinches set over a carpeted square or rectangular hall that can accommodate at least 40 (or 44 as in the case of Sulu) people at any given time. Perhaps this style emerged as a result of exposure to Middle Eastern mosques in the course of the Mecca pilgrimages.

However, while the pagoda type of masjid is the older of the two, the langgal is even older and antedates the former by several centuries. The oldest surviving example of the old multitiered pagodalike style is the Tubig-Indangan Mosque in Simunul Island, Tawi-Tawi, said to have been built in the 14th century by the celebrated Muslim figure Makdum Karim. According to Majul (1973), this must have been rebuilt several times. In particular, its roofing of palm leaves must have been changed many times, and its floor space must have been expanded at various times. But its four huge pillars of ipil wood are said to be the original. Two photographs, one taken in 1923 (in Orosa) and another in 1975 (in Majul), show the extent of the changes that have taken place on the structure. In the Orosa photograph, it appears as a slightly raised, cubelike adobe structure with a single pyramidal roof of nipa, while in the Majul photo, the nipa roof has given way to galvanized iron and shows not only one but two overlapping pyramids over which is a small minaret-like tower crowned by a bullet-shaped dome. Another dome has also been added over the mihrab. The interior views show a few windows and separate entrances for the men (on the sides) and the women (in front). As is typical in any mosque, the females do not go beyond the wooden screen while the males stay in the main prayer hall.

In the area of Lake Lanao, opinions differ as to which is the oldest mosque. For the Taraka people, it is the Babo-Ramain Mosque, while other sources mention the mosque built in Bundi Alao in the inged (township of Ditsaan, presently a part of the Ditsaan-Ramain municipality). A number of mosques carrying this old, wooden, tiered roof style may still be found in diminishing numbers in the Ramain area.

The mosque with dome and minaret is more popular nowadays. Hundreds of this type are found in many Muslim communities around the Philippines. One of these is the Quiapo mosque, a part of the Islamic Center in Globo de Oro and Elizardo Sts. Designed by Jorge Ramos, it has stained-glass panels by Antonio Dumlao. It was built to symbolize the nation’s Islamic heritage. The mosque is also located near the Quiapo church to highlight Muslim and Christian ties in Philippine society. Aside from the Quiapo mosque, other outstanding mosques of this style are the Grand Mosque of Bacolod in Lanao del Sur and the Blue Mosque in Maharlika Village in Taguig. Both of these retain traditional elements but incorporate modern features in design and planning, such as modern ablution facilities and, in the case of the Maharlika Mosque, a separate structure for the ritual washing of the dead prior to burial. The mosque complex may also accommodate a school, a library, a conference hall, and other function rooms around an open courtyard behind the main prayer hall or the mosque proper. Arabic geometric designs as well as large Quranic inscriptions have also become more common and have replaced in many places the traditional okir designs.

As Islam continues to spread, larger mosques are being built. The King Faisal mosque near the entrance of Marawi State University, the Capitol Mosque, the Maahad Marawi Mosque, and the Central Mosque built by the late Acmad Domucao Alonto Sr. are examples of large mosques found in Marawi City. These are in the style of Middle Eastern mosques, characterized by the dome and minarets.

The masjid has undergone numerous changes, but the main features have remained, their symbolic value strengthened and renewed in every new mosque constructed. This place of worship has continued to be a religious as well as a political, social, and cultural center for Muslims.  Written by Ma. Corazon A. Hila, with notes from René B. Javellana

text:
The munisipyo, from the Spanish municipio, refers to the town hall or a government building constructed during the American period to house government offices on the municipal level. The munisipyo housed offices for the three branches of government, such as the office of the mayor, the chamber for the town council, offices to transact business like the city registrar’s and the engineer’s, and the municipal court and jail. Most munisipyo were built at the center of a town, but with the growth of their population, some towns have constructed new munisipyo at the outskirts.

 

At the beginning of American rule, the insular government merely co-opted the existing casa real (town hall) and tribunal and made these into the town hall of a municipality. In 1901, an act of the Philippine Commission established the Bureau of Architecture and Control of Public Buildings. This bureau, abolished on 1 Nov 1905 and reorganized as the Division of Building Construction and Repair, was reestablished as the Division of Architecture by the Jones Law (Castañeda 1964, 55-56). This government office was tasked with designing and supervising the construction of public buildings, following the neoclassic style favored by its US-trained Filipino architects. It built many munisipyo during the 1930s and the 1940s.

 

Porticos and vestibules were almost always inseparable parts of town halls built during these decades. Town halls were constructed using concrete or wood and concrete, and they had galvanized iron roofs. They had invariably two stories. Castañeda remarks that the “incorporation of porticos in the structures was necessarily not the outcome of a dictum of the architects or designers, but usually that of the town dignitaries. Alcaldes (mayors) and the concejales (councilors) usually had the avowed option that a town hall would appear more dignified with them than without” (Castañeda 1964, 63). However, the influence of government architects prevailed. By this time they had built neoclassical buildings in Manila, namely the Legislative Building, the Post Office, and the University of the Philippines buildings which employed porticos and colonnades.

 

Many early town halls resembled the bahay na bato (stone house) because they were formerly either a tribunal or a casa real. The Macabebe, Pampanga town hall, which may have been a casa real, hews closely to the bahay na bato, as it is a simple frame building with wide eaves and an upper-story volada (protruding galleries). The portico, rising to the second floor, gives it the air of an American town hall. Wooden ionic columns support the roof of the portico, which has no pediment. Another town hall with the silhouette of a bahay na bato is the concrete two-story Tiwi, Albay munisipyo. The building has no portico; instead, a grand entrance approached by concrete steps in decreasing widths is the facade’s most prominent feature. The Malolos, Bulacan town hall, a plain concrete structure built in 1940, has a portico of square pillars supporting a flat roof. The town hall of Taal, Batangas is a pleasing variation of the typical munisipyo design. A terrace on the second floor is supported by arches with quadrilateral pillars. The portico is in the central portion of the second floor. Four pilasters support the gabled roof. Balusters decorate the second story. The Tabaco, Albay town hall has four Doric columns rising to two stories to make up the shallow portico. Through these columns can be seen the balconies on the second story. The rectangular building has a low-pitched roof, in contrast to the Tiwi munisipyo’s which has a high-pitched roof similar to that of the bahay the bato. While most munisipyo were built in the neoclassical idiom, some exceptions are noted, like the Sariaya, Quezon town hall which is art deco. A tall tower, decorated at its four corners by busts of women, is flanked by two wings to form a C-shaped plan. The entrance to the building is found in the tower and is approached by wide steps. Above the lintel of the main entrance is a concrete plaque depicting coconuts and other agricultural products of Sariaya. Similar in structure and style to Sariaya’s is the municipal hall of Jaro, Iloilo.  Written by René B. Javellana
