text:
The ospital or hospital is a specialized place intended for the care of the infirm. Its root word in Latin, hospes, meaning “visitor,” indicates that a hospital is a temporary place of residence and not a permanent one. Although hospitals are a permanent feature of the modern landscape, they were not known in the indigenous tradition. The infirm and ill were treated in their homes by native healers who used herbs for a variety of cures and by the babaylan who invoked the help of the spirits. It was during the Spanish colonial period that hospitals as specialized places were introduced.

 

Spanish Period

During the course of Spanish colonization, a number of hospital types were developed. There was the general hospital. A smaller hospital was the enfermaria (infirmary). Hospitals and infirmaries were also set up in conventos and even bishops’ houses. Lepers were housed some distance away from the town in a leprosario. Members of the army were treated in a hospital or enfermaria militar, while those of the navy were assigned to a hospital or enfermaria naval. There were hospitals, mostly of an informal nature, built near thermal springs and medicinal waters. The hospicio or asilo was a place not only for convalescing patients but also for orphans and senior citizens and eventually for the mentally ill. Schools such as the beaterios and colegios maintained their own clinics.

A typical hospital was of two floors, built as a quadrangle with one or more inner patios. There were long halls for the patients, one each for the sexes. An important early segment was the botica (apothecary), where medicines and herbal cures were dispensed. There were spaces assigned for operating rooms, dining rooms, kitchens, storage, and a morgue. There were offices for the mayordomo (director), doctors and their assistants, and pharmacists or managers of the boticas. The larger hospitals had rooms for dignitaries. There were orchards and kitchen gardens, and a little distance away was a cemetery. There was always a chapel, even a church, with the corresponding sacristy and quarters for the chaplain and sacristans. Some hospital compounds were quite large. The hospitals of San Gabriel, San Juan de Dios, and the Hospital Militar, both in the old and new site, rivalled if not exceeded the area covered by the Plaza Mayor in front of the Manila Cathedral. Some 19th century hospitals incorporated insane asylums.

The religious orders took the lead in health care—as hospital builders, physicians, pharmacists, and infirmarians—during most of the Spanish period. The most active were the Franciscans who arrived in 1578, and then the Hospitallers of San Juan de Dios who arrived in 1641. Each of the religious congregations had members who initiated the writing down and passing on of local remedies obtained from plants. The Daughters of Charity added to the work force in 1862. It is only in the 19th century when names of professional physicians and surgeons were encountered. The profession was enhanced with the establishment of the Faculties of Medicine and Pharmacy in the University of Santo Tomas in 1871, a century after negotiations with Madrid had begun.

Majority of hospitals were maintained by the religious orders that founded them, through alms collected from the faithful and through assistance from confraternities. Prelates conceded special blessings to those who aided hospitals and their work. The apostolate among the sick and dying was taken seriously by the religious orders. Felipe Pardo, a Dominican, remarked in 1673: “For this Hospital [de San Gabriel] is the most pleasant garden that we have in the Province, where so many flowers are gathered for heaven.”

The government provided annual subsidies and material support. A hospital for Spaniards, later the Hospital Militar, and another for the natives, the Hospital de los Naturales, were ordered established by Philip II in 1574, together with their maintenance. The latter hospital received 1,500 cavans of unhusked rice, 1,500 chickens, and 200 blankets from the Ilocos every year. Some institutions were adopted by the bishops, although they let the friars continue their physical and spiritual ministrations. Some hospitals received tax-free proceeds from the Galleon Trade or rent from haciendas or cattle ranches. The Hospital de la Misericordia was greatly aided by the Hacienda de San Juan de Buenavista in what is now San Rafael, Bulacan. The hospital for the Chinese was granted by Gov-Gen Luis Perez Dasmariñas the income from the river traffic between Intramuros and Binondo in 1595; this ended in 1629 with the construction of the Puente Grande, but the Chinese decided to support it themselves.

A hospital dedicated to the Santisimo Nombre de Jesus was inaugurated in Cebu by the confraternity of the same name in 1565, the first such institution established in the Philippines. Unfortunately, not much more is known about the survival of this hospital. Perhaps the most architecturally significant hospitals built during the Spanish period were what eventually came to be called the Hospital Militar, the Hospital de San Lazaro, the Hospital de San Gabriel, and the Hospital de San Juan de Dios, all in Manila.

Hospital Militar. Miguel Lopez de Legazpi established the Hospital Real in Manila, soon after founding the city in 1571. It was also known as the Hospital de los Españoles because it cared only for Spanish males. By the 19th century it was called the Hospital Militar, where only members of the military were treated. It occupied a block of four irregular sides along Aduana St in Intramuros across the University of Santo Tomas and the Ayuntamiento. Behind it, separated only by a narrow alley, was the Monasterio de Santa Clara. The hospital was burned in 1583 and 1603. After this, it was rebuilt in stone. With the acquisition of an adjoining lot in 1790, it was able to increase its capacity from 60 to 100 beds. Ruined by the 1863 and 1880 earthquakes, the Hospital Militar was rebuilt in 1883 according to modern standards along Calle Arroceros, on the site of today’s old GSIS building across the MRT Central Station. The expansive quadrangle consisted of six one-story pavilions, separated from each other by gardens, with 60 beds each. After 1898, the Americans converted it into the Sternberg General Hospital.

Hospital de San Lazaro. Soon after the arrival of the first Franciscans in Manila in 1578, Fray Juan Clemente, OFM, a lay brother, started receiving indigent patients and lepers in the monastery’s portería or reception hall. In 1581, Fray Clemente moved his wards on a site across the road, on swampy land which had been newly filled with the help of Bishop Salazar of Manila. The wooden structure could accommodate 200 patients in two halls. It burned down in 1583 and was rebuilt in stone by 1598, this time with three dormitories. It was first known as the Hospital de Santa Ana, but since it accepted locals of whatever faith, it came to be called the Hospital de los Naturales. After another fire in 1603, it moved out of Intramuros to across the creek from the Franciscan convent of San Fernando de Dilao where the Manila City Hall now stands. Victims of communicable diseases were sent here. In 1623, it welcomed 130 Christian lepers expelled from Japan, after which the hospital—as well as the creek that ran past it—came to bear the name of San Lazaro.

It was ordered demolished in 1663 because of the strategic danger it posed on Intramuros, but was rebuilt in 1681. This time it crossed the creek to be just south of the Dilao convento and near the Balete creek, on the site of today’s Technical University of the Philippines. The quadrangular building was of stone and brick. To lessen the danger of contamination, the clothes of the sick were washed in a special pool where the water did not empty into the rivers of the city.

After one more demolition in 1783, the Hospital de San Lazaro transferred to the former Jesuit hacienda of Meyhaligue on the outskirts of Santa Cruz district. The creek that flowed behind its west end likewise became known as the Estero de San Lazaro. The sprawling compound consisted of two great halls, one for each gender, with 100 beds in each hall. The halls opened onto open-air spaces for recreation. In the middle rose a church, which still stands. The facade features a richly ornamented entablature which recalls the Baroque era. In 1859, Fr Felix Huerta, OFM took charge of the hospital and improved its facilities. He moved the cemetery to a lot diagonally across, where the Espiritu Santo Church now stands. The lepers were transferred to Culion Island, Palawan. After 1898, the hospital was expropriated by the American government and the Franciscans were not allowed to return to the Hospital de San Lazaro which they had taken care of for three centuries.

The San Lazaro compound is contiguous to the Jose R. Reyes Memorial Hospital—both are part of a bigger complex that occupies a large city block bounded by Tayuman St to the north, Quiricada to the south, Rizal Ave to the east, and Estero de Magdalena to the west. In this large block is the Department of Health.

Hospital de San Gabriel. The Dominicans built a hospital dedicated solely to the Chinese, whether baptized or not. What was eventually called the Hospital de San Pedro Martir, built from 1587 to 1588, began as a shed with six beds. It was replaced by a larger one of wood in 1595, but after it burned down in 1597, it was rebuilt across the Pasig and renamed Hospital de San Gabriel. After another fire in 1604, a new hospital was finished in 1625. This one rested on heavy pillars of stone and had two halls that contained at least 70 beds. A third ward was added in 1639. This building seems to have survived the 1645 earthquake, but there were important renovations in 1728-30, 1738, and 1754. As retaliation against the Chinese who collaborated with the British, the Hospital de San Gabriel was closed in 1774. Thereafter, the vast compound was used for other purposes such as a rectory, government offices, military barracks, and apartments. In the 1920s, the decrepit buildings were sold to the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank.

Hospital de San Juan de Dios. The site abandoned by the Hospital de los Naturales in 1603, which was by Calle Parian where the Lyceum now stands, was ceded by the Franciscans to the Hermandad de la Santa Misericordia. This charitable institution was founded in 1594 based on those established in Portugal and Macau. The Hospital de la Misericordia attended to patients of non-communicable diseases, including slaves. Spanish women were confined in separate quarters. In 1656, the one-story stone structure for 12 beds was ceded to the Hospitallers of San Juan de Dios, who added two more halls and a church. Subsequent structures were destroyed by earthquakes in 1664, 1674, and 1727.

By 1742, a grander compound had been erected, with a two-story quadrangular all-stone building attached to a richly decorated church. The botica was located at a corner of the cloister, with a window to the street. A cemetery occupied part of the corner plaza fronting the church and convento. This was not unusual—a cemetery also lay between the University of Santo Tomas and the Colegio de Santa Rosa. Both levels of the cloister, which opened onto a spacious patio, were arcaded (Maldonado de Puga 1742).

By the 1850s, the three halls with 20 beds each had increased to 5 halls with 129 beds for men, 40 for women, 8 for dignitaries, 8 for cigarette vendors, and 16 for foreigners. The hospital also attended to out-patients.

After the 1863 and 1880 earthquakes, a new building was erected according to the 1876 plan of Luis Cespedes (Aguilera Rojas 1998, 127). The quadrangular compound was divided into four quadrants, each with an inner patio. The chapel, with its iconic neo-Byzantine dome, occupied part of a corridor cutting the compound in half; its apse fronted the Intramuros wall leading to the Parian gate. Abrogated voladas (protruding galleries) were uniquely incorporated onto the two faces of each of the four corners of the compound. The main entrance of the hospital opened onto the Calle Parian. A section of the ground floor was occupied by classrooms for the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Santo Tomas. There were consultation offices, laboratories, two halls for surgery, a delivery room, and a ward for prisoners. The hospital, the largest during the Spanish period, continued to operate until its total destruction during the Liberation of Manila in 1945. A new Hospital de San Juan de Dios opened in 1953 fronting Manila Bay along Roxas Blvd.

Leprosaria. Hospitals for lepers were often dedicated to San Lazaro, himself a leper. These were erected some distance from the town. Many were built of masonry, but apart from the Hospital de San Lazaro in Manila, very few have survived to this day. Leprosaria are known to have been built in Cebu City in 1850; in Vigan, Ilocos Sur, and Laoag, Ilocos Norte, both in 1861; in Palestina, Naga, Camarines Sur, which was a hospital established in 1586 and revived in 1873; and in San Joaquin, Basco, Batanes.

Army and Navy Hospitals. The Hospital del Espiritu Santo was established by the Franciscans in 1591 for the Spaniards and natives working in the shipyards in Cavite Puerto. Its masonry building could accommodate 20 beds. The hospital was turned over to the Hospitallers of San Juan de Dios in 1642. It was destroyed and rebuilt several times, with the last reconstruction in 1885 under the Daughters of Charity. A second hospital was built in Cavite Puerto, this time in the Cañacao district on Sangley Point. The Hospital de la Marina de Nuestra Señora de los Dolores was erected in 1876 as an offshoot of the expedition against Jolo. It consisted of two one-story halls elevated above the ground by two meters and had 26 beds each.

From about 1850, more and more army and navy hospitals and clinics were set up all over the country. These accompanied military operations especially in the Sulu Archipelago (Isabela de Basilan, Jolo, Bongao), in the Cotabato-Lanao area (Pollok, Cotabato, Tamontaca, Tumbao, Parang-parang, Tucuran, Pikit, Reina Regente, Iligan, Momungan, Ulama, and Marawi), in Davao, and in Palawan (Puerto Princesa, Balabac). Similar establishments were set up north of Manila in Olongapo, Vigan, Bangued, Bontoc, and Solano.

Although most of these hospitals were temporary in nature, built of timber or located inside palisaded forts, their design benefited from the research conducted by the military engineers in collaboration with the Manila Observatory. The 1873 Enfermaria Naval in Isabela, Basilan, was unique in that it was built on molave piles over shallow water. Like its 1876 counterpart in Cañacao, Cavite, it took on the indigenous way of construction. The 40-bed Basilan innovation comprised rooms for medicine, surgery, and eye operations, as well as a botica, a mess hall, and meeting and officers’ rooms.

Hospitals next to Thermal or Medicinal Waters. The healing properties of thermal and medicinal springs led the friars to build hospitals or even simple balnearios (bathhouses) next to the sources of such waters. The most substantial building was that erected in Los Baños, Laguna, a mission formerly called Mainit, founded in 1602 by the Franciscans. A two-story hospital dedicated to Nuestra Señora de Aguas Santas de Mainit was constructed of wood and stone around 1614. It featured celdas (cells) built over the vents of steam and hot water, and various pools, with water brought by bamboo pipes. There were separate quarters and baths for women. Renovations were undertaken in 1727, 1790, and finally in 1877, with plans by Fr Gabino Perez, OFM.

In Caysasay, Taal, Batangas, an arch carved with elaborate baroque leaves and tendrils was erected over the Balon ni Santa Lucia (Well of Saint Lucy). Pilgrims took baths in sheds with water drawn from two arched openings cut into the rock. Other places well known for their springs with bathhouses—actually little more than nipa sheds—were in Pakil, Laguna; Sibul, San Miguel, Bulacan; and Tiwi, Albay.

Hospicios and Asilos. Nursing homes and hospices for senior citizens were often built close to each other. The most significant example began as a hospital for convalescents established by the Hospitallers of San Juan de Dios in 1729 on the Island of San Andres, now Isla de Convalecencia, in the Pasig River. Initially consisting of a hall for 12 beds, it was renovated to include eight rooms for dignitaries, a chapel, a cistern, and a garden. In 1849, it was ceded to the Hospicio de San Jose which was founded in 1782 as an asylum for the aged, the mentally ill, and orphaned children. In 1877, the Hospicio expanded into four one-story pavilions separated by gardens and patios, to accommodate 300 to 500 interns. Under this category may be included a Casa de Recogidas, a house for women of ill-repute, established in Intramuros in 1728. The house was rebuilt by the architect Tomas Cortes from 1820 to 1822. Though it did not last long, it gave its name to the street—Calle Recogidas—which was only changed later to Calle Anda. The female wards were sent to the Hospital de San Juan de Dios to do laundry and other chores (Guerra 1994, 562-3; Santiago 2005b, 93-4).

 

American Period

One of the many innovations the American colonial government introduced early in the 20th century was the campaign to improve the physical health of the Filipino. Sanitation and health were a priority for the government. Sanitation was a type of preventive medicine. Working toward this end, the Americans improved the water system to make available safe and potable water in homes or in publicly shared facilities, built sanitary markets, and supervised the butchering of animals and the handling of food in the market. In the capital Manila, following the program of urban development prepared by Daniel H. Burnham, the Intramuros moat was drained and filled with sand. It was later converted to a nine-hole golf course known as Municipal Golf. Esteros in Manila and all throughout the archipelago where there were large populations were periodically dredged to unclog them and allow the free flow of water. Periodic fumigation was instituted to kill malaria-bearing mosquitoes. The government launched a universal campaign on vaccination, the eradication of disease-carrying pests, and the vaccination of pets and farm animals. The Bureau of Health, headed by a medical doctor, managed the program for people.

But when such preventive measures failed, the Americans organized a system of hospitals and health clinics built on a tiered system. At the village level was the clinic and puericulture center which focused on the health of mothers and children. On the town or city level was the public general hospital. And on the national level was Philippine General Hospital (PGH), which was not only a hospital but a research center and training hospital attached to the University of the Philippines. Inaugurated in 1910, PGH was designed by William Parsons in the Mission Revival style. It was the largest building erected in the first decade of the 20th century. The plans, dated 1908 and 1909, show a building composed of several pavilions in parallel array. A front pavilion housing the administration leads to a central area where common facilities are located. Both sides of this central area branch out to the different pavilions which are separated by courtyards and connected by arcaded galleries. Each pavilion houses a department: medical, surgical, orthopedic, or maternity. One pavilion is devoted to private rooms. The plans indicate provision for future expansion—enough space for five additional wings. The building is formal and symmetrical, the plans being somewhat like an organizational chart. The design is most appropriate for the tropics, since each wing is designed for maximum ventilation and protection from rain. In the PGH, Parsons introduced a style of modern architecture, functional in plan, employing the traditional arch while minimizing surface ornament.

Because the PGH was a training hospital, Nurses Home, a dormitory for nurses assigned to the PGH and for those in internship, was built in 1915 within the hospital compound on Taft Ave corner Padre Faura. Architect Tomas Mapua designed it in neo-Renaissance style.

Since tuberculosis was then the fatal disease that claimed the most lives, it was inevitable that a sanatorium for tubercular patients would be built. The Quezon Institute, designed in the 1930s, a major work of Juan Nakpil, consisted of pavilions symmetrically arranged and liberally spaced out. The pavilions included paywards, and the teachers’ and children’s pavilions. As with his other building of the same period, Juan Nakpil employed the art deco style. A native touch appears in the pitched roof of the central building. The Americans also built a laboratory for producing vaccines at the outskirts of Manila in Alabang. Here cattle was raised which were innoculated to produce vaccines.

San Lazaro, which traced its roots to the Franciscan Fray Juan Clemente’s hospital in Intramuros, transferred to Mayhaligue after the 1762-64 British occupation and the expulsion of the Jesuits who owned the property from 1636 to 1768. The Franciscans administered the hospital, named after St. Lazarus because it was a hospital for lepers, until 1898 when the Americans acquired it and repurposed the hospital to be a quarantine hospital for infectious diseases. The pre-World War II building was in the neoclassical style characterized by arches and an arched awning over the central entrance.

Another disease which Americans sought to contain was leprosy or Hansen’s disease. Because leprosy was still considered incurable and communicable in the early 20th century, the Americans continued with the practice under Spain of isolating patients. The Cebu Leprosarium founded in 1850 continued to function. On 27 Oct 1902, the Second Philippine Commission called for the creation of the Culion Leprosarium, under the Director of Health. The first batch of 370 patients came from the Cebu Leprosarium and arrived in Culion on 27 May 1906. Located on a remote island in northern Palawan, Culion was seen as the ultimate place of segregation, where the most severe cases were sent. The whole island, under the Bureau of Health, was administered as a hospital rather than a municipality although the leprosarium developed as a small town. Culion leprosarium was divided into two districts: Colonia and Balala. Colonia was where the hospital and the houses for those recovered or recovering from leprosy were found. Balala, also known as Sano, was where the hospital staff, the priest chaplains, the nuns, and other who were free of leprosy lived. Culion had its own set of coinage, which was used in the island. Money from other places had to be exchanged for Culion’s own money.

Another hospital that focused only on patients suffering from leprosy was the Central Luzon Sanitarium. More popularly known as Tala Leprosarium, it was the closest leprosarium to the country’s capital. It was established in 1940 in Tala, Caloocan and is presently known as Dr. Jose N. Rodriguez Memorial Hospital (DJNRMH).

Privately run hospitals were allowed to continue, subject to licensing and periodic evaluation. San Juan de Dios moved from Intramuros to a site along Dewey Blvd. Its management was transferred to the Daughters of Charity. Singian Clinic in San Miguel and Adventist Manila Sanitarium (now Adventist Medical Center) were among the pre-World War II private hospitals. Manila Sanitarium was known for promoting a vegetarian diet, following the tenets of the Seventh-day Adventist who were vegetarian.

The hospitals all over the Philippines were tested to breaking point in 1945 during the liberation of the Philippines, when war left many casualties. Public buildings, including churches, had to be converted to temporary hospitals.

 

Period of the Postwar Philippine Republics

After the period of rehabilitation and the rebuilding of damaged hospitals like the PGH, construction of new hospitals began in the 1950s. The largest construction project within a few years after World War II was the Veterans Memorial Hospital (now Medical Center), a sprawling two-story building with the front pavilions branching out at oblique rather than right angles. The hospital presided over vast grounds which have been developed into a golf course. A box-like structure with slab overhangs over the windows and parapets concealing the pitched roofs indicated the influence of the International Style. The hospital opened in 1955.

Built in the 1950s, the Children’s Memorial Hospital (now Fe del Mundo Medical Center) located on Banaue Street, Quezon City and designed by Cesar Concio departed from the conventional plan consisting of wings or pavilions. All rooms were in one curving multistory block at the left side of the entrance, while at the right, in a low and compact block, were the auditorium and various common facilities. While the building exemplifies freedom of form in modern design, its shape was dictated by practical considerations.

Designed by Luis Araneta, the original Manila Doctor’s Hospital on UN Ave, completed in 1956, was notable for introducing elegance into hospital design. The lobby was dominated by a curved stairway set against a large curved window. Rooms were liberated from antiseptic white walls and sported cheerful or soothing colors. The hospital was entirely air-conditioned, which was a novelty then. Jutting out on the right of the entrance was a restaurant.

The Makati Medical Center (MMC), Araneta’s largest work, was built in 1965, and with its nine floors, was the tallest in its time. The building, a large rectangular block, was accented at one end by a cylindrical block housing operating rooms, the intensive care unit, the nursery, and private rooms. On the exterior were flat, horizontal strips that serve as sunshades. The MMC represented the high-rise trend in hospital design which continued in such buildings as St. Luke’s Medical Center on E. Rodriguez Ave in Quezon City, Medical Center Manila on General Luna St, and the annex of the PGH.

During the martial law years, a project sponsored by First Lady Imelda R. Marcos was the expansion of the PGH. Along with the rehabilitation of the pre-World War II buildings was the addition of a seven-story tower complex. Respecting the lines of the heritage building, architect Jorge Ramos echoed the arcades of the Mission revival style of Parsons. The completed project was inaugurated on 2 Jul 1985, Imelda’s birthday. Ramos had earlier worked with Imelda in building the Philippine Heart Center, which came about after Imelda had visited Houston and had seen the specialized hospital dedicated to the circulatory system. Later, Imelda would push for other specialized hospitals along East Ave and the Quezon Circle in Quezon City.

The Philippine Heart Center for Asia in Quezon City, designed by Ramos and inaugurated on 14 Feb 1975, had two types of accommodations for patients: wards and private rooms. The latter were grouped into “petals”—that is, 10 to 14 rooms were clustered around the nurses’ station and were accessible to visitors through peripheral corridors, which were continuous glassed-in balconies. This arrangement required more space than the standard rows of rooms along corridors.

Just as Marcos’s Bagong Lipunan (New Society) forstered a return to one’s roots through architecture, Imelda patronized local artists, commissioning large murals celebrating Malakas and Maganda that were installed in various buildings. The Philippine Heart Center mural portrayed her as a loving mother in Filipiniana, embracing the handicapped, the aged, and the infirm of all ages. Behind her were troops of doctors, nurses, and health specialists.

The National Kidney Institute, also in Quezon City, was a two-story, Y-shaped building with a courtyard at the center. Recently, the hospital was remodeled with additional wings obscuring the original plan.

The floor plan of the Lung Center of the Philippines was basically two diamonds joined at their middle corners at the shaft of a T and hanging by their top corners from the arms of the same. The sides of the diamonds, called “wings,” contained the rooms and wards. Vertical bars running through the centers of the squares are supplementary corridors. The bottom of the T, aligned with the bottom corners of the diamonds, form the entrance area. The “wings” of the building do not spread out but are folded and interconnected in a compact plan.

Imelda also spearheaded the construction of the Philippine Children’s Medical Center along Quezon Blvd and near the Quezon Circle. This hospital was especially dedicated to children with rare and terminal diseases like cancer. The center, established in 1980, was in modernist style.

By the 1970s, early detection and multiple drug therapy had greatly reduced the progression and spread of leprosy that both Culion and Tala began to phase out their exclusive health program for leprosy. Assisted by private foundations and the United Nations, an aggressive program to eliminate leprosy was launched. Culion was one of the key hospitals where discovery and trials of drugs that cured leprosy was conducted. By the late 1980s, leprosy was no longer considered a threat, so in 1992 a law making Culion a municipality was passed and in 1995, the first municipal and barangay elections were held. Similarly, the 808-hectare property of Tala Leprosarium was reduced to 130, with the rest of the property turned over for the housing of previous patients who had been cured. Tala has effectively become a general hospital.

During the post-Marcos era, there were rapid developments in medical science and technology, and clients and patients expected specialized services and sophisticated facilities. These factors increasingly challenged the ingenuity and creativity of architects in designing hospitals and medical centers that had the latest in medical technology while exuding the air of a hotel or resort. New structures were built in the suburbs like the Medical City in Ortigas Ave, St Luke’s Medical Center at the Bonifacio Global City, Cardinal Santos in San Juan City, and the Asian Hospital along the South Expressway.

In the provinces, Cebu Doctors Hospital and Maria Reyna in Cagayan de Oro have also upgraded and built new structures. These hospitals vary in design. Most are modernist. But what is common among them are the integration of new equipment and modern methods of health care and the effort to make a hospital more appealing to patients. Newer hospitals give an impression of being more like hotels rather than a place for the infirm. Amenities such as fastfood outlets, mini-groceries, pharmacies, and an independent medical arts building for outpatients are included in the design. Depending on one’s budget, room choices can be simple like wards or suites like five-star hotels.  Written by Regalado Trota Jose, with notes from René B. Javellana

Arzobispado de Nueva Segovia in Vigan, Ilocos Sur, 2012

(Brian Aballe)

Facade of the Palacio del Gobernador in Intramuros, Manila

(Fiestas en Manila Año 1825 by Justa Moreno Gaarbayo, Patrimonio Nacional, 1977)

Malacañan Palace

(Old Manila by Ramon Ma. Zaragoza, Oxford University Press, 1990)

text:
Palacio, which is Spanish for “palace,” is a generic term designating the residence and office of the highest official, civil or ecclesiastical, during the Spanish colonial era. The term was applied to the Palacio Real del Gobernador/Governador or Palacio Real, Palacio Episcopal (Bishop’s Palace), Palacio Arzobispal or Arzobispado (Archbishop’s Palace), and Malacañan or Malacanang Palace. By analogy, any large and opulent residence may be called palacio or palasyo in Filipino.

Palacio Real del Gobernador/Governador. The original location of the first Palacio Real in the 1600s was near Fort Santiago facing Plaza Militar, until its destruction in the 1645 earthquake. Then Gov-Gen Diego Fajardo, 1644-53, moved it to a confiscated house formerly owned by Real Audiencia member Manuel Estacio Venegas. Its first true resident was Gov-Gen Sabiniano Manrique de Lara who occupied the palace on 19 Jul 1654. The house functioned as the governor’s residence and office, as well as the office of the Real Audiencia or Supreme Court.

 

During the term of Gov-Gen Fausto Cruzat y Gongora, 1690-1701, when the Palacio was rebuilt in the Hispanic idiom, there appeared to have been a north wing where the Royal Audiencia (until it had its own building in 1788), the Royal Secretariat, Royal Account Office, and Royal Treasury were located, and a south wing with the upper floor occupied by the governor general and his family. The secretary of the governor was located on the lower floor. The two wings branched out from a central atrium. The main facade had two front doors facing the Plaza Mayor.

A grand stairway led from the front door. On this stairway, Gov-Gen Fernando Manuel Bustamante, 1717-19, was assassinated on 11 Oct 1719. Brig Gen William Draper occupied the building during the British occupation in 1762. The earthquake of 1 Feb 1771 destroyed this Palace, forcing Gov-Gen Simon de Anda, 1770-76, to move to a temporary residence in Santa Cruz, then to an infirmary of the Augustinians in Cavite until 1776.

 

By 1850, Gov-Gen Narciso Claveria had redesigned the Palacio in the neoclassical style. The renovated grand staircase that led to the Sala de Besamor (Reception Hall) was inaugurated by Gov-Gen Manuel Crespo y Cebrian, 1854-56, on 19 Nov 1855 in honor of Queen Isabela II. Periodic reconstruction and alteration changed its plan until it was destroyed by another earthquake. The 19th century structure was a two-story building in the neoclassical idiom. On 3 Jun 1863, eve of Corpus Christi, a strong earthquake severely damaged the structure, along with the Ayuntamiento and the Manila Cathedral. Gov-Gen Rafael de Echague, 1862-65, moved temporarily to Colegio de Santa Potenciana, the current site of the Philippine Red Cross Manila Chapter. Due to the summer heat, the governor-general moved to Posesion de Malacañan, the official summer residence purchased by the government from Don Luis Rocha in 1825. Initially proposing to rebuild the Palace, Gov-Gen Echague eventually stopped the construction in favor of moving permanently to Malacañan.

Gov-Gen Rafael de Izquierdo, 1871-73, campaigned for the restoration of the Palacio del Gobernador with an approved budget of 100,000 pesos for reconstruction. But the Palacio was never rebuilt. When the Philippine Revolution broke out in 1896, the project was abandoned, and the occupying Americans opted to improve on Malacañan Palace instead.

The site of the Palacio in Intramuros was used as a plaza during the American Period. The present Palacio del Gobernador is a high-rise government building constructed in 1976 before the enactment of Presidential Decree No 1616 in 1979 which regulated building construction in the designated historical zone of Intramuros.

 

Malacañan Palace. The decision of Governor Echague to move to the summer home formerly owned by Don Luis Rocha sealed Malacañan’s future as the residence of the top executive of the Philippines. The American military governors and governor-generals chose to move into Malacañan during the pre-World War II era. Malacañan and its grounds then underwent renovation, and new facilities were constructed.

The first American executive to occupy Malacañan was Major Gen Wesley Merritt, whom American president William McKinley appointed as commander of the expeditionary forces to the Philippines. He stayed in Malacañan a mere 16 days in Aug 1898. The following month, Major Gen Elwell Otis replaced Merritt who stayed until he was replaced by Maj Gen Arthur MacArthur in 1900. In 1901, Howard Taft was appointed as the first civil governor, later renamed governor-general, of the Philippines. Received in grand style in Malacañan by MacArthur on 4 Jul, Taft moved in with his wife Nellie, three children, a Japanese maid, and Mrs. Taft’s sister, Maria.

Malacañan then was basically a large bahay na bato (stone house) in the traditional late Spanish colonial style. It had two stories, the lower floor being made of stone and the upper, of wood. Sliding capiz windows, ventanillas (small windows), and sliding windows under the window sill allowed for a well-ventilated upper floor. The house was approached either through the northwest end facing Aviles St (now J. P. Laurel) or through the southeast riverine route facing the Pasig. During the Spanish era and early in the 20th century, the river route was more commonly used. Here, a projecting dock was built, covered by an open balcony. The formal entrance to the house was through its side between the northwest and southeast. It had an overhanging second floor, supported by wooden pillars and reinforced by diagonal brackets.

Taft had the house renovated to accommodate rooms for his family, especially, a nursery for the children. Nellie Taft loved the house with its expansive garden and old trees, the view of the Pasig and a still unobstructed view of the cordilleras to the northeast. Parties and social gatherings were part of the imperial life style of the governor-generals, and Nellie Taft had the trees lining the Pasig transferred so that a wide promenade could be built along the banks of the Pasig. Here guests mingled and socialized in the open air.

Subsequent governors-generals would add their own touch here and there, but the first major renovation was done under Gov-Gen William Cameron Forbes who assumed governorship in 1909. He commissioned William Parsons to reconstruct the floor system, introduce fire proof reinforced concrete to replace wooden structural elements, and reconstruct the dining area. Parsons respected the traditional lines of the house, replicating in concrete what was once timber. He was charmed by “an old Spanish building [having] a good deal of character and charm” (Quezon III et al. 2005, 138).

Two governor-generals, Francis Burton Harrison and Dwight Davis, did much to renovate Malacañan as the seat of executive power. While previous governors went to the Ayuntamiento to work, Harrison preferred to conduct business in Malacañan. In 1921, he inaugurated the Executive House designed by Richard Doane, the consulting architect of the Bureau of Public Works. Davis added a new wing to house Harrison’s large family. Malacañan was demolished and rebuilt, retaining its historic appearance. Malacañan contractor was Marion M. Karolchuck, a Greek who worked on the Paco Church. Under Davis, the palace grounds were improved.

In 1935, Malacañan was occupied by Quezon after he was elected president of the Philippine Commonwealth. The last American governor general, Frank Murphy, then moved to the Mansion House at Baguio, while a residence for him was being built along Manila Bay. That residence is now the American Embassy.

Under Quezon, Malacañan underwent expansion. Office spaces were built because Quezon preferred to work in Malacañan rather than in the Executive House as the American governor generals had done. A boat house was built for the launch used to cross to Malacañan Park and down the Pasig. The Executive House was expanded by the addition of extra stories. New gates were installed and the gardens improved and planted with Doña Aurora (Mussaenda Philippica var. Aurorae), a shrub with white leaves, named after First Lady Aurora Quezon.

While Malacañan itself was only slightly damaged during the liberation of Manila in 1945, it did not escape looting and so lost its furnishings. After World War II, Pres Manuel A. Roxas did little to improve Malacañan because the government set as priority the rehabilitation of the country. It was his successor, Pres Elpidio Quirino, who refurbished Malacañan. Amalia Pastor, Malacañan’s interior designer, was tasked to make the place less dark and oppressive. Quirino’s expenses in refurbishing the palace was met with criticism and became an issue in the election.

Under the frugal Ramon Magsaysay, Malacañan remained largely unchanged from the Quirino era. When Carlos P. Garcia assumed office, he preferred to spend time in his home at Bohol Ave in Quezon City, rather than in Malacañan. While Garcia commissioned sculptures from Guillermo Tolentino who later on became National Artist, his administration did not do much renovation on Malacañan. “By the Garcia years, visitors came to view the Palace at this time as dowdy, if not frumpy and down-at-heel” (Quezon III et al. 2005, 244). During the Macapagal presidency, First Lady Eva Macapagal worked on Malacañan, cleaning it of debris and improving the garden. The open policy of Magsaysay continued to the Macapagal presidency and visitors would stroll freely in the gardens. With Architect Luis Araneta as consultant, Mrs Macapagal improved, refurbished, and redecorated Malacañan. The Reception and Social Halls were renovated and the palace, which had changed over time with additions and subtractions, was unified in design without sacrificing the historic accretions on the building.

Macapagal lost his bid for reelection to Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1965. First Lady Imelda Marcos then launched a series of renovations that would stretch through the Marcos’ years. In this era, Malacañan was used for statecraft. The palace was now a leading platform in projecting Philippine culture through architecture.

In 1965, the Marcos Room was added to the residential section. The Executive Building erected in 1921 by Harrison had its second floor cleared to make way for the Maharlika Hall in 1975. This building housed the office of the president.

From 1978 to 1979, Imelda had the residential area renovated. Windows were covered with bullet proof glass, the external walls were pushed forward, and central air conditioning was installed. At the east and residential wing, an open atrium from the time of Gov-Gen Dwight Davis was covered with a colored fiberglass skylight showing stylized coconut leaves in a sunburst design of eight rays. On the second floor of the atrium, bas-reliefs carved by Paete artisans interpreted the historical works of Angono-born National Artist Carlos “Botong” Francisco. The private quarters of the First Family were paneled with Philippine hardwood, given a coffered ceiling, and decorated with carvings by Betis artisans.

The main wing, Kalayaan, housed the Rizal Hall or Ceremonial Hall, the place for grand meetings with a large group. Like the residential quarters, the hall was paneled with hardwood and had two domed coffered ceilings reminiscent of the ceiling design of the Pantheon in Rome. At the center of the ceiling hung crystal chandeliers. Swags and other ornaments of carved wood decorated the curtained entrances. Capiz was used to filter light coming through the windows and capiz dividers were used to mark out space. On a background of hardwood carved to resemble sawali or woven bamboo was the presidential seal. Under the seal, the president and his guests would sit on a long raised platform. The floor was carpeted crimson with yellow gold trim designed as a braided rope and swags of foliage. All told in 1979, seven years after the declaration of martial law, Malacañan was awash with the elements of the Bagong Lipunan (New Society) nationalist aesthetics.

During the Aquino, Ramos, Estrada, and Macapagal-Arroyo presidencies, Malacañan had various uses. Corazon Aquino did not want to live in Malacañan because of its association with Marcos. She lived in a Malacañan guest house on Arlegui St and renovated the former San Miguel Brewery, acquired during the Marcos era, to serve as the new Executive House. The 1921 Executive House was renamed Kalayaan Hall, and Malacañan became a museum that exposed the excesses of the Marcoses. Fidel V. Ramos, who succeeded Aquino to the presidency restored Malacañan to its former function by returning to Malacañan and using Marcos’s office. He repaired the palace that had been damaged by typhoons. His successor Joseph Estrada decided to take residence at the Premier Guest House and improved it to be a residence and office. The interior of Malacañan was refurbished. But on 20 Jan 2001, he was forced out of office, and Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo took over as president. She renovated Malacañan, cleaning it of the personal effects of the Marcos family, which were turned over to the Presidential Commission for Good Government. She created a Presidential Briefing Room similar to the White House Situation Room. She recovered historic furniture, restored Kalayaan Hall, and spruced up the garden.

Palacio Episcopal. In 1595, during the Spanish era, the diocesan structure of the Philippines was organized. Manila was raised to an archdiocese with four suffragan or dependent dioceses: Nueva Segovia, initially based in Lallo, Cagayan, then transferred to Vigan, Ilocos Sur in 1758, Nueva Caceres in Naga, Camarines Sur, Cebu in 1595, and Jaro, Iloilo in 1865. During the Spanish colonial period, the archdiocese and all the dioceses had a palacio. From these residences, usually next to the cathedrals, the administration of the archdiocese and the dioceses was facilitated.

The only remaining example from the Spanish era of a palacio episcopal which is still functioning as such is the one in Vigan, Ilocos Sur, raised to an archdiocese in 1951. Presently known as Arzobispado de Nueva Segovia, Vigan’s episcopal palace is an oversized bahay na bato. Its date of construction is uncertain, but it was most likely built around the same time as the cathedral in 1790. Built parallel to the Cathedral of the Conversion of San Pablo or the Vigan Cathedral, the palacio is a longitudinal two-story building with a lower floor of stone and an upper floor of wood. A central arched entrance on the first floor leads to the grand staircase that connects the lower floor with the upper floor. The palacio functions as archdiocesan office, museum, and residence.

Nueva Caceres or Naga’s episcopal palace was first built near the bank of the Naga River, along a street presently named Calle Caceres. Called Casa de Clerigos, the first structure was of provisional material, and it was not until the time of Bp Antonio Obrigo Gallego, OFM, that a stone structure 27 baras (yards) long was built. This two-story structure had an upper floor supported by arches and a tile roof. By 1783, the building was substantially finished except for the roof which was only partially covered with tiles. In 1797, a seminary was officially established in the casa. It seems that the casa served as episcopal palace, residence of the cathedral canon, and seminary. Because of flooding, Fr Bernard de la Concepcion, bishop 1816-29, decided to move the residence and the cathedral to its present site. This building would suffer damage, repair, and expansion until 1879 when Bp Francisco Gainza assessed the condition of the building as severely damaged. He had the building demolished and a new one built. That building still stands and has been known as the Holy Rosary Minor Seminary since 1964. The post-World War II archbishop’s palace transferred to a lot east of the seminary and the cathedral on Elias Angeles Ave.

The site of the bishop’s palace of Cebu, built by Bp Santos Gomez Marañon, OSA, 1829-40, was across the Cebu Cathedral, on P. Burgos St. When it was destroyed during World War II, Julio Cardinal Rosales, then archbishop of Cebu, transferred the palace to a larger piece of property along Jakosalem St, beside the Diocesan Shrine of the Sacred Heart (formerly Sacred Heart Parish). The ruin of the old palace was torn down and a new building, Patria de Cebu, a diocesan hostel and center, replaced it.

Jaro became a diocese in 1865, when it was separated from Cebu. Fr Mariano Cuartero, OP was appointed as the first bishop. It is uncertain where the bishop’s palace was during the Spanish era, but most likely it was in the convento of the Cathedral of Santa Isabel de Hungria. The present palace, built along Seminario St and facing the Jaro Plaza or Graciano Lopez Jaena Park, is known as Arzobispado de Jaro. It is a post-World War II work by Juan Nakpil, built during the incumbency of Abp Jose Maria Cuenco, 1951-72, first Filipino bishop of Iloilo. The house uses elements from classical architecture like the arch windows and is laid out in the manner of a residence, where the offices are on the bottom floor and the residential area is on the upper floor. Due to the widening of the street in front of it, the road runs very close to the building, with only a narrow sidewalk separating it from the street.

The palacio or arzobispado of the Archdiocese of Manila was the residence and office of the Archbishop of Manila. The palacio was built along Arzobispo St, parallel to Calle Real del Palacio in Intramuros. The earliest palacio, built in anticipation of the arrival of Bp Domingo de Salazar, OP in 1581, was a makeshift house of wood, bamboo, and nipa. This humble residence was destroyed by fire in 1583 but rebuilt in stone, brick, tiles, and wood by Bp Salazar and Fr Antonio Sedeño, SJ soon after. This and subsequent buildings were weakened or destroyed by earthquakes.

In the late 19th century, the Archbishop’s residence, like all the other parochial residences in the islands, probably resembled a large bahay na bato with multiple living quarters, but grander in scale. Teodoro Agoncillo irreverently describes the turn-of-the-century Archbishop’s Palace in Intramuros as follows: “the Archbishop’s Palace, a building that did not look like a palace but a well-appointed Antillean house [obsolete term for the bahay na bato] of a get-rich-quick Spaniard of dubious morality.” Although the exigencies of living in an island setting probably dictated the principles of traditional Philippine tropical architecture for the palacio, the fashion of the period probably dictated ornamentation of late Revivalism of the 19th century.

With the new colonial regime, the American Government leased the old palacio for Manila’s Court of First Instance.The arzobispado in Intramuros was heavily damaged during World War II, so it had to be transferred to Tayuman and then to San Miguel, both in Manila. In the 1950s, then-Vicar General Rufino Santos moved the arzobispado to Villa Grimault in Shaw Blvd, Mandaluyong. The villa was renamed Villa San Miguel in honor of San Miguel Arcangel, the archbishop’s patron saint. By the 1960s, the Grimault was infested with termites and was torn down, and the present villa, designed by Jose Ma Zaragoza, was built.

The present offices of the Arzobispado de Manila were built in the late 1980s on a site next to the old palacio in Intramuros. This structure, which now houses the Archdiocesan Museum and Ecclesiastical Offices of the Archdiocese, resembles an oversized bahay na bato on the outside. Inside is a multistory building. An archdiocesan guesthouse built earlier became the Archbishop’s Residence, when the Archdiocese of Manila was divided into suffragan dioceses: Parañaque and Novaliches (Quezon City North), established in 2002; and Pasig and Quezon City, established in 2003. When Abp Gaudencio Cardinal Rosales moved into the archbishop’s residence in Intramuros, Villa San Miguel became the archdiocesan guesthouse.  Written by René Luis Mata, with notes from René B. Javellana

Prewar Tondo Market in Manila

(Edward Delos Santos/Pinoy Kollektor)

text:
The palengke, from the Spanish palenque, meaning palisade, is also known as tiyangge and tindahan, from the Spanish tienda, meaning “merchandise for sale,” and the Tagalog han, a suffix to denote place. It is a place or a building for buying and selling goods.

A specific building for the buying and selling of goods is absent in the ethnolinguistic communities of the Philippines. Instead, the trading of goods occurs at certain times, and any flat or unbuilt area is set aside for such transactions. Sites chosen for trade are usually accessible to many communities. Hence places like riversides, seashores, and deltas become market areas. The number of tradeware and beads found in archaeological sites amply demonstrates that Philippine communities have long been trading with each other and with their Asian neighbors.

The tradition of setting aside a time rather than a building for the sake of trade persists even today among lowland Filipinos. During certain times of the week, merchants go to a particular town to sell their wares and by nightfall have packed their goods to sell to the next town. The day for the itinerant market is set by tradition. This market also follows the calendar of fiestas in a given area. Temporary stalls may be set up days before the festivities and are taken down after and moved to another place where another fiesta is about to be celebrated. This itinerant market is called tabu (Cebuano for “meeting”) in Cebu or mercado (Spanish for “market”) in other places.

 

A tabu is usually a conglomeration of stalls made of bamboo and canvas that are easy to disassemble. When the stalls are not knocked down but remain in a place for a considerable length of time, they are collectively called talipapa in Tagalog. Usually a fish stall, the talipapa set up by private initiatives may begin as a temporary setup, then gain permanence and recognition in the course of time. Stalls may be of wood, galvanized sheets, salvaged building materials, and materials solicited from companies selling goods. Stalls usually have simple flat roofs. In neighborhoods, a retail store called sari-sari (literally, “mixed”) is set up by small entrepreneurs. The sari-sari carries foodstuff, cosmetics, hardware, and other goods that might be needed in an area. As a convenience store, it brings goods within easy reach, and the practice of selling goods at retail and sometimes on loan makes it an important economic institution.

Foreign loan words indicate the cultural influences that have created the Filipino concept of market.

With the establishment of the Galleon Trade, the Spanish presence in the Philippines was assured. To meet the demand for trade goods and also goods for local consumption such as food, cloth, and building materials, as well as to meet the need for services, the Spaniards allowed the Chinese, already present and trading in the Philippines, to continue with their business in a specific area assigned to them. That area, segregated from the Spaniards, was called parian. Cebu, Manila, and other large towns, like Vigan, Ilocos Sur and Malolos, Bulacan had a parian. That of Cebu was located on one side of the cathedral block and around the church specifically built for the Chinese. By 1595, the large number of Chinese prompted Bp Pedro Agurto to request that the Jesuits begin a mission for them. The general area of Cebu’ s parian has not changed much over the centuries, in contrast to Manila’s, which moved at least six times. The earliest location of the parian in Manila was within the walls of the city, but not trusting the Chinese, the Spaniards evicted them and told them to settle in the general area presently occupied by the Metropolitan Theater and the Manila Post Office Building. The parian was within the range of the cannons mounted on the walls of Intramuros.

The Chinese merchants and the Spanish rulers had an uneasy relationship. The Spaniards needed the Chinese for their needs and so tolerated their presence. By 1727, the parian was a village of well-built houses on whose ground floors business was conducted. It was also a thriving parish under the patronage of the Three Kings. In 1758, the Alcaiceria de San Fernando was constructed in the populous Chinese village of Binondo. Only the Pasig river separated the Alcaiceria from the northern flank of Intramuros. This two-story octagonal building contained several shops for merchants. Destroyed by fire in 1810, it was not rebuilt, probably because by this time many other stores and shops were already operating.

The typical market, even the itinerant one, sold food, clothing, utensils, equipment, and many others. The stores that opened in Binondo were actually the intermediary state between the early markets and the modern-day supermarket or grocery. In these buildings, which had two stories and a mezzanine or three stories, the top floors were the residences of the owners and their family, while the ground floors were the stores. These stores sold just about anything except the perishable foodstuff which had to be bought at the palengke. Stores in Escolta and also in Cebu’s parian had awnings over the entrance to shield passersby or potential customers from the heat.

Apparently, foodstuff was sold in open areas, in the tabu or in the talipapa, during the Spanish era. Only toward the era’s end were permanent markets built. One such market was the Arranque designed by Juan Hervas, a government architect. When the Americans started to govern the Philippines, they found two systems of trading: in the stores were canned goods, preserved foods, clothing, and other dry goods, while in the palengke, popularly called the wet market, were rice, fresh meat, fish, fruits, and vegetables. Sizing up the inadequacy of these structures, especially with respect to sanitation, the Americans built public markets all over the Philippines. Markets in Manila built during the American period include that of Paco ca 1910, restored in 2013 by Kapit Bisig para sa Ilog Pasig (Link Arms for the Pasig River) and partners in the business world. Perhaps the most attractive and best known of the American-built markets was Baguio’s. The site of the market was already in the Burnham-Parsons plan. The Baguio market consisted of one-story structures built along a wide passage. Each structure had many stalls in it, with some at the outer flanks of the building and other stalls facing a central interior corridor. Perpendicular to this corridor were narrow passageways.

One of the contemporary developments is the supermarket. Borrowed from the United States, the supermarket puts together the wet market and the grocery. Perishable goods are sold in specially designated areas where the goods are preserved in refrigerators. The goods may come prepackaged or sold by weight. A recent addition to the urban skyline is the mall, also called galleria. The mall, an American building concept, is a covered or open concourse flanked by shops. The concourse may be one or two stories with continuous balconies serving as access to the shops on the higher floors. Malls contain a variety of shops, including a grocery, and are modern versions of the shopping or marketing district.

In large urban centers, a reaction against preserved and instant foods has resulted in a return to organic farming and to home-cooked food—a movement known as “slow food” in contrast to fast food. This new consciousness about food and health has increased the popularity of the weekend organic market, an urban version of the traditional tabu, where sellers bring their produce straight from the farm to the consumers who buy them fresh. Like the tabu, food stalls in these markets are temporary.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Source

Quarterly Bulletin of the Bureau of Public Works. Apr 1912; Apr and Oct 1913; Jan, Apr, and Jul 1914; Jul and Oct 1916; Jan 1917.

photos.photodesc:
Malabrigo Lighthouse in Lobo, Batangas, 2015

(Jernel Pateña)

text:
The parola, which comes from the Spanish farola that originated from the Latin faro and the Greek pharos, means “lighthouse.” It is a structure built on a promontory, island, or rock to guide ships passing through a narrow channel or an area filled with rocks or sandbars. Strategically located, it indicates where a ship might safely pass. The parola first appeared during the mid-19th century and became necessary with increased international trade and the development of steamships.

In previous centuries the bell tower of the church served as a beacon, with lights hanging from it to guide ships. The practice continued up to the 20th century, as indicated by the report of the Philippine Commission of 1903 which states that the light at San Nicolas, Cebu harbor was “exhibited from a small platform on the south face of a church tower” (Fourth Annual Report of the Philippine Commission 1903, 193). A light could also be hoisted on a pole or hung from a tall tree. In Batanes, an ingenious system of navigation was built consisting of a monolith with a hole at the top end. Behind the monolith was another stone on which a storm lamp was lit. When visibility was low, the boatman would fix his vision on the light in the cavity of the monolith to guide the boat safely to the shore.

 

A 19th century parola consisted of a high tower that has a light or beacon, either electrical or chemical, on its upper story. Usually the tower tapered at the top and could be a polygon in plan or a cylinder. The topmost story was walled in by glass plates and had a catwalk built around its perimeter to allow cleaning and maintenance of the light. Below the light were the living quarters of the lighthouse keeper. Parola built during the Spanish era were usually of bricks or cut stone, although iron towers were also used.

Many extant parola were built in the last decades of the 19th century such as those in Burgos, Ilocos Norte, guarding Cape Bojeador; Palauig Island, Cagayan, guarding Cape Engaño; Corregidor, guarding the entrance to Manila Bay; Malabrigo, Lobo, Batangas, guarding the Verde Island passage to Tayabas Bay; Capul Island, Northern Samar, guarding the San Bernardino Strait; and Jintotolo Island south of Masbate. A number were not completed or were modernized by the Americans as early as 1903. They had more modern lights manufactured in Europe installed, repaired old buildings, or constructed new ones. In 1903, there were 57 lighthouses, many of them built by the Americans. The Spaniards built a cylindrical tower at Capul Island off Samar but its quarters were built during the American period. The parola at Cape Engaño in Santa Ana, Cagayan is one of the most pleasing. Built during the Spanish era, it is an octagonal tower capped by a cylindrical light, around which is a catwalk of wrought iron. The tower is surrounded by three buildings arranged as a “C,” which share the same wrought iron gate.

Lighthouses have recently gained attention as heritage sites and as adventure tourist destinations. The lighthouse at Cape Bojeador, Ilocos Norte has undergone restoration. Bricks baked in a kiln found at the slope of the mountain where the lighthouse stands were retrieved for the restoration process. The lighthouse at Capones Island off the Zambales coast attracts adventure tourism.  Written by René B. Javellana

 

Sources

Fourth Annual Report of the Philippine Commission 1903 (Part 3). 1904. Washington: Government Printing Office. See also: https://archive.org/details/ldpd_11897700_000/page/220.

Noche, Manuel Maximo Lopez del Castillo. 2005. Lonely Sentinels of the Sea: The Spanish Lighthouses in the Philippines. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

Main retablo of the Church of Nuestra Señora del Patrocino de Maria in Boljoon, Cebu, 2017

(Kiko del Rosario)

Retablos of the Church of San Pedro de Alcantara in Pakil, Laguna, 2016

(Vonna Vista)

text:
A retablo is the Hispanic altar piece of the 16th to the 19th centuries. It is from the Spanish retablo, from the Latin retro, meaning “behind,” and tabula or tabulum, referring either to a “board,” “table top,” or an “altar piece.” It is also known by the French term reredos. The retablo, which formed a decorative background for the altar table, evolved from medieval painted panels attached as backdrops to the altar. In Spain and her colonies, the retablo evolved into monumental proportions characterized by a fusion of architectural orders, painting, sculpture, and relleve (relief), which could be bajo relleve (low relief), medio relleve (demi-relief), or alto relleve (high relief). The last contains figures sculpted almost in the round.

Philippine retablos tend to be more restrained than their counterparts in Spain or Mexico. While the classical orders, the salomonica (twisted column), and the estipite (inverted obelisk) were used, these were often treated more as decorative than as structural elements—that is, as parts of a larger composition whose foci were the niches containing santos. Both the salomónica and estípite were popular in Baroque Spain and the Americas, with the estípite more prominent in Latin American rococo pieces. A retablo was crowned by a fronton (pediment), the most common being the triangular and the broken or open type.

 

Few retablos in the Philippines are more than 150 years old. Those that may be identified with the 17th or early 18th century are Juan de los Santos’s retablo for the San Agustin Church, Intramuros, 1617; the side retablos in Maragondon, Cavite; the central retablo formerly in Pangil, Laguna; and the central retablo in Lubao, Pampanga. These early works are characterized by several tiers of niches with santos, and the use of classical rather than baroque ornaments. The loss of early retablos may be attributed to their destruction by fire, typhoons, termites, and dry rot, as well as to enforced demolition or incorporation of parts into later altarpieces.

By the early 18th century, retablo-making in the Philippines was a fully developed art, with master artisans coming from Binondo or Santa Cruz, Manila, and from such towns as Paete, Laguna. Retablos of this period are characterized by multiple niches, florid decoration, bright colors, and aleron (decorative flanges) flanking either side of the retablo. These aleron, also called aleta or aleton—from the Spanish ala, meaning “wing”—took the form of large volutes, sometimes resembling coiled millipedes that metamorphosed into foliage with cherub putti peering. Wooden surfaces were primed with gesso and then painted. Details were gold-leafed—a skill in which women were said to be adept.

 

Excellent 18th-century retablos are those in Silang, Cavite, and the Basilica Minore del Santo Niño, in Cebu. In Silang, the main altar combines statuary with high reliefs on the life of Mary. The Santo Niño retablo contains 17 niches with santos and sprouts flanges at the first and second stories. Its broken pediment is flanked by a pair of diagonal volutes known as the Dientzenhofer motif, named after a family of architects in central Europe. Other outstanding examples of this period are the high altars in Magsingal, Ilocos Sur; Pakil, Laguna; Kawit, Cavite; Romblon, Romblon, dated 1724; Baclayon, Bohol; Boljoon, Cebu; and Guiuan, Eastern Samar.

The frenetic decorations of the so-called ultra-baroque that appeared in Spain and especially Latin America in the 18th century hardly sprouted here. The style was also called churrigueresque, after the Churriguera brothers who worked in early 18th century Spain. Toward the 1770s, rococo motifs called rocalla (from roca, meaning “rock”) began to appear in art and later in retablos. Rococo presented a lighter treatment of decorative elements, its favorite motif being flamelike decorations surrounding assymetrical niches and cartouches.

Retablos with rocalla elements are found in the sanctuaries of the churches of Tanay, Rizal; Betis, Pampanga; Salasa, now Bugallon, Pangasinan; Sinait, Ilocos Sur; San Jacinto, Tuguegarao, Cagayan; Argao and Dalaguete, Cebu. The side retablos at Pakil, Laguna; Tayabas, Quezon; and Tagbilaran, Bohol also display rocalla elements.

Around 1780, a reaction in Europe against the excesses of rococo gave rise to the Revivalist styles, like the neoclassical and neo-Gothic. The left side altar of Vigan Cathedral is a transition piece, with rocalla tendrils straggling in a classicizing format. An early example of the neoclassical is mentioned by Zuñiga, who, writing just before 1800, registered his admiration for the retablo of Lipa, Batangas. Artistic change took some time to reach the Philippines where poverty hindered the renovation of many retablos. But a series of devastating earthquakes from 1852 to 1880 damaged many structures, which were then rebuilt following the latest revivalist style.

Neoclassical retablos are more architectural than sculptural as compared to those of the baroque. They are characterized by the lack of florid ornamentation, a reduced number of niches—usually a principal one for the church’s patron, flanked by two minor ones—the use of the classical orders in an architectonic rather than decorative manner, and muted colors. To suit the changing tastes of 19th-century Manila, the baroque central retablo in San Agustin was replaced around 1854 by a neoclassical one and was composed of three pairs of massive Corinthian columns flanking a single niche. Other outstanding neoclassical retablos are found in the churches of Vigan, Ilocos Sur; Badoc, Ilocos Norte; Indang, Cavite; San Jose and Taal, Batangas; Carcar, Cebu; and Jabonga, Agusan.

The best-known surviving examples of neo-Gothic retablos are those of the San Sebastian Church in Manila. However, these were not the best, as they were exceeded in size and grandeur by the ruined altars of Santo Domingo in Intramuros. Other neogothic altars are found in Calbayog, Samar; Maribojoc, Bohol; Molo, Iloilo; and Jasaan, Misamis Oriental. The church at Oton, Iloilo, unique for its Greek-cross plan, had a magnificent four-sided neogothic retablo resembling the spires of gothic cathedrals in its very center.

Churches often had at least three retablos. The altar mayor (central or high altar) was the most elaborate. Flanking it were the colaterales or altares menores (side or smaller retablos). Some churches had many colaterales, eight in Santa Maria, Ilocos Sur or even 10 as in San Agustin, Intramuros. Single-niched retablos were also found in the sacristy and the baptistry, the former often enshrining a crucifix and the latter an image of John the Baptist baptizing Jesus. A charming example of the latter is found in the church of Morong, Rizal.

The altar, a long narrow table, was attached to the retablo. Flanking the altar were small tables for liturgical vessels called credencias (credence tables). At the center of the altar table, raised by about one-third of a meter, was the tabernaculo or sagrario (tabernacle), sometimes of wood, often of silver plate. A crucifix surmounted the tabernacle, which was flanked by step platforms, either bench-like gradas or stairway-like gradillas. Arrayed on these were candlesticks—at least six in number, in many cases 12 or more—reliquaries, flowers, and ramilletes (flowerlike decorations in silver, wood, or even shell).

The retablo of the altar mayor usually had a flight of steps behind it that allowed devotees to come close to the patronal image to kiss it or its vesture. Some churches maintained a camarin, a small room or chapel directly behind the main altar where this image could be cleaned or dressed for the next fiesta. An outstanding example of this space is the recently restored Camarin de la Virgen in Santa Ana Church, Manila.

A type of hispanic altarpiece called a retablo de espejos is known in the Philippines only through missionary chronicles and in inventories of church property, where an entry is described as embotido de espejos, literally inlaid with mirrors. This type was characterized by niches which had paneled doors, and by surfaces inlaid with tiny pieces of mirror, hence the name. This retablo was built to house precious relics.

Retablos were traditionally made of wood, gesso, paint, and gilt until the late 19th century. Later works used brick and mortar, such as those in Sarrat (Ilocos Norte) and Leon (Iloilo), or even marble. Early 20th century workshops or talleres like that of Isabelo Tampinco and Maximo Vicente made retablos, which were sent to churches all over the Philippines. An example of the understated neoclassical retablo of the Tampinco atelier may be seen in Manaoag, Pangasinan (ca 1909). The retablos in Bacon, Sorsogon, are in the unusual art deco style. Retablos continued to be made well into the 20th century, often employing cement and marble and favoring the baldachin design. After the Second Vatican Council concluded in 1965, retablos fell into disfavor—some antique ones were torn down in an overeager but unenlightened attempt to implement the decrees of the Council. Santos and retablo parts found their way into antique markets and ended up as decorative elements in private homes.

Starting around the 1980s, a popular sentiment set in: modern churches began to commission retablos. These “revivalist” pieces favored baroque motifs, like those at Antipolo Cathedral or Sacred Heart Church in Kamuning, Quezon City. The revival of retablo-making started a new growth among the talleres of Paete, Laguna and Betis, Pampanga. A number of new retablos utilizes molded resin and fiber glass which are then painted to achieve a contrived wood or stone surface. In these pieces, the joyous colors found in authentic pieces have been replaced by the brown and gold used in funeral fittings, giving rise to the term ataul (coffin) baroque to describe this style. The path broken by such artists as Locsin and Abueva for contemporary inspirational retablo art still has few travelers. Written by René B. Javellana, with notes from Regalado Trota Jose
