photos.photodesc:
Rice terraces of Batad in Banaue, Ifugao, 2016

(Kiko del Rosario)

text:
The rice terraces are terraced pond fields planted with rice and carved out of the mountains and hills of the Philippine Cordilleras. They are an outstanding example of an evolved, living cultural landscape that can be traced as far back as two millennia ago in precolonial Philippines.

Inscribed in the World Heritage (WH) List in 1995 under the official name “Rice Terraces of the Philippine Cordilleras,” the rice terraces are considered to be priceless contributions of the Philippine ancestors to humanity. While terrace-building is known also to the Assam people of northeast India and among the Naga Hills people of Burma, and in Taiwan, Indonesia, and many parts of Southeast Asia, the Philippine rice terraces are perhaps the most extensive in the whole world, occupying unusually high altitudes in the central Cordilleras of the Mountain Province, especially in the Ifugao, Bontoc, and Kalinga areas, and also in some parts of Abra.

 

Various theories have surfaced regarding the age of these terraces. Henry Otley Beyer, pioneer in Philippine archaeology, found abandoned rice terraces in Benguet. His theory was that the settlers of the area where the rice terraces were subsequently built migrated from the South China-Tonkin area, entered Lingayen Gulf, and then went up the Agno River to establish the terrace culture of northern Luzon. The oldest terraces, found in the highest mountains, according to Beyer, must have been made around 2,000 years ago during the Copper-Bronze Age, while the last ones were built some 500 years ago. This theory, however, does not explain the presence of similar abandoned rice terraces in Majayjay, Laguna and in the provinces of Rizal, Quezon, and even Cebu.

Anthropologist Felix Keesing and the Belgian missionary and scholar Fr Francis Lambrecht contradicted Beyer’s claims, noting that the earliest terraces could not have been built earlier than the Spanish times or ca. 1680, since no written accounts by Spanish chroniclers who visited the area in the 17th century ever mentioned the presence of these terraces. Even Ifugao folklore does not offer evidence of wet-rice agriculture. This contention is supported by a C-14 radiocarbon dating of artifacts dug out from an excavation in the area, which yielded a date of not earlier than 300 years ago.

From 1964 to 1967, Robert Maher of the University of Michigan took charcoal samples of rice chaff from a house terrace in Banaue, which revealed a C-14 dating of close to 3,000 BP—or roughly 1,000 years BC—that could have readily disproved the Keesing-Lambrecht theory. But Maher made it clear that “there was no age determination of the rice terrace itself” and that the age of the house terrace cannot be held simultaneous with those of the field-terrace sites (Maher 1973).

Terraces, as understood by the Cordillera peoples, could either mean house terraces which are “levelled terraced areas for houses, granaries and work sites; drained fields which are levelled terraced areas used for the cultivation of dry crops and intended for more permanent forms of terrace use after a few years; or pond fields, which are the levelled irrigated rice terraces” (Perez III et al. 1989). Almost all terraces, however, belong to the pond-field type.

E.P. Patanñe (1975) described a typical rice terracing as not simply “the levelling of mountainsides into broad steps or embankments but a whole system of engineering built around a network of irrigation canals fed by a mountain spring” (39). However, among the Tinguian of Abra, terracing is done “along rather steep banks of a river into which flow many rivulets. Ditches or canals are cut at almost right angles to the rivulet, and water is carried down to the terraced fields.” Furthermore, all rice terraces require the use of a series of retaining walls on different levels, whose purpose is to create level fields suitable for wet-rice growing in wet-rice farming, the walls retaining also the water diverted from the rivers (Klassen 1988).

Beyer (1955) described the process of building these terraces. The terraces were first built of broken stones. As these decayed, they were replaced by round river stones. After the retaining walls were built, they were backfilled with material from the river or from the hillside. Over gravel and sand the builders put some clay to make them waterproof. On top of this lining they placed another layer of sand. Skillfully built irrigation ditches took care of the water supply. Rice terraces may be found in elevations of anywhere from 500 to 1,600 m. The walls themselves rise up to a towering height of 6 m or, in some cases, up to 16 m in varying shapes and slopes, in stone and mud, depending on the terrain and on the capability and taste of the indigenous builders.

Traditionally known as the artists among the Cordillera groups, the Ifugao have fashioned long, massive sloping walls of stone and earth that seem to follow the contour of the mountainsides so that the terraces themselves appear as an enormous sculptural piece. The Bontok, on the other hand, have terraces that run in straight lines with almost vertical stone faces intended to maximize the level area for planting. Such a strictly architectural and functional approach to form may partly be explained by some references to Bontok culture—the Bontok being known for their reverence to the gods, their courage, resourcefulness, patience, industry, and physical endurance. The courageous and warlike Kalinga, in contrast to the Ifugao and the Bontok, have low stone walls supporting inward sloping earth walls.

Patanñe (1978) described the mode of planting on these rice terraces. When the wet season comes, the seedbeds are sown, the water is then channeled in the terraces, and the soil becomes soggy. The men line up in the field and stab sticks into the soil to allow the water to seep in, all the while chanting songs. Manure from the pigpens is brought up and the soil tramped upon and puddled into a soft ooze. Then the women appear with rice seedlings.

Water is steadily fed into the terraces and when the plants begin to grow, the sickly ones are promptly pulled out and the plots are kept free of weeds. As the rice plants mature, bamboo “birds” are hung from poles to keep away the greedy rice birds. The home of the terrace owner becomes taboo at harvest time. Only immediate friends and helpers are permitted to enter the terrace. A small fire is built and offerings and prayers made to the spirits of the fields before the ripened grains are plucked. While the harvesting is in progress, visitors are not allowed to approach the field. The work is done by hand, and the stalks with the grain are bundled up and left to dry in the sun. Before the grain is finally stored, a priest invokes the blessing of the high deity Lumauig so that the rice might last a very long time.

The Rice Terraces of the Philippine Cordilleras World Heritage property is the first recognized organically evolving cultural landscape. Five of the most intact and impressive rice terraces were identified as priority sites during inscription. These are found in the Province of Ifugao in the heritage cluster sites of Nagacadan in the municipality of Kiangan; Batad and Bangaan in the municipality of Banaue; Central Mayoyao cluster in the municipality of Mayoyao; and Hungduan terrace cluster in the municipality of Hungduan. These five Ifugao sites are of unparalled beauty, having special unique features: the Nagacadan terrace cluster in Kiangan is composed of two distinct ascending rows of terraces that are bisected by a river; the Hungduan terrace cluster uniquely emerges into a spider web; the central Mayoyao terrace cluster is interspersed with traditional farmers’ bale/fale (house) and alang (granary); the Bangaan terrace cluster serves as backdrop of a typical Ifugao traditional village; and the Batad terrace cluster is nestled in an amphitheatre-like semi-circule of terraces with a village at its base.

The rice terraces signify the identity and ingenuity of the Philippine Cordillera cultural groups and represent the physical, sociocultural, economic, political and religious mindset of a resilient people who have survived life in a rugged natural environment. It exemplifies a complex elaborate farming system of high to medium altitude irrigated rice agriculture that is unique in the world. Interlaced with the terraced pond fields of stone or mud walls are intricate irrigation systems with their accompanying watersheds—the ala or inalahan (communal) and the muyong (privately owned forests)—which exhibit skilled engineering management that is appreciated to the present. The terraces’ walls similarly act as pathways and within paddies are earth mounds planted with vegetables.

The rice terraces likewise illustrate the persistence of cultural traditions and the remarkable continuity and endurance of an agricultural and ecological system that reflect a cooperative regimen of work sharing by the whole community that is based on a mastery of the rich diversity of the natural environment within the Philippine Cordillera. Community-based zoning, building, and land use characterize this ecosystem. Moreover, the building and maintenance of these rice terraces are administered by mutual help teams in every community, with no complex institutionalized arrangements to oversee the continuous operation of the terraces. In maintaining these terraces, annual and lunar cycles and traditional pest control practices that are based on the processing of a variety of local herbs are used.

Significantly associated with the rice terraces are the boble or babloy (traditional settlements), and an architecture that has equally provided a sense of identity to the community and country. The Ifugao house called bale or fale is a reflection of architectural ingenuity. They are built in clusters on paved plots called dola or chola (house terrace). A modest four-walled structure, the Ifugao house is elevated from the ground by tukud or tuud (four posts) with lidi, libong, or halipan (rat proof disks) on the ends. Other noteworthy traditional architecture of the Philippine Cordilleras is the binayon or finaryon of the Kalinga, the fay-u of the Bontok, the Sagada house, the binuron of the Isneg, the house of the Ibaloy, and the binangiyan, apa,and allao of the Kankanaey. They all come in different forms, but all are of wood and thatch roof, and are graced with bamboo or reeds.

As in the lowlands, animism, associated with polytheism and ancestor worship, pervades the whole tone and process of rice production in these upland farming areas. Spirits are believed to abound everywhere—in the ricefields, river, hill, or mountain—and must be appeased by the regular performance of rituals and sacrifices guided by the spiritual leaders of these mountain peoples. Needless to say, the sense of community is heightened with these periodic ceremonies.

With the rice terraces, therefore, are a vast array of cultural traditions such as the planting and harvest rituals; the chants recited during harvest season, sickness, and death; the numerous ceremonies representing life and love; the customs that relate to birth, courtship, marriage, death; and the routinary practices of the everyday life of the people. Altogether, these have remarkably been sustained to the present, demonstrating the solidity of a culture that has evolved through time and through generations of practice.  Written by Ma. Corazon A. Hila, with notes from Joy B. Mananghaya

photos.photodesc:
Exterior of Spanish-period sabungan 

(Jose Honorato Lozano, 1847, Biblioteca Nacional de España Collection)

Spanish-period sabungan or cockpit interior

(Jose Honorato Lozano, 1847, Biblioteca Nacional de España Collection)

text:
A sabungan —from the Tagalog sabong, meaning cockfight, and an, a suffix denoting place—or cockpit is the building where cockfights are held. It is sometimes called a coliseum, sports center, or gallera, which is from the Spanish gallo, meaning “chicken.” It is one of the landmarks of a town, as well known as the church, the town hall, the plaza, and the market, since cockfights take place regularly on weekends and on holidays, and are attended religiously.

Its location varies. It could be in a busy section of the town, particularly if it is an old cockpit. New cockpits are usually built outside the town proper, on spacious grounds which can be occupied by food stalls and used for parking.

The building plan could be square, octagonal, or circular. The rueda (arena) is the center of the structure. Square in shape, it has a dirt floor to better absorb blood and is enclosed by a fence or grille with gates for access. Around the pit rise the seats for spectators in amphitheater fashion. The lower section of ringside is for heavy bettors; the galeria or upper section is for ordinary bettors and spectators.

Around the cockpit is an enclosure which serves both as the entrance area and as the ulutan, a gallery where cocks are matched prior to actual combat.

 

The roof may be square, octagonal, or circular in plan, depending on the floor plan. Over a square cockpit, the roof may be hipped or gabled. Over the octagonal or circular plan, the roof may be conical, somewhat like a salakot.

For maximum ventilation, the building which consists of the structural frame and the platforms for seats, has no sidings. The sabungan of this type looks light and transparent and is in fact quite airy. On the other hand, the sabungan may be enclosed by wooden sidings and provided with windows or with wooden louvers or jalousies. Some cockpits are completely enclosed and air-conditioned.

In the Philippines, cockfights were being staged prior to the coming of the Spaniards. In 1521, Magellan’s chronicler Pigafetta recorded the cockfights he saw in the Visayas.

The Spanish permitted or at least tolerated cockfights because the government earned revenues from taxes and fees collected from the sabungan. Descriptions of cockfights and the sabungero (cock owner) and trainer appear in literature, notably in Jose Rizal’s novel Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) and El Filibusterismo (Subversion). In his essay “Sobre la Indolencia de los Filipinos” (On the Indolence of the Filipinos), Rizal noted that cockfighting was a sport that antedated the arrival of the Spaniards, but its institutionalization as a form of gambling happened during the Spanish colonial period, as evidenced by the fact that all terms relating to gambling in cockfighting are derived from the Spanish.

Prints from the 19th century show various types of cockpits. There were the temporary open-air pits consisting mainly of an area enclosed by a bamboo fence. There were the more permanent types, which had a fence, circular fighting arena, surrounded by a narrow, slightly sloping gallery for spectators, with the entire area covered by a conical roof resting on slender posts. Another type has an elevated square arena surrounded by a ground-level gallery and an elevated balcony for spectators. The whole area was enclosed with walls of bamboo and covered by a roof of cogon grass with push-out windows for illumination and ventilation.

Since the Spanish period, cockpits have been used for political meetings and theatrical performances because the arena is visible from all seats and is spacious.

While the Americans’ puritanical ethos frowned on all types of gambling, cockfights continued into the American era. There seems to have been no bans on cockfights although laws regulated it. An indication that cockfights were allowed is the La Loma Arena, in Quezon City which is still running. Remodelled, rebuilt, and upgraded a number of times, this arena is considered Manila’s oldest, and its establishment can be traced to the year 1902.

 

In the past decades, cockfighting aficionados in the Philippines established several cockpit arenas in Metro Manila such as the Pasay Cockpit Arena in Pasay, Elorde Cockpit Arena in Parañaque, Zapote Cockpit Arena in Las Piñas, AP Recreational Area in Makati, Pasig Square Garden in Pasig, Mandaluyong Cockpit Arena in Mandaluyong, Northbay Cockpit Arena in Navotas, Potrero Cockpit Arena in Malabon, and Marikina Valley Cockpit Arena in Marikina. Occasional cockfights are held at the Araneta Coliseum in Quezon City, ULTRA Cockpit in Pasig, and San Juan Coliseum in San Juan. Cockfights held in large venues not solely dedicated to cockfighting are called pintakasi (derbies), which attract a large audience because elite and well-known fighting cocks, their handlers, and sponsors participate in these events. Large sums are allegedly exchanged in these fights. Derbies have even attracted foreign participants.

High-end cockfighting arenas are also situated in the provinces. Some of the arenas are air-conditioned and may be privately or publicly owned. Examples of these high-end arenas are Paniqui Provincial Cockpit in Tarlac, Iloilo Coliseum in Jaro, Iloilo, and the New Gallera de Mandaue Cockpit in Cebu.

Gambling has always been part of cockfighting. Wagers can go up into thousands of pesos, especially in the pintakasi where fighting cocks belonging to the rich are pitted against each other. The cockpit has a well-known figure called kristo, because with his arms outstretched like Christ on the cross, he takes bets from spectators while signaling the odds of each tupada (fight). The kristo are noted for their phenomenal memory. They can remember who made the bet, how much the bet was, and on which fighting cock a bet has been placed.

Because gambling is involved, government regulates cockfighting.

Presidential Decree (PD) 449 of 9 May 1974, known as the Cockfighting Law of 1974, regulates the construction of cockpits. Section 5 restricts ownership, operation, and management to Filipino citizens. Only one cockpit is allowed in each city or municipality, unless the population is over 100,000, in which case two cockpits may be opened. Cockpits must follow local zoning laws and are allowed to operate on Sundays and local fiestas, but operation is limited to three days. The PD was amended five times by Marcos, with the last amendment in 1981, PD 1802-A, creating the Philippine Gamefowl Commission. Despite regulations, there are unauthorized fights held clandestinely, requiring police action. Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from René B. Javellana and Nicanor G. Tiongson

text:
The sementeryo, from the Spanish cementerio, is a cemetery or memorial park —that is, a place for burying the dead. It is also known as kampo santo, from the Spanish campo, meaning “a tract of flat and even land,” and santo, meaning “holy”; pantyon, from the Spanish panteon, “a funeral monument”; and libingan, from the Tagalog libing, to bury, and an, a suffix denoting place.

The practice of burying the dead with special honors and in a special place is an ancient one, as attested to not only by the numerous burial grounds excavated throughout the Philippines but by the persistence of ancient burial practices among the enthnolinguistic communities of the Philippines. Excavations indicate that ancient Filipinos had elaborate rites for their dead and buried them with material goods such as tradeware, gold, and other ornaments such as the ones in Manila, particularly Lamayan St, Santa Ana; along the banks of Laguna de Bay, especially in Pila, Laguna; Iloilo in the Visayas; and Butuan in Mindanao.

 

Distinction must be made between primary and secondary burial: the first happens immediately after a person dies, and the second when the corpse is exhumed after a few months or years and the bones are interred or kept in some place of honor. For both primary and secondary burials, earthen or limestone jars were used. In some cases, the corpse was buried in a wooden coffin first, then the remains were kept in a jar. An outstanding example of a secondary burial earthen jar is the Manunggul jar found in Palawan. Earthen jars could be plain oversized pots with covers, or they could be decorated with light-colored slip, burnished or incised. Some earthen burial jars had zoomorphic and anthropomorphic figures molded on their covers, like the jars found in Maitum, Sarangani. Limestone burial jars found in Mindanao have flat sides and are incised with chevrons. Other burial jars are shaped as caskets or are zoomorphic.

 

Don Alonso Martin Quirante, sent by Gov-Gen Fajardo to conquer the Igorots, describes Kankanaey burial practices ca 1624: for many days prior to interment, often more than a month, the community gathers to feast around the corpse until it is fully desiccated, after which the body is wrapped in a blanket with provisions of buyo (betel nut) and other things given the corpse, then buried inside caves or placed on trees. The Dominican Francisco Antolin, writing in 1789, reports that the Tinguian inter their dead under the house, within the house or granary, or in a cemetery outside the village as in the case of Tonglo, or in mountainside caves. The dead are buried with as many as 20 expensive blankets and even personal ornaments or jewelry. The Ifugao, like the Tinguian, take part in lengthy feasts. The Ifugao, desiccate the corpse by salting and smoking with pine fires. After about four months, the bones are interred in one corner of the granary.

The practice of burying in caves persists today in the Cordilleras. The cave cemeteries of Sagada contain hundreds of mummified corpses, in some cases in wooden coffins. Today the Sama Dilaut (Badjao) and the Sama bury their dead on isolated islands. The southern Sama Dilaut’s traditional burial grounds are the islands of Bilatan Boon and Bunabunaan, Tawi-Tawi. Grave markers are carved with birds, sea horses, and serpents. Grave plots are adorned with canopies, colored paper parasols, and buntings. The Sama graves are marked with abstract sculptures that indicate the gender of the deceased and his or her status in the community.

 

The Spaniards did not find it difficult to convince the Filipinos of an afterlife. The Filipino practice of burying the dead with respect jibed squarely with the Christian respect for the dead in view of a future resurrection. Until the 19th century, it was the practice to bury dead Christians within the church grounds. Ecclesiastical and civil dignitaries were often buried within the church and in larger churches or cathedrals in a crypt below the sanctuary. Others were buried in an area on one side of the nave. In Europe, this was often the north side of the church, but the practice was not uniformly followed in the Philippines. Grave sites were marked by a lapida (stone slab), usually of marble, inscribed with the name of the deceased and the dates of birth and death. For secondary burial, the bones of the deceased were transferred to the church nave, where they were buried in the walls or in the floor of the church, appropriately marked by a stone slab.

During the 19th century, greater awareness of the spread of disease and a series of epidemics caused the cemeteries to be transferred outside the town boundaries often a kilometer or two away. These cemeteries were called campo santo. Ideally, the campo santo had a capilla (mortuary chapel) at its center and walls demarcating its boundaries. Within the walls were stone nichos (vaults) placed one on top of the other, where the dead, enclosed in a kabaong or ataul (coffin) were buried. The lapida sealed the nicho. The nicho was sometimes found along the perimeter wall; hence, the wall not only enclosed the cemetery but also served as a burial site. As a nicho was paid for by private individuals or rented from the church, the poor often could not afford such luxury and so for a pauper’s burial, a 2-meter-deep ditch was used. After about five years, secondary burial took place. For secondary burial, a place called osario, from the Latin ossa, meaning “bones,” was built. Wealthy individuals could have a special niche for their dead, while the poor or those remains which could not be identified were interred in a common niche.

The practice of secondary burial inside a church continued up to the 20th century when wealthy benefactors and other dignitaries were given a special place of honor on the church floor or wall, as seen in San Agustin Church. Another special place in the campo santo was the angelito (little angel), the burial site for baptized children who died before the age of reason which is seven. Catholic teaching indicated that such children went straight to heaven, rewarded for their unsullied innocence.

The campo santo was considered a consecrated ground, and those who were known as public sinners could not be buried in it. With the establishment of Masonry and churches other than the Catholic, the list of those who could not be buried in the campo santo increased. In response to the Catholic Church stand, Masons and Aglipayans took to building their own cemeteries, often right beside the Catholic, as in Cagayan de Oro.

In many towns, the cemetery was a flat space enclosed by a flimsy bamboo fence or thickets of the madre de cacao tree. But in more prosperous places, the cemetery was a well-designed space. An early example of this is the Paco Cemetery, built in 1823 as a burial site for victims of cholera. Two concentric walls enclose an open space divided into quadrants by spacious walkways. One walkway leads from the main entrance to the elliptical mortuary chapel and is covered by a stone vault. Behind the chapel are the angelito and osario. Outside Manila, outstanding cemeteries were built in Santa Maria and Vigan, Ilocos Sur; Nagcarlan, Laguna; Tabaco, Albay; San Joaquin and Janiuay, Iloilo; and Boljoon, Cebu.

The cemetery of Santa Maria, Ilocos Sur is at the foot of the hill where the church is built. The mortuary chapel within the cemetery is capped by a short bell tower. The outstanding feature of the Vigan Cemetery is the espadaña (bell turret) over the gate of the cemetery. The Nagcarlan Cemetery, built by Fr Vicente Belloc, OFM, is a brick structure. The mortuary chapel, located at the rear, is flanked by walls that curve out to enclose a circular space. Beside the chapel are the walls containing niches, and at the sides and front, the walls are pierced by arches. Inside the chapel, steps lead down to a crypt. The Tabaco Cemetery made of cut lava blocks has a handsome chapel with a hemispherical stone dome.

The San Joaquin, Iloilo cemetery has a low front section from where a grand flight of steps leads to the main elevated section dominated by an octagonal mortuary chapel with a towering dome. The Janiuay Cemetery, like San Joaquin, is elevated. Three front entrances, at the middle and sides, are impressive for their stairways and gothic arches. The cemetery chapel, now in ruins, was originally in the Gothic style. The gate of the Boljoon Cemetery is decorated by low reliefs of demons and symbols of death.

Toward the end of the Spanish period, the Archdiocese of Manila opened La Loma Cemetery at the outskirts of Manila. This cemetery, surrounded by a wall and entered through an elaborate wrought iron gate, has a full-sized church. Plots were laid out in orderly fashion for niches and mausoleums. The apportioning of public lands for cemeteries continued into the American period. The North and South Cemeteries were built for the inhabitants of Manila and its environs. Other municipal cemeteries were created. Many, however, were built after the American regime.

Cemeteries spawned a whole industry catering to the need for aesthetically pleasing burial sites. Prominent architects were employed by the rich to build mausoleums for their departed. These structures resembling small buildings could contain living quarters that are used on 1 Nov, All Saints Day, the day traditionally set for commemorating the dead.

Mausoleums range from the Egyptian style to the neogothic, neoclassic, art deco, and modern. Those in the Chinese Cemetery, which is adjacent to the North Cemetery and La Loma, draw from Chinese architecture. Ranking below the mausoleums are the nichos, often surmounted by a cross or by saints and angels. Other ornaments used in cemeteries are skulls, skeletons, laurel wreaths, lilies, and a tree or post cut in half or hourglasses with wings to symbolize the unexpectedness of death.

At the end of World War II, American and Filipino casualties were buried in special cemeteries. The American battle monuments in Makati and the Libingan ng mga Bayani are examples of such special cemeteries. The American Cemetery might be considered an early example of the memorial park that rose in popularity during the late 1960s. The American Cemetery has wide lawns planted with trees and flowers that were carefully chosen so that there is always one in bloom every time.

Patterned after memorial parks in the United States, the local memorial parks promise perpetual care for the grave of a loved one. Extensive landscaped grounds are properly zoned so that mausoleums occupy a particular area and nichos another, and wide tracts of green lawns cover burial vaults below ground level. A chapel, administration building, facilities, and free-standing sculpture complete the memorial park. The first memorial park to be opened was the Manila Memorial Park in Parañaque. Memorial parks have been built in many places outside Manila, their popularity stemming in part from the overcrowding and filth of the older cemeteries.

Reforms in Catholic liturgy, begun in the 1970s in response to the directives of Vatican II and concluded in 1965, led to the growing acceptance of cremation as a form of burial. Catholic rules stated that as long as cremation is not done to desecrate the body or to deny the resurrection of the body, which is considered sacred, cremation is allowed. The Catholic Church came up with a rite of burial for cremated remains. This development catalyzed the popularity of the columbarium or columbary, a place to keep cremated remains. Parish churches and cathedrals were quick to build columbariums or columbaria for the convenience of parishioners who now did not have to travel far to visit the grave of a relative, and for the economic benefits they brought in to the parish. Some early columbariums were built by Mount Carmel Parish in Quezon City and San Antonio Parish in Forbes Park. Memorial Park companies, funeral parlors, and municipal governments soon added to the number of columbariums.

Columbariums are either indoor, meaning in a crypt in a basement or in the premises of the church, or outdoor, meaning in a garden or open space in the premises of the church. Columbariums have single or family niches for the remains. Quite popular is the family niche about 50 cm wide, deep and tall, with a capacity for four urns. With the increasing popularity of cremations, funeral parlors have built their own crematoriums. The columbariums have also spread to the provinces.

Columbariums pose hardly any health hazards as the remains interred in them pass through fire. The Housing and Land Use Regulatory Board has placed the easement between a planned columbarium and a residential area at five meters.  Written by René B. Javellana
