text:
Teatro or theater refers to a building designed specifically for theatrical, musical, and dance presentations. It is also known as dula-an from the Tagalog dula, meaning “play,” and an, “a suffix denoting place,” and coliseo, from the Latin colosseum, meaning “a large place for staging spectacles.” The teatro may be an independent building or an auditorium, which could just be part of a larger structure such as a school or an office building.

 

The Spanish Colonial Period

“Teatro” was the name given to the structure when first introduced in the Philippines. The earliest theaters in the Philippines, known as teatros al aire libre (open-air theaters), were made up of a temporary platform surrounded by an open space for spectators. During fiestas and special occasions, there were portable stages assembled and dismantled after all the performances. It consisted mainly of the entablado (stage platform) and backstage areas; the audience section for the spectators; and the entrance lobby. Where a performance takes place is generally framed by an arch, the proscenio (proscenium), and covered by a curtain. The backstage has spaces for dressing rooms, space for scenery and equipment, workshops, and storage rooms. The audience section of old theaters was either rectangular or circular in plan, occupied by rows of seats that may be sloping on a single level or on several levels. Another type built in Arroceros and Tondo was the camarin-teatro (barn theater) of bamboo and nipa or thatch structure, a podium, and an audience section with wooden benches.

In the later years, the teatro adopted a trapezoidal or fan-shaped plan with the stage at the narrow end. Aisles ran between rows of seats and along the sidewalls. Seats were grouped in boxes or on tiers. The audience section was reached through a lobby. The balcony above the lobby was used as a lounge where the audience gathered for refreshments and to smoke during intermissions. The teatro may have other spaces within the building such as administrative offices, shops, and a refreshment parlor.

The Teatro Comico was located in the Campo de Arroceros near the Pasig River that flourished from 1780 to 1790. Tondo in 1840 was the setting of coliseos (bamboo theaters roofed with nipa) where Tagalog plays were performed.

The two most significant permanently-built theaters were Teatro del Principe Alfonso built in 1862 and Teatro de Binondo, also known as Teatro Español, inaugurated in 1864. Teatro de Binondo,first of the elegant theaters outside the walls of Intramuros, was a two-story building of stone, brick and wood with an arcaded first story, and the second level with an open colonnade, and balcony with balustrade. It was located on a site along a street parallel to Escolta, now San Vicente, between San Jacinto and Nueva Sts. It was built at a cost of 30,000 pesos sourced from the coffers of Caja de Carriedo and Obras Pias. The spacious lobby of the theater leads to a semicircular auditorium and an orchestra section with tiered seats. The seating included palcos (boxes) classified as principales and segundas (first and second class); plateas (tiered seats) on the main floor; and the tertulia or paraiso (gallery), the uppermost section. The stage is framed in a wide and pointed proscenium because of the angle of the roof. The theater soon became the hub of Manila’s upper crust and “the construction of the new theater has brought Manila a step closer to European civilization” (Cariño 2002).

The Teatro del Principe Alfonso, later called Teatro Español, was constructed in 1862 by Juan Barbero, a veteran stage director and actor, using light materials, largely of wood and galvanized iron. A popular venue for sarsuwela and komedya, it was open to all social classes. Located on the Campo de Arroceros, now the area between Quezon Bridge and MacArthur Bridge, it accommodated as much as 650 spectators.

With its reputed capacity of 2,500, Teatro Circo de Bilibid, originally a bullring, was the largest in its time. It was named as such because of its circular plan, and it was located opposite the Bilibid prison. The roof was of wood and galvanized iron. It flourished in the 1870s, became a cockpit in 1880, and was destroyed by a typhoon in 1882.

Similar in shape to the Teatro Circo de Bilibid was the Teatro de Novedades, later known as Teatro de Variedades. It was originally an octagonal pavilion for public dances and was converted to a theater in 1878. It was located opposite the Teatro del Principe Alfonso.

Across the Pasig, at the corner of Calle San Roque and Calle General Echague, was the Teatro Filipino built in 1880. It was constructed as a rectangular building of wood with galvanized iron roof. It had only one tier of boxes, the best of which were near the stage.

Considered the most celebrated in its time was the Teatro Circo Zorrilla, named after the Spanish poet and playwright Jose Zorrilla y Moral. Inaugurated in 1893, the theater was located at the corner of the Calzada de Iris and Calle San Pedro, now bounded by Recto Ave, Quezon Blvd, and Calle Evangelista. The circular hall accommodated 1,352 spectators, four of whom could sit in the palcos de honor (box of honor), 48 in palcos arranged in tiers, 400 in the butacas (orchestra seats), and 900 in the galeria (general admission section). The Zorrilla was the venue for sarsuwela, opera, drama, concerts, and silent movies. It was demolished in 1936 and its site is now occupied by Isetann Mall of Quiapo.

Teatro Tagalo de Tondo or Coliseo de Tondo prospered from 1840 to 1890 and was originally a structure of bamboo and nipa, with a facade of sawali, later of wood with galvanized iron roof. Other theaters were the Teatro Infantil de Dulumbayan that was 24 m wide and 34 m long. The stage had a nipa roof, and wood and bamboo floor. It had 14 palcos, 30 butacas, 12 seats in the orchestra pit, and a five-tiered galeria with bamboo seats. The Teatro Guiñol was 6 m wide and 14 m long, without roof and demountable for easy transport. A Franciscan Friar Cipriano Gomez established the only true opera house of the 19th century in Pandacan, sometime in 1887. The theater was exclusively for opera performed by native singers who were trained by an Italian teacher. Ladislao Bonus was the conductor of the orchestra.

Even during the Spanish era, schools encouraged the dramatic arts and promoted theater and similar functions to enhance the confidence of students and to train them in rhetoric and eloquence. Schools had a salon de actos, an auditorium, which could be used for dramatic performances. In the salon of Ateneo was enacted Jose Rizal’s Junto al Pasig (On the Banks of the Pasig), a short play to celebrate the Virgin of Antipolo’s fluvial procession through the Pasig.

 

 

The American Colonial Period

The durable Manila Grand Opera House was built in 1902 and followed the traditional design, with tiers of boxes around the audience section. The First Philippine Assembly was inaugurated on 16 Oct 1907 in this theater. The building was burned during World War II but later rebuilt like a cinema-style auditorium. Most movie stars of the 1950s and 1960s started their career in the post-war Manila Grand Opera House.

Occupying the forefront of art deco style in the Philippines was Juan Arellano’s Metropolitan Theater built in the 19th-century theater district along Arroceros, in Plaza Lawton. Inaugurated in 1931, it marked Arellano’s deviation from his Beaux Arts lineage. The facade of the Metropolitan could be likened to a stage whose focal point was a framed, proscenium-like central window of stained glass that corresponded in scale and in shape to the theater proscenium inside. This window was emphasized on both sides by curving walls that were lavishly decorated with tapestries of colored tiles reminiscent of traditional Southeast Asian batik patterns. The entrance doors had grillwork resembling stylized birds of paradise (Lico 2008, 336).

The theater proper could be accessed through a wide foyer which had a two-story semi-vaulted ceiling and was flanked on both sides by wide marble stairways leading to the loge and balcony. Two mural paintings of Fernando Amorsolo, The Dance and History of Music, were placed above the stair landings on the second floor. Moderne statues by Italian sculptor Francesco Monti enhanced the opulence of the lobby. The space above the proscenium was an exquisite setting for bas-relief figures allegorically depicting Music, Tragedy, Comedy, and Poetry, while a cascade of silver jewel-like plaques adorned both sides of the proscenium. It was designed for plays, opera, symphony concerts, and cinema. The orchestra, loge, and balcony of the auditorium could accommodate a 1,670 audience. Stylized from Philippine vegetation and wildlife, the motifs were executed with the assistance of Arellano’s elder brother Arcadio and Isabelo Tampinco, the leading decorative sculptor of the day. The building was destroyed in the 1945 World War II battle for liberation and was not restored until 1978 under the supervision of Otillo Arellano, Juan Arellano’s nephew (Lico 2008, 338).

During the American era, two school-based theaters, both in art deco, were well known in Manila: St Cecilia’s Music Hall and the Ateneo Theater. In 1906, the same year the Benedictine sisters established St. Scholastica College, Sr Baptista Battig, OSB, a student of the German composer and pianist Franz Liszt and an accomplished concert pianist before joining the Benedictines, founded a conservatory of music. St Cecilia’s was built as a venue for student concerts at St. Scholastica’s which were much awaited social events. Designed by Andres Luna de San Pedro in the style of the Egyptian art deco and completed in 1932, St Cecilia gave the concerts a noble home.

If Sr Battig was the moving force behind St Cecilia’s, American Jesuit Lee Henry Irwin was the one behind the Ateneo Theater. He taught at the Ateneo de Manila as a scholastic in 1922 and 1923, and he staged Julius Caesar in 1922. He returned to the United States to complete his studies and 10 years later, returned to Manila. Upon assuming his position as Grade School Headmaster, Irwin started mounting plays like King Lear. Under his encouragement, the Ateneo built a theater which was designed by Ateneo alumnus Juan Nakpil and completed in 1936. The theater which had a capacity of about 800 was famous for its acoustics. It had an orchestra pit and 19 dressing rooms, a very deep stage with four prosceniums. Irwin then introduced Manila to a program of Shakespeare’s plays. With the assistance of Jesuit scholastics, the annual passion play was mounted for Lent. It drew a large following, including Manila’s high society and government officials, including Pres Manuel Quezon. The theater, like St Cecilia’s, was damaged during World War II, but unlike the latter, it was never rebuilt.

The school auditorium, which also served as a theater venue, was a standard for schools before World War II. Far Eastern College (now a university), designed by Pablo Antonio, built art deco buildings along Quezon Ave, in 1939; the FEU Theater housed the administration building.

 

The Period of the Republics

During the post-World War II era, theaters continued to be built. In 1958, the Jose Rizal Centennial Commission presented the plan to build a National Shrine composed of a national theater, national library and museum at the Wallace Field in Luneta. The centerpiece for this project was to be Juan Nakpil’s National Theater designed in 1959, an edifice that would have combined concrete folded plate and spherical thin shell roof to achieve a sculptural and monumental effect. But the National Theater failed to be constructed on Wallace Field.

With a revised plan and simpler scheme than those of the national theater, Nakpil designed the Rizal Theater. It was the first theater in Makati and the centerpiece of Makati Commercial Center planned by the Ayala Company as part of an extensive urban development plan. Although normally used as a movie house, it had a large stage suitable for ballets and musicals. The auditorium had one sloping floor with orchestra, loge, and balcony forming one vast space. Unfortunately it was demolished in the 1980s to make way for Shangri-La Hotel.

Located on a 35-hectare site in Cubao, Quezon City, the Araneta Coliseum, built 1957-59, was an engineering achievement during its time. Between the years 1960-63, it reigned as the biggest domed coliseum in the world. The coliseum was constructed of reinforced concrete cylinder, with an aluminum dome structure having a diameter of 108 m. The dome was made of steel with 48 main ribs meeting in a compression ring that floated high above the floor. The dome was suspended 10 stories or 36.8 m above the arena floor, which itself had an area of 2.3 ha. It has been one of the largest clear span dome in the world and the largest indoor facility in Southeast Asia for sometime.

 

Theaters in the 1960s were a challenge to the creativity of the architect. When the Insular Life moved from Binondo to Makati in 1962, the Ayala Companies built what was then the tallest building along Ayala Ave, exceeding the 30 m limit of older buildings. Designed by Cesar Concio, Insular Life was noted for its rounded corner, its expressive use of sun baffles, and the bas-relief mural by Napoleon Abueva. Also well known was Insular Life Theater, located on the upper floor of the central building. Although built for corporate events, its stage was adaptable to theater productions. Repertory Philippines, established in 1967, adapted Insular as the venue for Broadway productions, linking Insular and Repertory in the popular mind. Greenhills Theater, completed in 1968 and designed by Antonio Heredia, was the first structure to use the technology of post-tension structural system that allowed a clear span 52 m and 6 m overhang and allowed the structure to “move with the earth” to reduce the disastrous effect of an earthquake. Acoustic engineering, lighting design, and sightlines of the audience were primary considerations for most of the theaters built during this period.

The most popular venue for quality concerts in the 1960s and 1970s was the ground-floor theater of Philam-Life Building on United Nations Ave which was known for its quality acoustics. Designed by Architect Carlos Arguelles, the theater orchestra had side walls lined with carved murals, while the wide theater lobby was dominated by a stained glass sarimanok by Galo Ocampo.

The Meralco Building, 1968, was designed by Architect Jose Maria V. Zaragoza. Located on Ortigas Ave, the 14-story building was known for the Meralco Theater on its ground floor. Plays, operas, musicals, ballets, and concerts have graced its spacious stage. It had the first revolving stage and its seating gently sloped so that what would have been the balcony section flowed into the orchestra.

Inaugurated in 1969, the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ (CCP) Theater of the Performing Arts houses the Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo (formerly the Main Theater), 1,805-seater; Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino (formerly the Little Theater), a 402-seater; and Tanghalang Huseng Batute (formerly Bulwagang Gantimpala), an experimental space which seats a maximum of 250. It also houses art galleries, a museum, rehearsal rooms, and offices. Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo has an orchestra section, parterre boxes, two balconies, and two tiers of side boxes as well as a large orchestra pit. The Theater of the Performing Arts is the work of National Artist Leandro V. Locsin. He worked with the finest technical team consisting of structural engineer Alfredo L. Juinio, constructor David M. Consunji, acoustical consultants Bolt, Beranek and Newman, mechanical and electro-systems consultants and others to create a venue that gave splendid quality to all the performances in this theater.

 

The CCP complex rises prominently on reclaimed land along Roxas Blvd. Another structure that is part of the complex is the Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas, better known as Folk Arts Theater. Designed by Locsin, it is an arena-type, thousand-seat theater constructed within an incredibly short period for the Miss Universe Pageant in 1974. It was in use for pop concerts and other big productions until the 1990s when it had to close for major repairs. Since then the theater has been leased out to the public. A lessee, Day by Day Christian Ministries, rented the place in 2005, calling it Bulwagan ng Panginoon (Hall of the Lord). The Manila Film Center nearby, built in 1982 for the Manila International Film Festival, was damaged by an earthquake in 1990. It was ordered closed and remains unused, except occasionally when it is rented out.

Also designed by Locsin was the National Arts Center, 1976, at Mt Makiling, Los Baños for the National High School for the Arts. The huge theater has a pyramidal roof over an audience section that is open on three sides.

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, as the Philippines faced the problem of political, social, and economic recovery, some performing arts venues started to deteriorate for lack of maintenance and lack of viable activities. The Metropolitan Theater, restored in 1978, went into an economic downspin as income plummeted. Restored with a loan from GSIS, the building was sequestered for being unable to service its debt. Left idle, the building deteriorated. In 2015, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, exercising its right of first refusal on the sale of cultural treasures as mandated in the National Heritage Act, took over this heritage building. It got approval from the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) to purchase the building.

In the early 1990s, new theaters were built, which were equipped with the latest devices in stage technology. The AFP Theater in Camp Aguinaldo is a fully-equipped venue built ca 1996. It has a capacity of 1,074. While it serves the needs of the army camp, it is also rented out to the public. The Carlos P. Romulo Auditorium in RCBC Plaza, designed by Fisher Dachs Associates, Skidmore Owings & Merrill, W.V. Cosculluela & Associates, is a multipurpose venue for corporate activities and for performances. It seats 450. Construction of RCBC began in 1996 and was completed in 2001. The auditorium is suited for smaller productions, although musicals have been successfully staged in it.

Resort’s World Theater is located inside the Resort’s World Manila in Newport City, beside the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA) Terminal 3. A joint venture between Alliance Global Group and Genting Hong Kong, the complex was inaugurated in stages, beginning with a soft launch on 28 Aug 2009. The theater is in the restaurant and cinema wing, connected to the hotel and casino by a wide corridor flanked by retail stores. The theater is known for its wide stage and its state-of-the-art stage equipment.

Mall of Asia Arena is a multipurpose indoor arena which can seat 16,000 to 20,000. It is a flexible arena which can be configured for sports, its primary use, but also for religious events, like the visit of Pope Francis in Jan 2015 and entertainment events like rock concerts. The arena was opened on 16 Jun 2012.

Solaire Theater in the Solaire Resort and Casino Complex, completed in 2013, is described as a lyrical theater. With a capacity of 1,760, the fan-shaped theater employs Constellation Acoustic System created by Meyer Sound which has the ability to alter the acoustical properties of the hall to suit the requirements of different types of local and international performances such as Broadway musicals, operas, concertos, and ballets.

School-based theater became an even more important phenomenon after the war. Many schools rebuilt, refurbished or built theaters in their compounds. St Cecilia of St Scholastica’s College was rebuilt. Another important theater was the Fleur de lis Auditorium in St Paul College, Manila, which was known for plays in which students of St Paul’s and the neighboring boys’ schools, the Ateneo de Manila on Padre Faura St and De La Salle College on Taft Ave, would participate. Here, Fr James Reuter, SJ staged notable plays and musicals. The auditorium was inaugurated on 12 Dec 1957 and came to be known as the “Broadway on Herran” because of its musical productions. Fleur de lis was designed by Jose L. Reynoso. National Artist Carlos “Botong” Francisco painted the 3.5 by 4.5 mural, Evolution of Philippine Culture, which was ready for the theater’s grand opening.

In the 1950s and 1960s, St Joseph’s College Mater Dei Auditorium was a popular venue in Quezon City. St Joseph’s, a school run by the Franciscan Sisters for the growing community of New Manila, Kamuning, and San Juan, opened in 1932. It was abruptly closed during World War II but reopened in 1948. The Mater Dei Auditorium was built after World War II behind the main building of St Joseph’s. The annual play held at the auditorium was an event that drew a large audience. Zenaida Amador was the director of many of these plays. She mounted Broadway musicals here until she established Repertory Philippines.

Up until 2004, the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) mounted its performances at the open-air Dulaang Rajah Sulayman in Fort Santiago. That same year, construction for the PETA Theater Center began. Inaugurated in 2006, the PETA Theater Center in Eymard Drive, New Manila, Quezon City is now the venue for PETA’s productions and is also leased to independent theater groups. Its black box theater, known as the PETA Phinma Theater, has an adjustable stage and audience arrangement. “It may be an Arena, an End Stage, or Thrust Stage using various platforms, thrusts, ramps and extensions as imagined or required by each production” (PETA Phinma Theater 2016). Depending on the stage and audience arrangement, the theater can accommodate anywhere from 400 to 450 people. The PETA Theater Center also has a library (known as Lia Sciortino and O’ong Maryono Resource Center), two studios which serve as rehearsal space and a multipurpose venue, a roofdeck that can also be used as venue for intimate performances, and two halls—the PETA Smart Exhibition Hall and the Lino Brocka Hall—which are also multifunctional.

The University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman Campus has a number of theaters. Abelardo Hall, the music hall of the Conservatory of Music, was built from 1960 to 1963. Architect Roberto Novenario designed it, following the International Style which used honeycomb sun baffles as brise-soleil. The Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater at Palma Hall, the home of Dulaang UP, was designed and refurbished from the existing auditorium that was built with the rest of Palma Hall after World War II. Other theaters in UP are the UP Theater (also known as Villamor Hall) and Aldaba Hall at the back of the UP Theater, Teatro Hermogenes Ilagan at the Faculty Center which was gutted down by fire in 2016, and Cine Adarna of the UP Film Insitute Film Center, which is dedicated to cinema.

After World War II, Ateneo moved to Quezon City and did not have a large theater like the one in Padre Faura. So in the 1950s and 1960s, plays were mounted in multipurpose auditoriums in the Grade School and College and in the High School covered courts. In 1956, Onofre Pagsanghan established the Ateneo High School Dramatics Society, which was renamed Dulaang Sibol in 1966. For many years this theater group did not have a theater of its own but performed in classrooms with improvised lights made of recycled tin cans and par lamps, until Dulaang Sibol theater, renamed Tanghalang Onofre Pagsanghan, was built in the 1980s. Ateneo also built the Henry Lee Irwin Theater in the 1980s, a 1,200-seater beside the Ateneo Grade School.

Most of the better-known school-based theaters are concentrated in the National Capital Region. Thus, Silliman University’s Claire Isabel Mc Gill Luce Auditorium built in 1973 and completed in 1975 stands as an exception. It is considered the largest and most fully equipped theater outside Metro Manila. In 2008, work on upgrading the theater was completed with a grant from the Luce Foundation, which initially sponsored its construction. Shaped as a sculptural block with the lower portion truncated at the facade to make way for the glass-enclosed entrance, the upper portion of the structure serves as canopy and foyer to the theater.

The College of Saint Benilde’s School of Design and Arts houses a theater built as a structure that juts out of the facade in a daring cantilever. The theater also serves as the canopy for the main entrance. The theater and school complex, designed by Ed Calma in the deconstructionist postmodern idiom, was completed in 2007.  Written by Rodrigo D. Perez III, with notes from Maria Cristina V. Turalba and René B. Javellana

Manobo tree house

(The Manobos of Mindanao by John M. Garvan, Washington DC Government Printing Office, 1931)

Depiction of a Mandaya village with tree houses

(Le Tour du Monde, Nouveau Journal des Voyages by Edouard Charton, Librairie de L. Hachette et Cie, 1884)

text:
The tree house, built either on tree stumps or limbs, has become a rarity in the country. Early 20th century anthropologists and travelers have documented it as existing only in a few parts of northern Luzon among such groups as the Bugkalot (Ilongot) and the Gaddang, in north-central Mindanao among the Bukidnon, and in some areas in eastern Mindanao among the Manobo of Agusan and the Mandaya of Davao. It was usually found in places where violent intercommunity strifes and night attacks were frequent. Occasionally, it was a practical solution to frequent flooding in low-lying areas and to wild animals prowling at night.

One of the earliest accounts of the tree house was written by the Frenchman Paul de la Gironiere in the early 19th century. Writing about the dwelling and settlement patterns of the Tinguian of Palan, northwest Abra, he noted that the Tinguian had a day and a night abode. The day abode was a typical bamboo and straw hut of modest proportions, while the night abode called alligang was even smaller and was perched high on a tree top, about 18-24 m above ground, as a precaution against surprise nocturnal attacks of the Guinana, their archenemy.

 

In 1913, Fay Cooper Cole wrote on the tree houses of the Mandaya of Mindanao. Cole noted two types of tree houses: firstly, those that rest “on the limbs of trees, conforming in size and shape to the nature of the supporting branches,” and secondly, those built on trees whose crowns had been “cut off some 4.5 or 6 m above the ground leaving the stump to serve as a part of the foundation.” Houses of the first type had sloping roofs and some did not have sidewalls. For those without horizontal sides, the roofs sloped directly from a central ridgepole to the edges of the platform, making the sidewalls unnecessary. In the second type, many smaller poles were added to support the flooring and also to extend the space upward to form the framework for both the walls and the roof. Either type of house was entered by means of a notched pole or a bamboo or rattan ladder which was drawn up at night to prevent illegal entries and surprise attacks by warring groups.

The tree house is often located on the edge of cliffs and can be approached only from one direction.

Although fragile in appearance, the Mandaya tree house could endure even the worst storms; the whole house may move and creak with each strong wind but it always remains safely in place. Using no nails nor hardware, the structure is firmly lashed together with rattan, and during turbulent weather, further secured by anchoring the house with the help of strong vines to nearby trees. Despite its limited size, this house can also accommodate two to three families living together. As by custom, suitors and husbands of married daughters reside with the women’s folk.

 

Several other tribal groups are reported to have tree houses, namely, the Gaddang of northern Luzon, whose thatched-pile dwellings are built right into the high-forked branches of a tree; some members of the Higaonon tribe of Bukidnon, whose swaying high-rise dwellings are connected by a wobbly catwalk to a central communal room; the Bugkalot, whose houses are scattered and concealed in the forest, fenced with fallen trees and thorny bamboo, and approached by way of a hidden entrance; and other groups like the Tiruray, the Manobo, and the Aeta.

A further development of the tree house concept may be seen in houses propped up on poles as tall as trees in elevations ranging from 6 to 18 meters above the ground among such peoples as the Blaan. The aforementioned groups, however, also maintain other types of piled dwellings, moving to the tree house only during critical periods when defense is important.  Written by Ma. Corazon A. Hila

text:
During the Spanish era, the tribunal or casa tribunal, usually built along or near the plaza, which fronted the church, was the town’s court of law. It was also known as corte (court) and juzgado (judge’s sala).The analogue of the tribunal in Manila,

 

The colonial capital, was the audiencia. The term referred both to the body of justices constituting the supreme court of the archipelago and the building where they held their sessions. Audiencia referred also to the process of litigation where a hearing was done. The justices had their own building across the Palacio del Gobernador at the site presently occupied by a fire department along Aduana St, presently A. Soriano.

 

A feature that distinguished the casa tribunal from the casa real (royal house) was the presence of a calabozo (jail), usually on the first floor of the two-story structure or in the most secure area of a one-story structure. The two-story casa tribunal did not differ much from the bahay na bato (stone house) except that some tribunal, were made entirely of stone and had balconies jutting out of the facade. The one-story type was similar to the schoolhouse. When a town had no casa tribunal, the casa real or the convento in the church complex served as tribunal, hence the stories about friars imprisoning and punishing dissidents in the convento.

 

A development of the calabozo in the tribunal was the construction of penal institutions and colonies during the 19th century, the best examples of which are Bilibid in Manila, the carcel in Cebu, and San Ramon in Zamboanga. Another common penal practice during this century was deportation to Mindanao, Paragua (now Palawan) or the Marianas. Deportation had a double purpose: punishment and the creation of communities in areas not under Spanish rule. Prisoners—whether criminals, vagabonds, prostitutes, or political dissidents—were housed in bahay kubo (nipa hut) settlements organized by the civil government. In some cases, areas of deportation were disorganized. Deportees were simply sent to a place and left to fend for themselves, building whenever and however they pleased. Missionaries sent to Mindanao found many settlements disorganized. They took the initiative of organizing the towns, following the norms of colonial town planning. They laid out streets in a grid, designated sites for the church, plaza, casa real, and tribunal and standardized the size of home lots. Areas in Mindanao where deportees were sent were Dapitan, famous for being the place of exile of Jose Rizal from 1892 to 1896, Davao, and Surigao.  Written by René B. Javellana

text:
The tsalet, which comes from the French word chalet, meaning “sheltered place,” originally referred to the Swiss peasant house characterized by a steep roof, an ornamented gable, and upper floors projecting over the lower ones. In the Philippines the term is used for the compactly planned, one-story suburban house that appeared during the early decades of the 20th century. The tsalet could also be a two-story structure with living quarters on the upper floor or a one-story house elevated above the ground. The house embodied principles of tropical architecture popularized by the government architect William Parsons. The one-story house, like the bahay kubo (nipa hut), was raised 50 cm or more above the ground to avoid the humidity of the earth. The first floor of the two-story house, like that of the bahay na bato (stone house) was an empty space. Concrete was used for its foundations and piers. A prominent feature was the veranda built in front of the house or on three sides of it which was often adorned with carved railings. Entrance to the house was through a simple set of stairs at the very center of the house facade, or through an L- or T-shaped concrete or wooden stairway. Stairs were usually concrete but could also be of wood. The house, made of wood, had large windows, a departure from those of the Swiss prototype which were small and hung as casements. Neither was its galvanized iron roof as low pitched nor as largely projected at the eaves as in the continental variety. Instead the roof had vents to allow the free flow of air, thus cooling the structure.

 

Compared with the older bahay na bato, the tsalet was simple, comfortable, and not ostentatious, although some used decorative elements like lattice work and carved transoms. Planned as a quadrilateral, the tsalet had the amenities of modern living: a living room, dining room, kitchen, bedrooms, and bathrooms. The tsalet, often built in a lot with trees and flower gardens, was a comfortable home for the urbanized middle class that emerged and grew under the American colonial period. There were different variations—that is, with adaptations of the continental, American (the log-cabin type), and native models, and with some local details. In Metro Manila, the tsalet can still be found in the Paco and Malate districts of Manila, in Pasay City, and in San Juan City where Cafe Ysabel is located.  Written by Monica P. Consing and Ma. Corazon A. Hila, with notes from René B. Javellana

text:
The tulay, also known as taytay or puente, is a bridge—that is, a horizontal structure that provides passage between two points separated by a depression, a body of water, or a thoroughfare.

At the turn of the 19th century, American engineers documented elaborate indigenous bridges. One built over a river on the Carigara-Barugo Road in Leyte consisted of dressed wood beams and planks and had a geometrically designed wooden handrail and a nipa roof. Indigenous Philippine bridges are constructed out of pliant but sturdy materials like bamboo and coconut trunks. The Mandaya of Davao Oriental connect their houses built above bamboo marshes with bamboo bridges without handrails. Even today, the bamboo or coconut bridge is found in areas where the government has not yet built suitable infrastructure. Tall bamboo poles or coconut trunks are lashed together to form the piers of the bridge. The number of piers depends on the distance to be spanned. The piers support girders, which in turn carry the bamboo poles that form the passage. The bridge may have a handrail, often to one side.

 

Spanish Colonial Era

Stone bridges were introduced by the Spaniards in the Philippines. While the Spanish colonial era is identified with the iconic church, convento, and fortifications, it was also a time when great effort was exerted to open land routes to gain access to the highlands and remote areas of the country and to complement the sea and riverine routes, the time-tested way of reaching towns and settlements. A good number of friars were responsible for building these land routes which had bridges traversing waterways and chasms.

Augustinian bridge builders were Fr Andres Patiño, who linked Malabon and Tinajeros, and Fr Francisco Valencia, who linked Malabon with Navotas. Frs Ramon Sanchez, Benito Varas, Ramon del Marco, Celestino Mayordomo, and Raymundo Cortazar worked in Batangas, especially in Lipa, Tanauan, and Taal. Frs Buzeta, an author, Melchor Fernandez, and Antonio Piernavieja built bridges in Bulacan. Fr Juan Tombo connected San Miguel de Mayumo, Bulacan with Gapan, Nueva Ecija. Along Luzon’s western coast, Frs Rufino Redondo, Evaristo Guadalupe, and Antonio Jorda worked in Ilocos. Fr Jose Coruguedo linked Narvacan with Abra. As early as 1579, a year after they arrived in Manila, Franciscans were busy building roads and bridges in Laguna. A pioneer was Fr Francisco de Gata. A Franciscan brother, Lorenzo de Santa Maria, assisted the priests by opening roads to link the Franciscan missions. Fr De la Parilla built a bridge in Baras, Rizal and laid out the six principal streets of the town. Fr Jose Fernandez connected Dulag with Tanauan in Leyte.

Jesuits were known as builders of churches, residences, and colleges but their work in infrastructure has not been sufficiently studied. Two names come up as builders: Fr Antonio Sedeño and Fr Diego Garcia.

Dominicans had a reputation for being builders of roads and bridges that lasted. Two well-known friars are Frs Manuel del Rio and Juan Villaverde who opened a way to the Cagayan Valley from Pangasinan and Nueva Ecija. The mountain trail between Malionliong, Pangasinan, through the Central Cordillera then reaching Ituy Valley of Nueva Vizcaya, and continuing to Gamu, Isabela was the work of Fr del Rio. Completed in 1739, this roadway passed through hostile territory and was later on abandoned. In the 19th century, Fr Villaverde created a mountain trail now named after him—the Villaverde Pass in northern Luzon. He also linked Nueva Vizcaya with Kiangan via Bagabag; Ibung via Solano, Nueva Vizcaya; and Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya and San Nicolas, Pangasinan. Frs Manuel Corripio worked on the roads of Dupax, Francisco Carrozal built the road system of Solano, and Antonio Lobato built roads and bridges in Tuguegarao. In Pangasinan, Frs Eugenio Minguez built the Sual-Zambales road; Gabriel Perez the Lingayen-Salasa road; Quiros y Domingo Taboada, the Mangaldan-Santa Barbara road; and Gaspar de Castro a link road between San Jacinto de Cauili and Manaoag. Fr Ramon Agustin built the road linking Manaog and Binalonan. In Batanes, two bridges at Ivana were built by Fr Nicolas Castaño.

The Recollects had Frs Simon de San Agustin who built the bridge linking Quiapo with San Sebastian; Marcial Bellido who linked Masinloc with Palawig in Zambales; Celestino Yoldi who built the road to San Juan de Bolboc, Batangas; and Lucas de Jesus Maria who built the Calle Rosario near the Puente de España. Fr Matias Carbonell built Puente Isabel II near the Recollect hacienda at Imus. For this deed, Fr Carbonell was honored by acting Gov-Gen Ramon Montero in 1857 (Noche 2011, 17-20).

Civil engineering came to the Philippines in the middle of the 19th century when the Inspeccion General de Caminos y Canales was organized in 1799 during the reign of Carlos IV of Spain. By 1834, the Escuela de Ingeniera Civil was organized in Spain, which provided training and education for engineers prior to posting in Spain or in the colonies. The corps in charge of building was known as Cuerpo de Ingenieros de Caminos, Canales, y Puertos. In the Philippines, the Inspeccion General de Obras Publicas was established in 1866 and was subsumed under the Dirrecion General de Administracion Civil. Engineers who worked for Obas Publicas were Manuel Ramirez Bazan, Castro Olano, Genaro Palacios, Eduardo Lopez Navarro, and Damian Quero. Complementing the work of civil engineers were military engineers like Francisco de Castro Ponte, Carlos de las Heras, Rafael Quevedo, and Agustin Lopez Maroto (Noche 2011, 21-2).

The bridges built during the Spanish era followed a traditional method of construction using stone arches. This method of construction can be traced back to the ancient Romans but enjoyed resurgence during the Renaissance when more and more infrastructure was built in Europe and then in the European colonies in the Americas, Africa, and Asia. To build arched bridges, the piers had to be built first and this involved building a temporary coffer dam where the pier was to be placed. Then a stone and mortar structure with deep foundations was built. The type of stonework and mortaring used in the construction of churches, homes, the casa real (royal house), wall, and other colonial buildings was also used for bridges. Once the piers were set, a wooden form in the shape of a semicircular arch was laid, linking one pier to another. The cut stones that formed the arch were laid over the form and linked using mortar. The bridge was then waterproofed using a sand and mortar layer called palitada.

Noche’s documentation (2011) of Spanish era bridges shows the extent of bridge building during the Spanish colonial era. Some bridges are still in place and in use, but some are known only through documentation and photographs. Some have survived, at least partially, often hidden from view because they have been overlaid with a new roadbed. What follows is a quick survey of bridges Noche documented and arranged geographically, with Manila as the hub.

Manila. The walled city of Intramuros was surrounded by a moat, and Fort Santiago was cut off from the city by a moat. Intramuros bridges led to the principal gates of Intramuros, some passing through ravellins before arriving at the gate. While the Intramuros bridges were made of stone, the portion closest to the wall was a wooden drawbridge that was lifted to seal the city. A nightly curfew was imposed so that inhabitants had to be inside the walled city before the drawbridges were raised at 11 at night.

In 1772, Puente del Fuerza de Santiago was built slightly west of Fort Santiago’s main gate. Puente de Puerta del Parian, 1782, connected to the Revellin del Parian, which in turn had Puente del Revellín del Parian, 1814. Designed by Mariano de Ocampo, Puente del Fuerza connected with the Escolta, a road that linked the north and south banks of the Pasig through a bridge. Puente de la Puerta Real de Bagumbayan was built to connect the new Puerta Real built after the British occupation, 1762-64. It connected with Puente Durmiente, 1784, that arches into the Revellin de Bagumbayan (Noche 2011, 52-60). Beyond the walls of Intramuros, Manila was divided into north and south and bisected by the Pasig River. An early stone bridge vital to the life of Intramuros and the neighboring districts was the Puente Grande de España built in 1630. It spanned the south and north banks of the Pasig River (Noche 2011, 32). Located east of the site presently occupied by Jones Bridge, the bridge consisted of elliptical arches of stone resting on massive stone piers. In the course of its history, the bridge was renovated a number of times in the 19th century: in 1814 under Domingo Ildefonso de Aragon, the leading civil engineer of the era; in 1824 when two of the original ten arches were removed; and in 1859 when stone railings were replaced by wood and marble resting places for the convenience of pedestrians. Four years later, the bridge collapsed and was replaced by a pontoon bridge designed by Pedro Lopez Esguerra. The original bridge was never rebuilt but instead was replaced by the Puente de España.

The Puente de España, erected in 1875, had six spans of masonry and two of iron. Puente de España was almost perfectly aligned with Puente Grande and its south approach was almost side by side with the bridge it was replacing. However, the north approach diverged. Puente Grande landed on Plaza de San Gabriel (now Plaza Moraga) while Puente de España landed on Nueva, now Yuchengco (Noche 2011, 35-36).

Spanning the Pasig was Puente Colgante which connected the old Parian (also Arocerros) with Quiapo. It was also known as Puente de Claveria, in honor of Gov-Gen Narciso de Claveria. It was the second bridge to be built across the Pasig. This toll bridge was a technological innovation because it was a suspension bridge that used steel and steel cable. Erected in 1852, it was the project of a private company, Matias, Mechacatorre y Cia. Construction was entrusted to a French engineer named M. Gaband, and the steel parts were imported from England.

As a suspension bridge, Colgante consisted of two tall concrete towers built on either side of the Pasig. A pair of stout cables hung from the piers and were anchored to the north and south banks. Smaller cables were hung from these stout cables and supported the roadway which was a trussed bridge. Steel railings flanked the bridge, and iron street lamps provided illumination. Built for human andcalesaor horse carriage traffic, the bridge survived the earthquake of 1863 and was for more than a decade the only link between north and south Manila. The bridge lastedto the 1920s when it was replaced by the art deco Quiapo Bridge, later renamed Quezon Bridge (Noche 2011, 39). Suspension bridges were built in other parts of the Philippines where piers could not be sunk into the riverbed, such as during the campaign to conquer Mindanao in the 19th century.

Puente de Santa Cruz connected Santa Cruz with the southern bank. Begun during the Spanish era, it was completed during the American era. Carlos de Heras designed the bridge with a reinforcing truss at the center. This allowed for a more stable and wider bridge. The bridge was damaged during World War II and was replaced by a flat deck bridge known as McArthur (Noche 2011, 43).

Puente de la Convalesencia, built in 1880, had two parts. The first part landed at Isla de Convalesencia, now home to Hospicio de San Jose; the second part started from Isla to San Miguel district. Initially, the bridge was made of wood, but it was replaced by a steel bridge now popularly known as Ayala Bridge because it was the project of the Ayala y Compañia. The bridge had the central steel sections manufactured by the company of Gustave Eiffel in France. Eiffel is famous for the tower named after him. Eduardo Lopez Navarro designed the bridge which connected Paco and San Miguel. It collapsed in 1890, and the government decided to build Santa Cruz bridge to replace it (Noche 2011, 40).

Puente de Blanco, also Puente de Binondo, and Puente de Meisic are both in Chinatown along Ongpin St. The first is closer to the Binondo Church, but both have all but disappeared under later additions. Puente de Binondo traces to a structure built in 1796 although it is uncertain how much of this bridge survives. It spans the Estero de Binondo. Puente de Meisic spans estero de Magdalena (Noche 2011, 48-51).

The Acueducto de Carriedo, built in 1883, carried neither human nor vehicular traffic but supported the large iron pipes that brought water from Marikina River and the springs of San Juan to a covered reservoir called El Deposito. This reservoir, which was near the present-day San Juan City Hall, then brought the water to Manila. The whole acueducto (aqueduct) was named after Francisco de Carriedo, mayor of Manila, who in the 18th century left an endowment of 10,000 pesos for a water works for the city. It took more than a century for the project to get underway. Today, small sections of the aqueduct exist; some are overgrown, while others are occupied by informal settlers (Noche 2011, 47).

Puentes de Ferrocarril is a generic name of bridges built as part of the Plano General de los Ferrocarriles del Norte de Filipinas (Master Plan for the Railroad of Northern Philippines) prepared in the 1870s by military engineers Juan D. Barry, Manuel Saenz de Peralta, and Luciano Maria Bremon. The plan called for a network that would link Manila with Laoag, the first phase of which was a link to Dagupan. In 1875, a royal decree defined the rules governing the concession, construction, and operation of the railway. Eduardo Lopez Navarro as director of the Obras Publicas was appointed to implement the project. The plan called for laying down 1,730 km of track through provinces known for its rich agricultural output and growing population. A spur from Quingua, Bulacan would bring the railroad to Cabanatuan which would then connect with Cagayan Valley in the future. A plan to run south to Bicol was also planned. Except for the Manila-Dagupan line, the rest of the plan remained unimplemented because of the Philippine Revolution.

A number of bridges of this system survived World War II. One was the Puente de Ferrocarril de Labangan at Calumpit, Bulacan, which was recently demolished. Edward Sykes of London was awarded the concession to build the railway in 1887, but the following year it was transferred to Jorge Higgins Wellfith, representing the Manila Railway Co. Ltd., an English registered company. On 8 Jul 1887, Don Carlos E. de Bertodano arrived in Manila to inaugurate construction. On 31 Jul, the cornerstone for the Tutuban Station was laid, and work began. Most of the construction materials were imported—railroad ties and bridge timbers came from Australia, and Portland cement, rails, switches, track spikes and bolts, bridges, and cast iron caissons were from England. Bertodano supervised construction initially until taken ill and replaced by Horace Higgins. The bridges followed British lattice design for the spans. Piers were set up by sinking 6 ft x 6 ft drums that were bolted as they sunk. Enclosed material was dug, filled, and weighed down. If the river bed was soft, piles were first driven into it before the piers were erected. At the ends of the bridge were concrete piers reinforced by stone masonry. The bridge at Calumpit represents the type of bridge built for the railroad system (Noche 2011, 61-2).

North of Manila. Traveling northeast leads to Cagayan Valley, which for most of its history was isolated from the capital and was accessible through the Rio Grande de Cagayan, which ran through a wide plain between two mountain ranges, the Central Cordillera to the west and the Sierra Madre to the east. Dominicans evangelized the valley, traveling from Manila to Aparri then down the Rio Grande up to Ilagan, Isabela. From Ilagan, travel was through horse and river boat. Cagayan opened to land travel in the 19th century with the work of the Obras Publicas and the intrepid road-builder Fr Juan Villaverde, OP. In 1890, he opened a trail later named after him. Another well-known friar builder in Cagayan was Antonio Lobato de Santa Maria, OP. Responsible for building the church and convent of Tuguegarao, and the three hornos or kilns for firing bricks, only one of three bridges he constructed survived—Puente de Penque-Ruyu. Puente Dampol in Dupax was first constructed in 1775 under Fr Manuel Corripio, OP. In 1812, the bridge was destroyed by an earthquake; subsequently, Fr Francisco Rocamora, OP built a replacement in 1818 which still stands today. Puente de San Luis in Solano is one of the few surviving bridges built by Fr Villaverde. Named after the town patron San Luis de Beltran and planned as early as 1884, the project could not be realized immediately because Villaverde was opening the Camino de Quiangan. Villaverde finally constructed the San Luis bridge between 1884 and 1891, when he was appointed pastor of the town (Noche 2011, 109-16).

As early as 1572, the Spaniards had entered the Ilocos. That year, Juan de Salcedo founded Ciudad Fernandina, which is now known as Vigan. The Augustinians evangelized Ilocos. In Ilocos Norte, Puente de Barit in Laoag which is along the Laoag-Bacarra National Road is made of bricks and segmented into three arches. Little is known about this bridge. Paoay, whose church of San Agustin is listed as World Heritage Site by UNESCO, has two brick bridges leading to it: Puente de Paoay on the Paoay-Currimao Road and Puentecito de Cabuyog. Considered the more beautiful and well built of the two, Puente de Paoay has a decorative parapet over a wide elliptical arch bridge. Little is known about its history. Badoc has two bridges—a large and small bridge called Puente Grande de Balaybaboy and Puente Chico. Both are made of bricks, originally covered with lime plaster. The two bridges were probably built simultaneously. Fr Antonio Estavillo, OSA, curate in the 18th century, or Fr Santiago Muñis, OSA, who built the Badoc convent in brick in the 1860s, are the two likely builders of these bridges. In Ilocos Sur, Puente de Santa Maria crosses the estero of the same name. The brick and bridge may have been built by Fr Juan Cardaño, OSA, who was parish priest beginning in 1804 (Noche 2011, 117-28).

Abra was a dependency of Ilocos Sur until it was erected as an independent province in 1917. In 1876, Vigan was established as an engineering district of the Obras Publicas. Eduardo Soriano was appointed district engineer. He had three assistants. There are four colonial bridges in Bangued along the streets Howard Taft, Santiago, Peñarubia, and Francis Burton Harrison. All made of brick and rubble, the bridges appear to have been constructed during the same period. Puente de Calle Governor Howard Taft is the most interesting of these because its railings are rendered as undulating waves meeting at the center where the semicircular parapet terminates in a bulbous finial. No data about its construction is known, but it may have been built under Soriano (Noche 2011, 129-32).

Batanes was evangelized by the Dominicans who island-hopped from Aparri in Cagayan Valley to the Babuyanes and to the Batanes Island group in 1680. By 1688, the Dominicans had left Batanes for various reasons, including the difficulty of supporting the remote island group financially. In 1719, the Dominicans returned at the initiative of Fr Juan Bel, vicar of the Babuyanes. From then on, with the support of the crown, the Dominican mission flourished so that in 1783, Batanes was recognized as colonial territory and integrated into the Philippines.

The Dominicans were responsible for building churches, convents, and the infrastructure of the islands. They also introduced stone and mortar construction, which was adapted by vernacular architecture to create the typhoon resistant house of the native Ivatan. Puente de Ivana on the Camino Real that leads to Ivana is a triple arched structure of stone masonry. It may have been constructed during the term of Fr Nicolas Castaño, OP, 1798-1824. Puente de San Vicente, also in Ivana may also be the work of Fr Castaño or Fr Fabian Martin, OP, 1850-60, who oversaw the construction of two bridges in Ivana. Puente de Mahatao was built by Fr Cresencio Polo, OP during his term as parish priest, 1867-87. The bridge led directly to the Mahatao church. Puentecito de Mahatao, a small bridge along the Mahatao-Uyugan road, is unusual for its triangular rather than rounded arch. Puente de Yugan in Uyugan, consisting of three arches broken by stout piers, lies hidden under a slab of concrete decking added in the 20th century. It was built by Fr Fabian Martin during his term as missionary of Ivana. The mission of San Antonio de Yugan was renamed Uyugan between 1844 and 1878 (Noche 2011, 129-38).

South of Manila. Puente de Zapote, Las Piñas is noted for being a scene of battles between the Katipuneros and the Spanish troops in 1897, and between the Katipuneros and the Americans in 1899. In Imus, Cavite is Puente de Isabel II, was built by Fray Matias in 1875. Its central pier is marked by a cross. Puente de Mabacao, along the Maragondon-Magallanes road was built in 1876, presumably by Eduardo Lopez Navarro. There are more bridges reported in Cavite but their provenance has yet to be determined (Noche 2011, 65-9).

The rapid economic growth of Batangas, brought about by a boom in coffee, its newest cash crop, and the steady growth of coconut plantations, made it imperative that the road system of Batangas be improved. To make this happen, the government created a distinct engineering district under Antonio de la Camara, who served as director of engineering from 1877 to 1888. While a road system, with bridges over rivers and chasms, had been laid out, the road was not paved. Americans improved on Batangas’s road system. In Batangas are Puente de Cay Utak and Puente de Kawa-Kawa at San Jose de Malaquing Tubig. Located along the old San Jose-Lipa road, both may be the work of Fr Ramon Sanchez, OSA, who restored the church and built its belfry in 1856. Puente de Pansipit along the Taal-Lemery road was built in the late 19th century probably by Navarro or Batangas district engineer de la Camara. Puentecito de Caysasay, ca 1850, in Taal is attributed to Fr Celestino Mayordomo, OSA. Taal has many other bridges whose dates of construction and designers are uncertain: Puente de Calle Laurel and Puente de M.H. del Pilar. Puente de Bauan on the Bauan-Batangas National Road has been renovated. Only its eastern and western flanks have the original masonry work (Noche 2011, 70-9).

Laguna was the site of many friar estates owned by the Dominicans and Jesuits. Some of the infrastructure in this area were the result of their effort. Equally active in construction were the Franciscans. Although they did not own any estates as their own rule of life did not allow it, the Franciscans were avid bridge builders. Fr Victorino de Moral de Calatrava, OFM built Puente de Capricho in Majayjay in 1849-52. The bridge crossed Rio de Olla and linked the church with the town’s outskirts. Fr Victorino was highly unpopular for his exaction of labor for his building projects. Responding to complaints about him, Fr Victorino was assigned to Lucban, leaving the bridge of whim unfinished. Also crossing the Rio de Olla is Puente de Olla, inaugurated on 5 Dec 1874 (Noche 2011, 80-6). This bridge was destroyed by Typhoon Santi (international name: Mirinae) in 2003, and subsequently replaced by a concrete one.

Like Laguna, neighboring Quezon, has a collection of stone bridges built at the initiative of the Franciscan friars. Puente de Alitao linked Sariaya and Tayabas, the capital of the province, with the same name. An earlier wooden bridge built in 1798 was replaced by stone in 1823 during the tenure of Gov Juan Lopez. Three bridges, all in Tayabas, were essential in making this capital accessible: Puente de Don Francisco de Asis, 1854; Puente de Malagonlong, 1841-50, initiated by Fr Antonio Matheus, OFM; Puente de Mate and Puente de Lakawan. Puente de Capricho a.k.a. Puente de Arco, in Lucban, was damaged during World War II and is no longer used (Noche 2011, 87-98).

Bicol’s improved infrastructure came about as a means to protect the peninsula from slave raiders. Better roads, bridges, and a string of watchtowers made for rapid deployment of troops to respond to raids. Likewise, improved roads allowed coastal villagers to seek refuge in high ground. Bicol’s infrastructure was greatly improved with the appointment of Jose Ma. Peñaranda as governor on 14 May 1834. Under his term, a rapid improvement of Bicol’s defensive facilities was initiated.

The builders of the bridges of Albay are uncertain. Puente de Busay, built along Camalig-Daraga road may be the work of Ricardo Ayuso who was appointed as district engineer of Nueva Caceres, or of the Franciscan friars. Puente de Camalig may be the work of Fr Miguel Antonio de Barcela, OFM who was parish priest for two long periods, 1846-64, and 1875-70. Puente de Basud Segundo, Polangui may be the work of Fr. Jose Arnau, OFM who was parish priest from 1839 to 1848 or Fr Isidro Pons, OFM, parish priest from 1859-64. Puente de Travesia, Guinobatan may be the work of Fr Zeferino de Quintanar, parish priest from 1851 to 1863. Puente de Paulog, Lig-ao may have been built at the same time as Puente de Busay and Puente de San Jose. Like most Bicol bridges, information on year of construction and builder of Puente de Malinao and Puente San Jose, Bagacay are uncertrain (Noche 2011: 99-108).

Islands South of Luzon. Marinduque was a mission of the Franciscans, but in 1615, it was transferred to the Jesuits. Puente de Boac in Barangay Murallon is a single arched masonry bridge. Year of construction and builder are uncertain. Since the 1930s, its road deck and supporting parapets have been remodeled, obscuring its Hispanic roots (Noche 2011, 147).

Romblon in the Sibuyan Sea belonged to a cluster of islands evangelized by the Recollects beginning 1635. These islands included Banton and Tablas. The Recollects were responsible for much of the Spanish era construction, building churches, conventos, fortifications, roads and bridges. In 1853. Romblon became a comandancia politico-militar. Three bridges cluster near each other in small areas in the poblacion of the municipality of Romblon, Romblon. Puente de Belen is named for the statue of Nuestra Señora de Belen found near the bridge. The bridge leads to the parish church of San Jose. Puente de Romblon spans the same dry riverbed as Puente de Belen and like it has seats along its side. Puente de Rio Casalogan spans the Casalogan river. The year and builder of these bridges is uncertain. It could have been built by the Recollect Fathers like Fr Pedro de San Agustin, 1644-1726, who built the church at Romblon. Noche (2011, 140) suggests that these bridges may have been built under Don Eduardo Asuero y Soto, the province’s Commandant P. M. el Teniente de Infanteria, who built the town’s water system in 1864. The bridges may have been built at this time (Noche 2011, 139-46).

Visayas. Panay was evangelized by the Augustinians. Puente de Boni en route to Miag-ao was built in 1854 during the term of Miguel Navales as gobernadorcillo (mayor). The bridge is named after Boni Neular who served as maestro de obras (master builder). No longer functional, the bridge is a decorative element in a park. The bridge is slightly curved, the result of an earthquake in 1948. There are three bridges in Alimodian, the most significant of which is Puente de Eloisa, probably built during the incumbency of Fr Florencio Martin who built the church of Santo Tomas de Villanueva de Alimodian (Noche 2011, 163-67).

Cebu was also evangelized by the Augustinians. Puente de Salog in Samboan may have been built at the same time as Jacob’s ladder, a stairway of stone that leads from the road to the crest of a hill where Samboan church stands. The bridge located a few meters from the bottom of the ladder may be the work of the secular priest Toribio Gerzon, parish priest from 1847 to 1897. Other bridges in Cebu are the Parian in Cebu City, Puente de Montañesa in Malabuyoc, and an unnamed bridge in Alegria demolished to give way to the expansion of the Cebu Circumferential road (Noche 2011, 159-62). There are bridges, too, in Cauayan and Dalaguete.

Leyte and Southern Leyte were Jesuit missions founded in 1595 but turned over to Augustinians in 1768 and in the 19th century to the Franciscans. Puente de la Purisima in Palo spans the Rio Bangon. It is a 19th-century bridge. Puente de la Reina in Ormoc City is no longer functioning as a bridge but as a decorative element in a park behind the city hall. Construction of the bridge began on 30 Jun 1864 and was completed in 1865 during the incumbency of Gen Francisco de Herrera, district governor of Leyte. Puente de Combado in Maasin crosses the Putat Creek. It was built in the late 18th century (Noche 2011, 151-58).

Bohol was evangelized by the Jesuits who arrived in 1596. The area was turned over to the Recollects in 1768. Most of the bridges in Bohol are in the south. Dimiao has five Spanish colonial bridges, but the more outstanding ones were Puente de Calle Mabini and Puente de Tonga Can-andan. Puente de Calle Mabini in Dimiao is located inland. Its history is uncertain. Puente de Tonga Can-andan along the Dimiao-Valencia Road may have been the work of Fr Enrique de Santo Tomas de Villanueva, OAR, who was the parish priest in 1795-1805, 1806-12, and 1815-17, or Fr Manuel Carasuan de San Pascual, OAR, the parish priest in 1844-45.

Puente de Riego in Loboc is one of six bridges built during the incumbency of Fr Aquilino Bon in 1856. Fr Bon was known for his architectural projects. The new facade of Loboc church and its free-standing bell tower are the works of Bon. The five other bridges of Loboc are: Puente de Guadalupe, Puente de Garita, Puente de San Pedro, Puente de Alagras, and Puente de La Loma. Puente de Lam-ao in Lila was built in the 19th century. Other Bohol bridges are Puente de Dauis; Puente de Balbalan, Puente de Calle Mabini, Puente de Dimiao, and Puente de Taongon, all in Dimiao; and Puente de Tiguis, Puente de Lumanoy, and Puente de Lum-ap, all in Lila. A bridge of earthwork, technically called a causeway, was built during the 19th century in Bohol to link the towns of Tagbilaran and Dauis. Rammed earth held by stone riprap at its approaches crossed the Dauis channel. The middle span was made of wood and elevated so that boats could still travel through the channel (Noche 2011, 167-71).

American Colonial Era

While the Spanish built many bridges in the 19th century, bridge building during the American period took on a faster pace as the colonial government sought to improve transportation and communication. Deteriorating bridges were repaired or replaced by new ones. Work begun during the Spanish era was improved and continued.

American-built bridges were of three types. The most durable, the steel bridge, consisted of girders or trusses resting on concrete piers sunk into the riverbed. This was the truss bridge. The roadway could be made of sturdy lumber, like molave, or paved with asphalt. A rung below the steel bridge was the wooden bridge that spanned creeks and rivulets. This bridge followed the structural design of the girder bridge or consisted of a triangular arch, with the bases embedded in the earth and the apex supporting the span. The structure supported the roadway, which was flanked by railings on either side. A third type of bridge, similar to the pontoon bridge, rested on the surface of the water and was used while a permanent bridge was being repaired or built.

Many American-built bridges are still used today. The Ayala Bridge over the Pasig is one example. In 1906, this steel truss bridge replaced the old Puente de la Convalesencia. The bridge linked the north and south banks of the Pasig with a short spur connecting to the Isla. During the American regime, other hispanic bridges built over the Pasig were also replaced by new ones.

Jones Bridge replaced Puente de España damaged by a typhoon in 1914. Construction on the pre-World War II bridge began in 1916 and was completed in 1921. Designed by Juan Arellano, it was built west of the Puente de España. It was considered the most beautiful bridge of its time—allegorical statues decorated its approach and the sides of its piers, complementing its neoclassical design. The concrete statues have been attributed to Ramon Martinez; however, this attribution has been placed in doubt and the name of German sculptor, Otto Fisher-Credo, has been cited. Fisher-Credo, 1890-1959, who collaborated with Arellano on the sculptures and decorative elements of the Legislative building, was born in Berlin and died in Vancouver. He studied at the academies of art in Berlin, 1908-15, and in Paris, 1919-21. He lived in the Philippines, Mexico, Cuba, the United States, and settled in Canada. He befriended Mexican muralist Diego Rivera in Mexico. In 1926, he had his first solo show in Manila and then lived in Manila for six years. Photographs of Fisher-Credo’s studio show the Madre Filipina, one of four statues on the bridge in his studio. The dolphins flanking the bridge piers are by Fisher-Credo.

The bridge cost one million dollars to build and was criticized for being so luxurious. Destroyed during World War II, it was replaced by a simpler bridge after. Three of the four statues on the bridge survived bombardment in 1945. Madre Filipina was moved to Rizal Park and the two other statues to the front of the Court of Appeals.

Quiapo Bridge in the art deco style was built to replace Puente Colgante. The bridge was allowed to function until Quiapo Bridge was completed and then Colgante was taken down. The Spanish era Santa Cruz Bridge was completed during the American era. Santa Cruz was damaged during World War II and replaced by a reinforced structure after the war. Quiapo Bridge on which the Americans mounted large cannons to shell the southern side of Manila, especially Intramuros where Japanese troops had retreated and taken refuge, was generally spared from damage. Quiapo Bridge would afterwards be renamed Quezon Bridge.

When Bonifacio Drive was built as an extension of Dewey Blvd, a bridge was built to connect the road with the North Harbor on the northern side of the Pasig. It was named Del Pan, and much later renamed Roxas.

Many American-built bridges still stand all over the Philippines. Built from 1901 to 1905, Kennon Road linked Rosario, La Union with Baguio, the summer capital. To bridge gaps between chasms, trestle bridges were built, later to be replaced by steel truss bridges. One of the longest bridges is found in Carmen, Pangasinan. Its central section was a truss bridge which was unfortunately damaged by the earthquake of 1990. Many bridges of the American Era were truss bridges, found all over Luzon and as far south as Cagayan de Oro. Made of standardized girders, they were composed of trusses, a structure of connected elements shaped as a triangle. The trusses were imported from the United States and the units were sent where needed. It was easy to construct a truss bridge—all that was needed was to bolt and weld the units together.

 

 

Period of the Republics

Much of Philippine infrastructure was destroyed during World War II. During the 1940s and 1950s, rehabilitation was the guiding principle. With the use of reinforced concrete which was introduced in the pre-World War II era, bridges built after the war took on simpler lines. Massive piers built into the riverbed supported reinforced-concrete girders. The roadways were paved with concrete or asphalt and were flanked by pedestrian walkways with concrete railings.

Reinforced concrete bridges were common during the post-World War II period and as reinforced concrete improved and better engineering techniques developed, the construction of lighter, longer, and stronger bridge spans made it possible to connect not only waterways but also low areas prone to flooding and the intersections of roads. All this gave rise to superhighways and elevated roads.

From the 1960s to the 1980s, the government prided itself in the improvement of infrastructure in the country. Cemented highways were built to link the capital, Manila, with provinces north and south. At intersections, where heavy traffic was expected to converge, underpasses and overpasses were built.

It was during Ferdinand Marcos’s first term, 1965-69, that the development and construction of infrastructure assumed a rapid pace. His success at public works was one reason why he was voted to a second term. Marcos prided himself for having had built more roads and bridges than all the previous administrations. The construction of the North Diversion road, now North Luzon Expressway or NLEX, began during Marcos’s first term. NLEX introduced a number of innovations in the bridges that had to be built over the toll way to allow for through traffic from Manila to the north. Ramps or interchanges which were variations of bridges had to be constructed. The connection between NLEX and EDSA at Balintawak was a cloverleaf, the first such structure in the Philippines. Other interchange types were diamond, folded diamond with roundabout, trumpet, trumpet with roundabout, half Y, and parcio or partial cloverleaf.

The North Expressway has an elevated portion, the Candaba Viaduct, which stretches for about 40 km above flood-prone areas. Although called a viaduct, structurally it is a long bridge resting on piers sunk into the flat plains of Pampanga. Also constructed was the Patapat Viaduct linking Pagudpud, Ilocos Norte and the Cagayan Valley. Elevated 31 m above the sea and running along the northernmost coast of Luzon, it is 1.3 km long.

During Marcos’s second term, two bridge projects stood out: the San Juanico and the Cebu-Mactan bridge. Construction began on the San Juanico in 1969 and finished in 1973 during the era of martial law. This arched shaped truss bridge was 2,200 m or 2.2 km, making it the longest bridge in the Philippines. The bridge linked Santa Rita on Samar Island and Tacloban on Leyte. The bridge was part of the Pan-Philippine Highway that ran through the eastern side of Luzon. The bridge had a graceful S-curve when exiting San Juanico Island to move north toward Samar.

The channel separating Mandaue, Cebu, and Mactan Island was bridged to expedite traffic between these two islands. The project was integral to the construction of an international airport at Mactan, as the old Cebu airport at Lahug was dangerous for aircrafts because of its proximity to the mountains and its inadequacy for handling larger airplanes that had international routes. Construction on the bridge began in 1970 and was completed in 1972. The box truss type bridge was 846 m long and 9 m wide.

Building bridges continued after the Marcos era as government improved infrastructure. Lahar from the 1991 eruption of Mt Pinatubo covered the Central Plains, especially Pampanga, and made MacArthur Highway impassable. To address this problem, the section of MacArthur that had been covered was raised and a suspension bridge was built between Mabalacat, Pampanga and Capas, Tarlac.

In Cebu, a second bridge was opened in Aug 1999 to connect Mandaue with Lapu-Lapu City. Named after Supreme Court Justice, Marcelo Fernan, of Cebu, it is a cable-stayed bridge 1,237 m long. The central span is 185 m. In this bridge type, the central section is a suspension bridge anchored to a central tower.

The bridge has been used further in constructing elevated highways or skyways, for building approaches to the highways, and as a system to channel traffic. Bridges also link tall buildings and may be elevated pedestrian passages from one building to the next in the business district of a city.  Written by René B. Javellana
